                            <comment id="12830691" author="bishiboosh" created="Sun, 7 Feb 2010 10:33:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In the javadoc, the only example with &quot;&quot; as first parameter for the String version is StringUtils.indexOf(&quot;&quot;, &quot;&quot;) = 0&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Will this example be still valid ? Do I understand clearly that we must have both this behaviour and StringUtils.indexOf(&quot;&quot;, *) = -1 ?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12830848" author="chandrashekarm" created="Mon, 8 Feb 2010 06:44:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;          StringUtils.indexOf(&quot;&quot;,&quot;&quot;)   returns 0&lt;br/&gt;
          StringUtils.indexOf(&quot;&quot;,&quot;a&quot;)  returns -1 &lt;br/&gt;
          StringUtils.indexOf(&quot;&quot;,&apos;&apos;)  cant be given&lt;br/&gt;
          StringUtils.indexOf(&quot;&quot;,&apos;c&apos;) returns  -1&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think API is working correctly or is there any other scenario where it behaves  differently?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12830854" author="bayard" created="Mon, 8 Feb 2010 06:58:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks Valentin and Chandrashekar. You&apos;re both correct.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve updated the javadoc to make it clearer, sorry for the false alarm &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Adding extra javadoc to point out that usually indexOf on an empty String == -1. &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-589&quot; title=&quot;StringUtils: indexOf(&amp;quot;&amp;quot;, String) and indexOf(&amp;quot;&amp;quot;, char) have different behaviour&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-589&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-589&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&quot; src/&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/StringUtils.java&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-587] ClassUtils.toClass(Object[]) throws NPE on null array element</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-587</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;see summary&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12455497">LANG-587</key>
            <summary>ClassUtils.toClass(Object[]) throws NPE on null array element</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mbenson">Matthew Jason Benson</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-586] Use of ThreadLocals in ToStringStyle and HashCodeBuilder trigger memory leaks in container environments</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-586</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The thread local in org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.ToStringStyle is created but never removed and no API is provided to remove it. If a webapp&apos;s use of LANG triggers the loading of this class, a reference chain will be created that will cause a memory leak on web application reload.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;See &lt;a href=&quot;http://markmail.org/thread/uetw2fdrsqgbh2cv&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://markmail.org/thread/uetw2fdrsqgbh2cv&lt;/a&gt; for more info.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12455350">LANG-586</key>
            <summary>Use of ThreadLocals in ToStringStyle and HashCodeBuilder trigger memory leaks in container environments</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-585] exception.DefaultExceptionContext.getFormattedExceptionMessage catches Throwable</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-585</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;It&apos;s generally a bad idea to catch Throwable.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The getFormattedExceptionMessage method should be changed to catch less; e.g. Exception + RuntimeException should be adequate.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The Javadoc examples in ContextedException and ContextedRuntimeException suggest catching Throwable; these examples should be changed too.&lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12447102">LANG-585</key>
            <summary>exception.DefaultExceptionContext.getFormattedExceptionMessage catches Throwable</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebb">Sebb</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sun, 31 Jan 2010 01:34:20 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 3 Feb 2010 11:41:44 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 3 Feb 2010 07:38:33 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>3.0</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.exception.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12828021" author="bayard" created="Mon, 1 Feb 2010 06:58:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Agreed, setting fix version to 3.0.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12828995" author="bayard" created="Wed, 3 Feb 2010 07:38:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed - Exception caught now instead of Throwable. That handles RuntimeException too.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Fixing &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-585&quot; title=&quot;exception.DefaultExceptionContext.getFormattedExceptionMessage catches Throwable&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-585&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-585&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;. Don&apos;t catch Throwable, catch Exception instead. &quot;&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/exception/DefaultExceptionContext.java&lt;br/&gt;
Transmitting file data .&lt;br/&gt;

                            <comment id="12829037" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Wed, 3 Feb 2010 11:41:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Also fixed Javadoc that referred to Throwable:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?rev=906015&amp;amp;view=rev&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?rev=906015&amp;amp;view=rev&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-584] ExceptionUtils uses mutable lock target</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-584</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;ExceptionUtils uses a mutable lock target: both the methods removeCauseMethodName() and addCauseMethodName() take out a lock on CAUSE_METHOD_NAMES but then modify it.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;That doesn&apos;t work - locks need to be immutable.&lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12446940">LANG-584</key>
            <summary>ExceptionUtils uses mutable lock target</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebb">Sebb</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 28 Jan 2010 18:22:48 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 3 Mar 2010 09:34:30 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 2 Feb 2010 23:37:20 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.exception.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12806396" author="bayard" created="Fri, 29 Jan 2010 17:11:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Looks like, apart from one comment, we removed being able to modify the cause names in 3.0. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;API is (the deprecated):&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public static Throwable getCause(Throwable throwable) {&lt;br/&gt;
    public static Throwable getCause(Throwable throwable, String[] methodNames) {&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12806397" author="bayard" created="Fri, 29 Jan 2010 17:12:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;javadoc mention of addCauseMethodName removed. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Do you think this should stay open against 2.x, or minor and close?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12806456" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 29 Jan 2010 19:24:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;If the methods are to be kept, then the easiest solution is just to create an immutable lock object and use that instead.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If that&apos;s OK, I&apos;m happy to implement it.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12806642" author="bayard" created="Sat, 30 Jan 2010 08:09:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Sticking in 2.x in case such a thing ever happens. Not an issue in 3.0.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12828837" author="niallp" created="Tue, 2 Feb 2010 23:37:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Looks like this was fixed in trunk before the locks were removed:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;amp;revision=755391&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;amp;revision=755391&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;So I ported that change back to the 2.x branch:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;amp;revision=905837&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;amp;revision=905837&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-581] Javadoc bug in org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtils.removeEndIgnoreCase()</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-581</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;the org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtils online document &lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/lang/api-release/org/apache/commons/lang/StringUtils.html#removeEndIgnoreCase%28java.lang.String,%20java.lang.String%29&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/lang/api-release/org/apache/commons/lang/StringUtils.html#removeEndIgnoreCase%28java.lang.String,%20java.lang.String%29&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;at removeEndIgnoreCase()  description, there is one line &lt;br/&gt;
StringUtils.removeEnd(&quot;www.domain.com&quot;, &quot;.com.&quot;)  = &quot;www.domain.com.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;it should be &lt;br/&gt;
StringUtils.removeEnd(&quot;www.domain.com&quot;, &quot;.com.&quot;)  = &quot;www.domain.com&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Online document&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12445485">LANG-581</key>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-578] Problem while using simple quotes in ExtendedMessageFormat when a registry is specified</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-578</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;This runs successfully : &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;ExtendedMessageFormat templateFormat = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; ExtendedMessageFormat(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;&apos;{0}&apos;&lt;/span&gt;&apos;&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(templateFormat.format(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;[] { &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;MESSAGE&quot;&lt;/span&gt; })); 
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The result is &apos;MESSAGE&apos;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This raises an error :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;Map&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;, FormatFactory&amp;gt; formatFactory = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; HashMap&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;, FormatFactory&amp;gt;();
        formatFactory.put(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;formatDate&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; FormatFactory() {

            @SuppressWarnings(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;all&quot;&lt;/span&gt;)
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; Format getFormat(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; name, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; arguments, Locale locale) {

                &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; SimpleDateFormat();
            }
        });
ExtendedMessageFormat templateFormat = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; ExtendedMessageFormat(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;&apos;{0}&apos;&lt;/span&gt;&apos;&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, , formatFactory);
&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(templateFormat.format(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;[] { &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;MESSAGE&quot;&lt;/span&gt; })); 
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The result is an exception (java heap space).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;b&gt;way&lt;/b&gt; : In &lt;em&gt;appendQuotedString&lt;/em&gt; method the code above doesn&apos;t seem to increment the index pos before returning&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-575] HashCodeBuilder reflectionAppend creates unnecessary copy of excludeFields</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-575</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;See &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/builder/HashCodeBuilder.java?view=markup&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/builder/HashCodeBuilder.java?view=markup&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please review the implementation for &lt;b&gt;reflectionAppend&lt;/b&gt; (lines 174 to 202)...  Specifically, see line 182:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;List&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt; excludedFieldList = excludeFields != &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt; ? Arrays.asList(excludeFields) : Collections.&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt;emptyList();
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Note that if you are in the habit of passing in a String array for excluding fields (&lt;tt&gt;String[] excludeFields&lt;/tt&gt;) &amp;#8211; which is a best practice when using Hibernate (to skip primary keys (&lt;tt&gt;@id&lt;/tt&gt;) and version fields (&lt;tt&gt;@version&lt;/tt&gt;) that change upon persistence) &amp;#8211; &lt;em&gt;EVERY TIME&lt;/em&gt; the &lt;em&gt;hashCode&lt;/em&gt; is calculated, an &lt;em&gt;ArrayList&lt;/em&gt; is being created &amp;#8211; generating fodder for the garbage collector.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I thought I might get around this by passing a &lt;tt&gt;Collection&amp;lt;String&amp;gt;&lt;/tt&gt; instead of a &lt;tt&gt;String[]&lt;/tt&gt;, but ironically the implementation of the &lt;tt&gt;reflectionHashCode(Object object, Collection&amp;lt;String&amp;gt; excludeFields)&lt;/tt&gt; (see lines 475 to 477), for example, transforms the &lt;tt&gt;Collection&amp;lt;String&amp;gt;&lt;/tt&gt; into a &lt;tt&gt;String[]&lt;/tt&gt; only to have it transformed internally into a temporary &lt;tt&gt;ArrayList&amp;lt;String&amp;gt;&lt;/tt&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I would expect the implementation to use and read what is submitted, whether that is a &lt;tt&gt;String[]&lt;/tt&gt; or a &lt;tt&gt;Collection&amp;lt;String&amp;gt;&lt;/tt&gt;.  I don&apos;t think it needs to create another copy just to have a convenient &lt;tt&gt;contains&lt;/tt&gt; method.  Efficiency is important, especially in the event of rehashing.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Sun Java JDK 1.6.0_17&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12443995">LANG-575</key>
            <summary>HashCodeBuilder reflectionAppend creates unnecessary copy of excludeFields</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="awhitford">Anthony Whitford</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 22 Dec 2009 09:12:17 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 25 Feb 2010 19:51:36 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 9 Jan 2010 11:44:17 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.builder.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12793560" author="awhitford" created="Tue, 22 Dec 2009 09:20:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Note that &lt;b&gt;EqualsBuilder&lt;/b&gt; has the exact same issue.&lt;br/&gt;
See:  &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/builder/EqualsBuilder.java?view=markup&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/builder/EqualsBuilder.java?view=markup&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;b&gt;reflectionAppend&lt;/b&gt;, line 321:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;List&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt; excludedFieldList = excludeFields != &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt; ? Arrays.asList(excludeFields) : Collections.&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt;emptyList();
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;And so does &lt;b&gt;CompareToBuilder&lt;/b&gt;...&lt;br/&gt;
See:  &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/builder/CompareToBuilder.java?view=markup&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/builder/CompareToBuilder.java?view=markup&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;b&gt;reflectionAppend&lt;/b&gt;, line 356:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;List&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt; excludedFieldList = excludeFields != &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt; ? Arrays.asList(excludeFields) : Collections.&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt;emptyList();
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12793561" author="awhitford" created="Tue, 22 Dec 2009 09:22:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Considering how repetitive this issue is, you may want to consider &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-283&quot; title=&quot;Visitors for Builders&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-283&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-283&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; because there does seem to be a refactoring opportunity here.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12795020" author="bayard" created="Tue, 29 Dec 2009 06:43:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Definitely hoping to challenge the builder code before 3.0 is released. Its got the most duplication and the most JIRA items open.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks for both of your optimization suggestions.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-571] ArrayUtils.add(T[] array, T element) can create unexpected ClassCastException</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-571</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;ArrayUtils.add(T[] array, T element) can create an unexpected ClassCastException.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For example, the following code compiles without a warning:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;[] sa = ArrayUtils.add(stringArray, aString);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;and works fine, provided at least one of the parameters is non-null. However, if both parameters are null, the add() method returns an Object[] array, hence the Exception.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If both parameters are null, it&apos;s not possible to determine the correct array type to return, so it seems to me this should be disallowed.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think the method ought to be changed to throw IllegalParameterException when both parameters are null.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12443723">LANG-571</key>
            <summary>ArrayUtils.add(T[] array, T element) can create unexpected ClassCastException</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebb">Sebb</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 18 Dec 2009 04:38:51 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 25 Jan 2010 07:06:14 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 16 Jan 2010 12:39:59 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>3.0</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>

</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-568] @SuppressWarnings(&quot;unchecked&quot;) is used too generally</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-568</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;@SuppressWarnings(&quot;unchecked&quot;) is used in several places on entire methods.&lt;br/&gt;
Mostly there is no documentation as to why it is safe to ignore the warnings.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Seems to me the annotation should be used as close as possible to the site of the warning, and the reason should be documented, so it can be revisited if there is a code change later.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In fact, at least one of the warnings is NOT safe to ignore:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;String[] s = ArrayUtils.add((String[])null, null);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;generates a ClassCastException, which should not happen if the warning is OK to ignore.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12443539">LANG-568</key>
            <summary>@SuppressWarnings(&quot;unchecked&quot;) is used too generally</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="sebb">Sebb</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebb">Sebb</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 16 Dec 2009 15:31:41 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 30 Dec 2009 10:58:04 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 18 Dec 2009 19:03:52 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>3.0</fixVersion>
                                    <component>General</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12791762" author="bayard" created="Thu, 17 Dec 2009 03:30:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Seems good. I count 11 in the main source, so not that painful to fix. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;./ArrayUtils.java:    @SuppressWarnings(&quot;unchecked&quot;)&lt;br/&gt;
./ArrayUtils.java:    @SuppressWarnings(&quot;unchecked&quot;)&lt;br/&gt;
./ArrayUtils.java:    @SuppressWarnings(&quot;unchecked&quot;)&lt;br/&gt;
./ArrayUtils.java:    @SuppressWarnings(&quot;unchecked&quot;)&lt;br/&gt;
./ArrayUtils.java:    @SuppressWarnings(&quot;unchecked&quot;)&lt;br/&gt;
./builder/CompareToBuilder.java:    @SuppressWarnings(&quot;unchecked&quot;)&lt;br/&gt;
./Range.java:            @SuppressWarnings(&quot;unchecked&quot;) // OK because we checked the class above&lt;br/&gt;
./Range.java:        @SuppressWarnings(&quot;unchecked&quot;)&lt;br/&gt;
./Range.java:        @SuppressWarnings(&quot;unchecked&quot;)&lt;br/&gt;
./text/StrBuilder.java:    @SuppressWarnings(&quot;null&quot;) // str cannot be null&lt;br/&gt;
./text/StrLookup.java:            @SuppressWarnings(&quot;unchecked&quot;) // System property keys and values are always Strings&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12792345" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 18 Dec 2009 05:06:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?rev=892135&amp;amp;view=rev&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?rev=892135&amp;amp;view=rev&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Log:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-568&quot; title=&quot;@SuppressWarnings(&amp;quot;unchecked&amp;quot;) is used too generally&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-568&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-568&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; - @SuppressWarnings(&quot;unchecked&quot;) is used too generally&lt;br/&gt;
Partial fix - some warnings remain to be addressed&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?rev=892136&amp;amp;view=rev&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?rev=892136&amp;amp;view=rev&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Log:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-568&quot; title=&quot;@SuppressWarnings(&amp;quot;unchecked&amp;quot;) is used too generally&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-568&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-568&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; - @SuppressWarnings(&quot;unchecked&quot;) is used too generally&lt;br/&gt;
Partial fix - some warnings remain to be addressed&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Note: this exercise has discovered two places where the casts were not safe - see &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-571&quot; title=&quot;ArrayUtils.add(T[] array, T element) can create unexpected ClassCastException&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-571&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-571&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12792581" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 18 Dec 2009 19:03:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?rev=892343&amp;amp;view=rev&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?rev=892343&amp;amp;view=rev&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Log:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-568&quot; title=&quot;@SuppressWarnings(&amp;quot;unchecked&amp;quot;) is used too generally&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-568&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-568&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; - @SuppressWarnings(&quot;unchecked&quot;) is used too generally&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think all the warnings that can be safely suppressed have now been suppressed (and documented).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There are two warnings that remain cannot be suppressed safely; see &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-571&quot; title=&quot;ArrayUtils.add(T[] array, T element) can create unexpected ClassCastException&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-571&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-571&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-567] ArrayUtils.addAll(T[] array1, T... array2) does not handle mixed types very well</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-567</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;ArrayUtils.addAll(T[] array1, T... array2) does not handle mixed array types very well.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The stack trace for &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Number[] st = ArrayUtils.addAll(new Integer[]&lt;/p&gt;
{1}
&lt;p&gt;, new Long[]&lt;/p&gt;
{2L}
&lt;p&gt;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;starts:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.lang.ArrayStoreException&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.lang.System.arraycopy(Native Method)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.ArrayUtils.addAll(ArrayUtils.java:2962)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;which is not all that obvious.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It would be a lot clearer if the method threw an IlegalArgumentException or similar.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12443536">LANG-567</key>
            <summary>ArrayUtils.addAll(T[] array1, T... array2) does not handle mixed types very well</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>

&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?rev=892114&amp;amp;view=rev&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?rev=892114&amp;amp;view=rev&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;

                            <comment id="12792517" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 18 Dec 2009 15:59:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I did consider checking the types before trying the array copy in which case the issue would not have arisen.&lt;/p&gt;

                            <comment id="12792519" author="pbenedict" created="Fri, 18 Dec 2009 16:13:08 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Sebb, I agree. The code should assume things work, and catch exceptions for the exceptional cases. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-564] Improve StrLookup API documentation</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-564</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The API for StrLookup is confused. The class has been partly genericised, but why?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The Javadoc says the class is for looking up Strings which are indexed by Strings, and this agrees with the method lookup()&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Surely if the class is generic on &amp;lt;V&amp;gt;, the lookup() method should return V, not String?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Does it make any sense for the class to return anything but a String? If not, then why is the class generic?&lt;br/&gt;
If it does make sense, then lookup() should return V.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12443271">LANG-564</key>
            <summary>Improve StrLookup API documentation</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebb">Sebb</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 14 Dec 2009 15:03:09 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 23 Aug 2011 08:41:30 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 16 Jan 2010 13:07:22 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>3.0</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.text.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12794333" author="bayard" created="Thu, 24 Dec 2009 06:48:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Agreed that this is confused. I think we should roll back the generics changes.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12794437" author="joehni" created="Thu, 24 Dec 2009 14:32:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Or consider using &amp;lt;T extends CharSequence&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12794448" author="mbenson" created="Thu, 24 Dec 2009 15:54:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;+1 for T extends CharSequence for parameters, but to guarantee a T return type would a) require a Class&amp;lt;T&amp;gt; parameter, and b) require us to make assumptions about constructors of T subclasses... so either String or CharSequence (returning String) would still seem the appropriate RT.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12801123" author="bayard" created="Sat, 16 Jan 2010 08:24:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The class is for providing a Str, Str view on a Str, V storage. From the tests:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;        Map&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Object&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt; map = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; HashMap&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Object&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt;();
        map.put(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;number&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Integer&lt;/span&gt;(2));
        assertEquals(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;2&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, StrLookup.mapLookup(map).lookup(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;number&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Based on that, the genercizing looks good to me (yeah I know I&apos;m contradicting my previous comment, I hadn&apos;t dug into the previous code). I think a bit more javadoc explanation is in need but not a generics change.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12801161" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 16 Jan 2010 13:07:22 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?rev=899933&amp;amp;view=rev&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?rev=899933&amp;amp;view=rev&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Log:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-564&quot; title=&quot;Improve StrLookup API documentation&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-564&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-564&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; Improve StrLookup API documentation&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Modified:&lt;br/&gt;
   commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/text/StrLookup.java&lt;br/&gt;
   commons/proper/lang/trunk/xdocs/changes.xml&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13089035" author="eneveu" created="Mon, 22 Aug 2011 21:34:43 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I was also confused by the StrLookup type parameter while browsing the commons-lang 3.0.1 source. Instead of creating a duplicate issue, I thought it would be better to comment here, even though this issue seems to be closed...&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t see the point of having a generic type parameter on the StrLookup class, if it&apos;s not used anywhere. No method / field in StrLookup references this type parameter. IntelliJ IDEA itself reports a warning: &quot;Type parameter &apos;V&apos; is never used&quot;. Moreover, Java generics are not reified, so there is no reliable way to access the type parameter at runtime (and I don&apos;t see the point of doing that anyway...).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;While the Javadoc tries to clarify the purpose of a StrLookup, the unused type parameter is still confusing, and the client code has to un-necessarily specify type parameters. For example, I have to write:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;StrLookup&amp;lt;?&amp;gt; lookup = StrLookup.noneLookup();
StrLookup&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt; lookup2 = StrLookup.systemPropertiesLookup();
StrLookup&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Integer&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt; lookup3 = StrLookup.mapLookup(integerMap);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;instead of&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;StrLookup lookup = StrLookup.noneLookup();
StrLookup lookup2 = StrLookup.systemPropertiesLookup();
StrLookup lookup3 = StrLookup.mapLookup(integerMap);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;


&lt;p&gt;My best guess is that this type parameter was added when commons-lang was generified, because StringLookup.mapLookup() takes a generified Map. Doing this is not really needed, though: we could remove the &amp;lt;V&amp;gt; type parameter everywhere, and replace the StrLookup.mapLookup()&apos;s Map&amp;lt;String, V&amp;gt; with a Map&amp;lt;String, ?&amp;gt; (which is the same as Map&amp;lt;String, ? extends Object&amp;gt;, but shorter).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I guess it&apos;s too late to change this now, due to backward compatibility... But I thought I&apos;d comment just in case it&apos;s still possible.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13089308" author="bayard" created="Tue, 23 Aug 2011 07:01:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve put your comment in &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TEXT-80&quot; title=&quot;StrLookup API confusing&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;TEXT-80&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-745&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;. Closed issues are far too easy to miss comments on.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13089351" author="eneveu" created="Tue, 23 Aug 2011 08:41:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Ok. I wasn&apos;t sure whether I should create a new issue, but it makes sense since this one was closed 18 months ago. Thanks!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-561] unescapeHtml has been dropped without going through deprecation</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-561</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The method StringEscapeUtils.unescapeHtml() is missing from version 3.0, yet is not deprecated in 2.4.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As far as I can tell, unescapeHtml is now called unescapeHtml4.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;ISTM that unescapeHtml should be reinstated (and deprecated), and perform the same function as Html4.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Another issue - unescapeHtml3 has no Javadoc.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12442682">LANG-561</key>
            <summary>unescapeHtml has been dropped without going through deprecation</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebb">Sebb</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 8 Dec 2009 00:38:49 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 17 Dec 2009 03:41:04 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 10 Dec 2009 12:12:48 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>3.0</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12787255" author="pbenedict" created="Tue, 8 Dec 2009 02:04:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;A 2.4.1 version can be released to deprecate the method appropriately?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12787366" author="bayard" created="Tue, 8 Dec 2009 08:36:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Agreed that unescapeHtml3 needs Javadoc.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t see any reason to deprecate unescapeHtml. There is lots of backwards incompatible changes in Lang, there&apos;s no point trying to sugar coat other changes and putting the pain off until later. Better to get it done with now when people are having to go to the work of making their code work.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12787367" author="bayard" created="Tue, 8 Dec 2009 08:37:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;To go further - there should be no deprecated code in Lang 3.0.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12787604" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 8 Dec 2009 18:05:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;How about keeping unescapeHtml as an alias for unescapeHtml4 in LANG3?&lt;br/&gt;
(With suitable Javadoc).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This would not be the same as keeping deprecated code in LANG3.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I found the problem with the Gump build of JMeter.&lt;br/&gt;
There&apos;s currently no easy way to fix this, as unescapeHtml4 does not exist in LANG2 and LANG3 has yet to be released.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12787657" author="niallp" created="Tue, 8 Dec 2009 19:00:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Presumably there is going to be a package name change before Lang 3.0 is released? If so everything breaks.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12788698" author="bayard" created="Thu, 10 Dec 2009 12:12:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Closing per Sebb&apos;s comment on dev now that the package name has been changed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

    </item>


<item>
            <title>[LANG-557] Javadoc wrong for StringUtils startsWith, startsWithIgnoreCase, endsWith and endsWithIgnoreCase</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-557</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In the examples given along with the descriptions of startsWith, startsWithIgnoreCase, endsWith and endsWithIgnoreCase of StringUtils class, the full string and the suffix/prefix are used in the wrong order.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;eg: &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It is mentioned that StringUtils.startsWith(&quot;abc&quot;, &quot;abcdef&quot;) = true&lt;br/&gt;
It should be StringUtils.startsWith(&quot;abcdef&quot;, &quot;abc&quot;) = true&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/lang//api/org/apache/commons/lang/StringUtils.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/lang//api/org/apache/commons/lang/StringUtils.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-552] StringUtils replaceEach - Bug or Missing Documentation </title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-552</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The following Test Case for replaceEach fails with a null pointer exception.&lt;br/&gt;
I have expected that all StringUtils methods are &quot;null-friendly&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
The use case is that i will stuff Values into the replacementList of which I do not want to check whether they are null.&lt;br/&gt;
I admit the use case is not perfect, because it is unclear what happens on the replace.&lt;br/&gt;
I outlined three expectations in the test case, of course only one should be met.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If it is decided that none of them should be possible, I propose to update the documentation with what happens when null is passed as replacement string&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtils;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; org.junit.Test;


&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;StringUtilsTest {

	@Test
	&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void replaceEach(){
		&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; original = &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;Hello World!&quot;&lt;/span&gt;;
		&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;[] searchList = {&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;Hello&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;World&quot;&lt;/span&gt;};
		&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;[] replacementList = {&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;Greetings&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;};
		&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; result = StringUtils.replaceEach(original, searchList, replacementList);
		assertEquals(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;Greetings !&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, result);
		&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//perhaps &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;this&lt;/span&gt; is ok as well
&lt;/span&gt;                &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//assertEquals(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;Greetings World!&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, result);
&lt;/span&gt;                &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//or even
&lt;/span&gt;		&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//assertEquals(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;Greetings &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;!&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, result);
&lt;/span&gt;	}

	
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12440184">LANG-552</key>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-544] ToStringStyle.registry ThreadLocal initialValue should return a Set that implements reference equality checking instead of object equality</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-544</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;ToStringStyle.registry ThreadLocal initialValue should return a Set that implements reference equality checking instead of object equality.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This change would still protect against cyclical object graphs, but also protect against the following conditions:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Incorrect implementations of hashCode/equals for any objects in the object graph&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Unintended side effects of the hashCode/equals methods for any objects in the object graph&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Unfortunately, Java versions prior to 1.6 do not provide a simple built-in mechanism to create such a Set.  This issue is discussed here in detail:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=4479578&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=4479578&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A possible work-around is to use an IdentityHashMap instead of a Set.  This class is available in Java 1.4 and later.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12438599">LANG-544</key>
            <summary>ToStringStyle.registry ThreadLocal initialValue should return a Set that implements reference equality checking instead of object equality</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="michael.richards@paetec.com">Michael Richards</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 20 Oct 2009 17:22:59 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 21 Oct 2013 05:45:28 +0000</updated>
                                            <version>2.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>Patch Needed</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.builder.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12801127" author="bayard" created="Sat, 16 Jan 2010 08:49:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;If we&apos;re unable to move to JDK 1.6, a possibility is implementing Collections.newSetFromMap(Map) in Lang.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Alternatively, implement an IdentityHashSet (rough draft):&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;package&lt;/span&gt; org.apache.commons.lang3.collections;

&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; java.util.AbstractSet;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; java.util.Collection;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; java.util.HashMap;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; java.util.IdentityHashMap;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; java.util.Iterator;

&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;IdentityHashSet&amp;lt;E&amp;gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;extends&lt;/span&gt; AbstractSet&amp;lt;E&amp;gt; {

    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;private&lt;/span&gt; IdentityHashMap&amp;lt;E, E&amp;gt; decorated;

    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; IdentityHashSet() {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;super&lt;/span&gt;();
    }

    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; IdentityHashSet(Collection&amp;lt;E&amp;gt; collection) {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (collection != &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;) {
            HashMap&amp;lt;E, E&amp;gt; map = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; HashMap&amp;lt;E, E&amp;gt;();
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; (E element : collection) {
                map.put(element, element);
            }
            decorated = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; IdentityHashMap&amp;lt;E, E&amp;gt;(map);
        } &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;else&lt;/span&gt; {
            decorated = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; IdentityHashMap&amp;lt;E, E&amp;gt;();
        }
    }

    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; size() {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; decorated.size();
    }

    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; Iterator&amp;lt;E&amp;gt; iterator() {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; decorated.keySet().iterator();
    }

    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;boolean&lt;/span&gt; add(E element) {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (decorated.contains(element) ) {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;;
        } &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;else&lt;/span&gt; {
            decorated.put(element, element);
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;true&lt;/span&gt;;
        }
    }
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12987426" author="bayard" created="Thu, 27 Jan 2011 07:58:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Moving to 3.1 as no activity on a patch and I don&apos;t have an itch for the builder package. I&apos;d like to see us move to Java 6 in a later 3.x version so might be best implemented then.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-538] DateFormatUtils.format does not correctly change Calendar TimeZone in certain situations</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-538</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If a Calendar object is constructed in certain ways a call to Calendar.setTimeZone does not correctly change the Calendars fields.  Calling Calenar.getTime() seems to fix this problem.  While this is probably a bug in the JDK, it would be nice if DateFormatUtils was smart enough to detect/resolve this problem.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For example, the following unit test fails:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;  public void testFormat_CalendarIsoMsZulu() {
    final String dateTime = &quot;2009-10-16T16:42:16.000Z&quot;;

    // more commonly constructed with: cal = new GregorianCalendar(2009, 9, 16, 8, 42, 16)
    // for the unit test to work in any time zone, constructing with GMT-8 rather than default locale time zone
    GregorianCalendar cal = new GregorianCalendar(TimeZone.getTimeZone(&quot;GMT-8&quot;));
    cal.clear();
    cal.set(2009, 9, 16, 8, 42, 16);


    FastDateFormat format = FastDateFormat.getInstance(&quot;yyyy-MM-dd&apos;T&apos;HH:mm:ss.SSS&apos;Z&apos;&quot;, TimeZone.getTimeZone(&quot;GMT&quot;));
    assertEquals(&quot;dateTime&quot;, dateTime, format.format(cal));
  }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, this unit test passes:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;  public void testFormat_CalendarIsoMsZulu() {
    final String dateTime = &quot;2009-10-16T16:42:16.000Z&quot;;
    GregorianCalendar cal = new GregorianCalendar(TimeZone.getTimeZone(&quot;GMT-8&quot;));
    cal.clear();
    cal.set(2009, 9, 16, 8, 42, 16);
    cal.getTime();

    FastDateFormat format = FastDateFormat.getInstance(&quot;yyyy-MM-dd&apos;T&apos;HH:mm:ss.SSS&apos;Z&apos;&quot;, TimeZone.getTimeZone(&quot;GMT&quot;));
    assertEquals(&quot;dateTime&quot;, dateTime, format.format(cal));
  }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Sun JDK6, RHEL 5.3&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12438318">LANG-538</key>
            <summary>DateFormatUtils.format does not correctly change Calendar TimeZone in certain situations</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="jpeterson">Jeff Peterson</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 16 Oct 2009 16:47:39 +0000</created>

                            <resolved>Thu, 17 Dec 2009 06:05:11 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.time.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12791798" author="bayard" created="Thu, 17 Dec 2009 06:03:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think this is due to FastDateFormat&apos;s:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        if (mTimeZoneForced) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            calendar = (Calendar) calendar.clone();
            calendar.setTimeZone(mTimeZone);
        }

&lt;p&gt;If I call getTime() before that, then the code works. If however I wait until after that to call getTime(), it does not work. The calendar before and after report themselves to be equal, and their toString contains the same information in both cases, yet something must not be getting lazy-initialized and then lost in the clone.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12791799" author="bayard" created="Thu, 17 Dec 2009 06:05:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the report Jeff. I&apos;ve inserted a getTime() into FastDateFormat that fixes your test case, and hopefully extends to the general problem.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Fixing &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-538&quot; title=&quot;DateFormatUtils.format does not correctly change Calendar TimeZone in certain situations&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-538&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-538&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; - you need to call getTime() on a calendar sometimes to get it in the right state, otherwise the timezone gets out of whack. &quot; src&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/time/FastDateFormat.java&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/test/org/apache/commons/lang3/time/FastDateFormatTest.java&lt;br/&gt;
Transmitting file data ..&lt;br/&gt;
Committed revision 891542.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13766132" author="cpm" created="Fri, 13 Sep 2013 01:17:37 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi. This bug is existing in version 3.3.1. The &quot;assertEquals(&quot;dateTime&quot;, dateTime, format.format(cal));&quot; from the test above returns the following error:&lt;br/&gt;
org.junit.ComparisonFailure: dateTime expected:&amp;lt;2009-10-16T&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;16&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;:42:16.000Z&amp;gt; but was:&amp;lt;2009-10-16T&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;08&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;:42:16.000Z&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Reproduced whit Sun Java version: 1.6.0_45 and 1.7.0_21 on Fedora 17 (Linux 3.9.10-100.fc17.i686.PAE).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I will try to clone this issue.&lt;/p&gt;

</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-535] ClassUtils.getShortClassName() will not work with an array;  it seems to add a semicolon to the end.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-535</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;A semicolon is introduced into the class name at the end for all arrays...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;String sArray[] = new String&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;2&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
sArray&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;0&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; = &quot;mark&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
sArray&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; = &quot;is cool&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
String simpleString = &quot;chris&quot;;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;assertEquals(&quot;String&quot;, ClassUtils.getShortClassName(simpleString, null));&lt;br/&gt;
assertEquals(&quot;String;&quot;, ClassUtils.getShortClassName(sArray, null));&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Java 1.4.2&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12436341">LANG-535</key>
            <summary>ClassUtils.getShortClassName() will not work with an array;  it seems to add a semicolon to the end.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mjuchems">mark juchems</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 22 Sep 2009 19:53:54 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 25 Feb 2010 19:22:04 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 15 Oct 2009 07:31:51 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12759012" author="bayard" created="Thu, 24 Sep 2009 05:07:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I wonder if the package name equivalent is prefixed by &apos;[&apos; for arrays.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12759118" author="mjuchems" created="Thu, 24 Sep 2009 13:30:58 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Doing this in java :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;String sArray[] = new String&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;2&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
sArray&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;0&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; = &quot;mark&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
sArray&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; = &quot;is cool&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
String simpleString = &quot;chris&quot;;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;sArray.getClass() = &quot;class [Ljava.lang.String;&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I am sure this is where they are going wrong.  I have not looked into the code, however, I would imagine they are taking everything past the last &quot;.&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I am not sure what the correct return should be.  I know what I would like it to be, and that is apparent.  However, an &quot;array&quot; is a primitive data type and therefore not an Object,  so I believe it should throw and exception.  But that would not be helpful...&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12759158" author="joehni" created="Thu, 24 Sep 2009 16:10:27 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Actually ClassUtils.getShortName should do what Class.getSimpleName does in JDK 1.5&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12759355" author="bayard" created="Fri, 25 Sep 2009 01:59:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Or it needs deleting if there is a JDK 1.5 alternative.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12759401" author="joehni" created="Fri, 25 Sep 2009 06:30:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Since 3.0 targets JDK 1.5 only - yes.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12759514" author="mjuchems" created="Fri, 25 Sep 2009 12:49:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;So I put it all together in 1.5:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;String sArray[] = new String&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;2&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
sArray&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;0&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; = &quot;mark&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
sArray&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; = &quot;is cool&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
sArray.getClass().getSimpleName();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;this returns:  String[]&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I guess the java team has spoken.  I suggest deleting since 1.5 has an alternative...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt; I still think I would rather have just the name and no brackets, however.   For my use I would have to do some additional editing.  I am sending in an Object[] or an Object into a method and need the same behavior for both.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This failed when I sent in an array:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;protected void createXML(XStream xStream, PrintWriter pw, Object o) {&lt;br/&gt;
		pw.write(&quot;&amp;lt;?xml version=\&quot;1.0\&quot; encoding=\&quot;UTF-8\&quot; ?&amp;gt;&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
		xStream.alias(ClassUtils.getShortClassName(o, null), o.getClass());&lt;br/&gt;
		xStream.toXML(o, pw);&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So I changed it to this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;protected void createXML(XStream xStream, PrintWriter pw, Object o, Class c) {&lt;br/&gt;
		pw.write(&quot;&amp;lt;?xml version=\&quot;1.0\&quot; encoding=\&quot;UTF-8\&quot; ?&amp;gt;&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
		xStream.alias(ClassUtils.getShortClassName(c), c);&lt;br/&gt;
		xStream.toXML(o, pw);&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Not a big change, but it is something..&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12759519" author="joehni" created="Fri, 25 Sep 2009 13:06:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In that case you could have written:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;ClassUtils.getShortClassName(o.getClass().isArray() ? o.getClass().getComponentType() : o.getClass())
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, we&apos;re getting OT here. Come to the user&apos;s list of Commons, or for XStream specific questions to XStream&apos;s user&apos;s list ...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Cheers,&lt;br/&gt;
J&#246;rg&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12764960" author="bayard" created="Tue, 13 Oct 2009 05:54:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Difference in behaviour between JDK getSimpleName and Lang getShortClassName:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  JDK returns the class name for an inner class.&lt;br/&gt;
  Lang returns the surrounding class name and the class name of the inner class as the class name.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Difficult to say which is correct imo. Lang relies on &apos;$&apos; as the inner class name separator.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12764972" author="bayard" created="Tue, 13 Oct 2009 06:42:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Plus Lang provides a String API in addition to the Class API. Given that a Class may not be available, this isn&apos;t the same as say relying on the File API instead of Strings for IO work.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12764973" author="bayard" created="Tue, 13 Oct 2009 06:44:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Attaching a patch that adds support for:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;arrays&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;primitive arrays&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;multiple dimension arrays&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Stops getPackageName using the underlying cls.getPackage().getName() after discovering java.lang.String[]&apos;s getPackage to be null (at least within the Maven2/JUnit classloader).&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Plus various tests.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12765947" author="bayard" created="Thu, 15 Oct 2009 07:31:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt; svn ci -m &quot;Applying my patch from &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-535&quot; title=&quot;ClassUtils.getShortClassName() will not work with an array;  it seems to add a semicolon to the end.&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-535&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-535&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; - adding support to getShortClassName and getPackageName for arrays, including primitive arrays and multi-dimensional arrays. Also stopped getPackageName relying on the underlying class.getPackage as it&apos;s sometimes null&quot; src/test/org/apache/commons/lang/ClassUtilsTest.java src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/ClassUtils.java &lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/ClassUtils.java&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/test/org/apache/commons/lang/ClassUtilsTest.java&lt;br/&gt;
Transmitting file data ..&lt;br/&gt;
Committed revision 825420.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
