<item>
            <title>[LANG-432] Fix case-insensitive string handling</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-432</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;String.to*Case()&lt;/tt&gt; is locale-sensitive, this is usually not intended for case-insensitive comparisions. Please see &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nabble.com/Re%3A-Common-Bugs-p14931921s177.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Common Bug #3&lt;/a&gt; for details.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12394820">LANG-432</key>
            <summary>Fix case-insensitive string handling</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bentmann">Benjamin Bentmann</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 25 Apr 2008 16:02:31 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 25 Feb 2010 19:47:32 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 22 Oct 2009 05:47:05 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12595891" author="bayard" created="Sun, 11 May 2008 06:29:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;SystemUtilsTest and StringEscapeUtils both fixed. Need to dig more into the StringUtils one to understand the nature of the change.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12595895" author="bentmann" created="Sun, 11 May 2008 08:11:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The proposed changes to &lt;tt&gt;StringUtils.containsIgnoreCase()&lt;/tt&gt; aim at establishing the following assertion:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;str1.equalsIgnoreCase(str2)    ==&amp;gt;  StringUtils.containsIgnoreCase(str1, str2)
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;or more completely&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;StringUtils.containsIgnoreCase(str1, str2) 
iff. there exists k &amp;gt;= 0 such that
str1.substring(k, k + str2.length()).equalsIgnoreCase(str2)
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12768577" author="bayard" created="Thu, 22 Oct 2009 05:47:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Apologies for the long delay in applying the rest of the patch. Looks good and it&apos;s gone in as:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Applying the final part of Benjamin Bentmann&apos;s patch to &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-432&quot; title=&quot;Fix case-insensitive string handling&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-432&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-432&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;, improving our handling of case-insens&lt;br/&gt;
itive Strings&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/StringUtils.java&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-429] NullPointerException (NPE) in FastDateFormat.getInstance(FastDateFormat.java:211)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-429</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Sometimes (sadly this is not reproducible) the following method call results in a NullPointerException (NPE):&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Stacktrace:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.lang.NullPointerException&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.commons.lang.time.FastDateFormat.getInstance(FastDateFormat.java:211)&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.commons.lang.time.DateFormatUtils.format(DateFormatUtils.java:258)&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.commons.lang.time.DateFormatUtils.format(DateFormatUtils.java:232)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t know how this is actually possible, since the exception is being raised when accessing a static field &apos;cInstanceCache&apos; that will be implicitly initialized...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Could this have something to do with class gc?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;MS Windows XP (SP 2), Java 1.5.0 Update 11&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12394699">LANG-429</key>
            <summary>NullPointerException (NPE) in FastDateFormat.getInstance(FastDateFormat.java:211)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="3">Duplicate</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="kburjack">Kai Burjack</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 24 Apr 2008 13:04:57 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 17 May 2008 05:24:02 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 17 May 2008 05:24:02 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.2</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12592053" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 24 Apr 2008 13:33:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think it&apos;s possible because the cInstanceCache field is not final - see &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-367&quot; title=&quot;FastDateFormat thread safety&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-367&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-367&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Updating to version 2.4 should fix the problem.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12592054" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 24 Apr 2008 13:35:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This issue appears to be the same&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12592062" author="julien.ayme@gmail.com" created="Thu, 24 Apr 2008 13:52:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;IMHO, this is rather an example of a data-race issue due to the cInstanceCache field not being final and not being synchronized in &amp;lt;clinit&amp;gt; in FastDateFormat in Lang 2.2.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I suppose that the following scenario could explain your problem:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;at least two Threads concurrently access to FastDateFormat.getInstance() method, while FastDateFormat is not being loaded by the current classloader:&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Thread A loads FastDateFormat.class, and creates cInstanceCache.&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Thread B enters the FastDateFormat.getInstance() method, BUT FastDateFormat.class is in a incoherent state (cInstanceCache is null) because of memory synchronization and/or compiler optimizations&lt;br/&gt;
     =&amp;gt; this causes the NullPointerException in Thread B&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Thread A enters in FastDateFormat.getInstance() method and everything is correct.&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;I suggest you to upgrade to Lang 2.4 in which the cInstanceCache field has been made final, and see if this problem still occurs.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Furthermore, the semantic of final keyword has been strengthen due to JSR-133 , which is part of Java 5.&lt;br/&gt;
I encourage you to read the following section: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cs.umd.edu/~pugh/java/memoryModel/jsr-133-faq.html#finalWrong&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.cs.umd.edu/~pugh/java/memoryModel/jsr-133-faq.html#finalWrong&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
and the Final Fields paragraph in JSR-133: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cs.umd.edu/~pugh/java/memoryModel/jsr133.pdf&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.cs.umd.edu/~pugh/java/memoryModel/jsr133.pdf&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12592064" author="julien.ayme@gmail.com" created="Thu, 24 Apr 2008 13:54:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Ugh, my comment came in late &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;, this issue is indeed the same as &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-37&quot; title=&quot;[lang] unit test for org.apache.commons.lang.text.StrBuilder&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-37&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-37&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12592319" author="kburjack" created="Fri, 25 Apr 2008 09:21:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for your VERY fast answers!&lt;br/&gt;
I will give it a try with 2.4&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12595887" author="bayard" created="Sun, 11 May 2008 06:06:16 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Did 2.4 fix things Kai?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12597709" author="bayard" created="Sat, 17 May 2008 05:24:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Closing with the assumption that this fixed things.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-428] StringUtils.isNumeric</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-428</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;StringUtils.isNumeric.&lt;br/&gt;
if we put empty string as parameter we got true.&lt;br/&gt;
StringUtils.isNumeric(&quot;&quot;) return true.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12394687">LANG-428</key>
            <summary>StringUtils.isNumeric</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="artemsakhnov">Artem Sakhnov</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 24 Apr 2008 10:28:10 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 1 Mar 2011 06:32:13 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 1 Mar 2011 06:32:13 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.3</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.0</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12592055" author="jwcarman" created="Thu, 24 Apr 2008 13:36:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The javadocs specifically state that &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;p&gt;An empty String (&quot;&quot;) will return true.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So, I think we should close this one.  This is desired behavior apparently.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12592059" author="artemsakhnov" created="Thu, 24 Apr 2008 13:49:08 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;but later in javadoc says&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Returns:&lt;br/&gt;
    true if only contains digits, and is non-null&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;so, you shure we can close it?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12592067" author="jwcarman" created="Thu, 24 Apr 2008 14:07:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Yes, the javadocs specifically mention the empty string case.  So, it is desired behavior (or at least was when the author wrote it).  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also, there could be code out there that depends on this behavior.  Changing it now would be a regression bug.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12592070" author="artemsakhnov" created="Thu, 24 Apr 2008 14:10:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;closing, but ill rewrite it for myself, because empty string is not numeric &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; cya&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12592072" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 24 Apr 2008 14:12:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Note that null is different from the empty string.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Most of the isType() methods in this class work the same way: after checking for null, they check to make sure there are no illegal characters in the String.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;An empty String has no characters, so cannot contain an illegal character.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you want to ensure that the String is non-empty, use StringUtils.isNotEmpty().&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12592078" author="artemsakhnov" created="Thu, 24 Apr 2008 14:22:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&amp;gt; If you want to ensure that the String is non-empty, use StringUtils.isNotEmpty().&lt;br/&gt;
thats ok&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;but i need to check GET parameter. and i dont want put it in 2 conditions, i just want call  StringUtils.isNumeric(myGetParameter) and get valid answer. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;so my 	opinion, StringUtils.isNumerric(&quot;&quot;) should return false. if it so, then we dont need additionall conditions for result 	approve&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12592079" author="jwcarman" created="Thu, 24 Apr 2008 14:23:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Maybe the method could be better named isNotNonNumeric()?  &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12592081" author="artemsakhnov" created="Thu, 24 Apr 2008 14:28:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;just put there 1 more condition for empty string )))) thats be nice.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12592086" author="skitching" created="Thu, 24 Apr 2008 14:47:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The existing behaviour is consistent with the other methods. &lt;br/&gt;
And as James notes, any change would break existing code.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So IMO, WONTFIX is the correct resolution. Sorry Artem but backwards compatibility and consistency are very important in widely-used libs like commons-lang.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I guess that a new method, isNumericValue(String) could be added to implement the requested behaviour. But I&apos;m not sure it is worth it.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12592091" author="artemsakhnov" created="Thu, 24 Apr 2008 14:52:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;ok&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12592120" author="mbenson" created="Thu, 24 Apr 2008 16:20:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Actually given that the behavior is documented I would argue that the truly correct resolution would have been INVALID.  But I don&apos;t feel strongly enough about it to reopen and re-resolve the issue.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12986333" author="sslavic" created="Tue, 25 Jan 2011 11:03:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;For anyone wandering around, you can use org.apache.commons.lang.math.NumberUtils.isDigits(String) or isNumber(String) instead (see &lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/lang/api-2.4/org/apache/commons/lang/math/NumberUtils.html#isDigits%28java.lang.String%29&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;javadoc&lt;/a&gt; )&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12991115" author="bayard" created="Sun, 6 Feb 2011 06:53:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Must admit I don&apos;t see why isNumeric, isAlphanumeric, isAlpha return true for &quot;&quot;. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12991119" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Sun, 6 Feb 2011 07:10:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Yeah, that does not make sense. I wonder if the intent of the author of that Javadoc comment was to just document behavior. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12996978" author="bayard" created="Sun, 20 Feb 2011 06:14:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Reopening to consider changing this functionality in 3.0. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12997145" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Sun, 20 Feb 2011 14:42:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;+1 to fix. The &quot;does not contain illegal chars&quot; semantic should be captured in a different method if at all IMO. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12997448" author="mbenson" created="Mon, 21 Feb 2011 15:37:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I was recently frustrated by the apparent nonsensicality of &lt;tt&gt;StringUtils.isNumeric(&quot;&quot;) == true&lt;/tt&gt; as well, and this despite my having added a comment to this issue those approximately 3 years ago.  &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/tongue.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;  +1 from me to change this behavior.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13000740" author="bayard" created="Tue, 1 Mar 2011 06:32:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Resolving &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-428&quot; title=&quot;StringUtils.isNumeric&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-428&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-428&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; - Changing StringUtils.isAlpha, isAlphanumeric and isNumeric to return false when passed an empty String. Documenting this in the changes report and in the upgrade article. Also fixing a Javadoc c+p error in isNumericSpace and isAlphanumericSpace. &quot;&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/StringUtils.java&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/site/changes/changes.xml&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/site/xdoc/article3_0.xml&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/test/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/StringUtilsIsTest.java&lt;br/&gt;
Transmitting file data ....&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-423] StringEscapeUtils.escapeJava() behavior changed; backslash escapes &apos;/&apos; characters</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-423</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;StringEscapeUtils.escapeJava(String str) escapes forward-slash (&quot;/&quot;) characters.  Prior to 2.4, this was not the case.  This is caused by the patch in &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-363&quot; title=&quot;StringEscapeUtils.escapeJavaScript() method did not escape &amp;#39;/&amp;#39; into &amp;#39;\/&amp;#39;, it will make IE render page uncorrectly&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-363&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-363&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;, which changed the behavior of StringEscapeUtils.escapeJavaScript(String str) to escape forward-slashes for compatibliity with IE.  The change was implemented in code common to both methods; StringEscapeUtils.escapeJavaStyleString() .&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This side-effect change to StringEscapeUtils.escapeJava() is a problem in my project.  I don&apos;t see any reason why it is necessary to escape forward-slashes in escapeJava(), so I suggest the behavior be changed so that escapeJavaScript() escapes forward-slashes, but escapeJava() does not.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12393761">LANG-423</key>
            <summary>StringEscapeUtils.escapeJava() behavior changed; backslash escapes &apos;/&apos; characters</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="3">Duplicate</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mhurne">Matt Hurne</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 11 Apr 2008 15:36:18 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 11 Apr 2008 18:04:14 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 11 Apr 2008 17:53:14 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.4</version>

                            <comment id="12588052" author="mhurne" created="Fri, 11 Apr 2008 17:45:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Attached is a patch that will revert the behavior of both variants of StringEscapeUtils.escapeJava() to NOT escape forward slashes.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12588056" author="mhurne" created="Fri, 11 Apr 2008 17:49:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hehe, looking at that diff, it appears someone already implemented a nearly identical fix in svn.  So I suppose my patch isn&apos;t really needed.  I&apos;m leaving the ticket open, however.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12588058" author="mhurne" created="Fri, 11 Apr 2008 17:53:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Closing. Don&apos;t know why I didn&apos;t see that in my search results before I created this ticket...&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-421] StringEscapeUtils.escapeJava(String) escapes &apos;/&apos; characters</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-421</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Commons Lang 2.4 StringEscapeUtils.escapeJava(String) now escapes &apos;/&apos; characters, which is not a valid &quot;escapable&quot; character in Java strings.  I haven&apos;t tried the other Java escape/unescape methods to see if they have a similar problem, or that only Java &quot;escapable&quot; characters are escaped by escapeJava(String).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This bug may have appeared as an unintended side-effect of the fix for &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-363&quot; title=&quot;StringEscapeUtils.escapeJavaScript() method did not escape &amp;#39;/&amp;#39; into &amp;#39;\/&amp;#39;, it will make IE render page uncorrectly&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-363&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-363&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also the javadoc for escapeJava is now a little off, in that &apos;/&apos; should now be included in the sentence describing the differences between Java and Javascript strings, with respect to escaping rules.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The following is a JUnit3 test demonstrating the bug.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import junit.framework.TestCase;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import org.apache.commons.lang.StringEscapeUtils;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public class StringEscapeUtilsTest extends TestCase {&lt;br/&gt;
    public void testEscapeJavaWithSlash() &lt;/p&gt;
{
        final String input = &quot;String with a slash (/) in it&quot;;
        
        final String expected = input;
        final String actual   = StringEscapeUtils.escapeJava( input );

        /**
         * In 2.4 StringEscapeUtils.escapeJava(String) escapes &apos;/&apos; characters,
         * which are not a valid character to escape in a Java string.  
         */
        assertEquals( expected, actual );
    }
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12392947">LANG-421</key>
            <summary>StringEscapeUtils.escapeJava(String) escapes &apos;/&apos; characters</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/blocker.svg">Blocker</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="ggregory">Gary D. Gregory</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="shanmann">Steve Hanmann</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 2 Apr 2008 15:42:39 +0000</created>

                            <comment id="12584648" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Wed, 2 Apr 2008 15:50:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The JLS reference is &lt;a href=&quot;http://java.sun.com/docs/books/jls/second_edition/html/lexical.doc.html#101083&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://java.sun.com/docs/books/jls/second_edition/html/lexical.doc.html#101083&lt;/a&gt; (3.10.5 String Literals)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12584655" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Wed, 2 Apr 2008 16:07:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed. Added unit test method based on attachment provided.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-419] WordUtils.abbreviate bug when lower is greater than str.length</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-419</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In WordUtils.abbreviate, upper is adjusted to the length of the string, then to lower.&lt;br/&gt;
But lower is never adjusted to the length of the string, so if lower is greater than str.lengt(), upper will be too...&lt;br/&gt;
Then, str.substring(0, upper) throw a StringIndexOutOfBoundsException&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The fix is to adjust lower to the length of the string&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12392362">LANG-419</key>
            <summary>WordUtils.abbreviate bug when lower is greater than str.length</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="v.behar">Vincent Behar</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 26 Mar 2008 17:05:47 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 25 Feb 2010 19:50:47 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 11 May 2008 05:18:15 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-418] Javadoc incorrect for StringUtils.endsWithIgnoreCase</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-418</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The javadoc for StringUtils.endsWithIgnoreCase() shows an example that appears incorrect.  It currently looks like the following:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    StringUtils.endsWithIgnoreCase(&quot;def&quot;, &quot;ABCDEF&quot;) = false&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I believe that should return true.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It also appears that the examples in the javadoc have the parameters backwards, as the signature shows the second parameter as the &quot;suffix&quot;, yet the suffix in the examples is the first parameter.  The following sample I think would be more correct:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    StringUtils.endsWithIgnoreCase(&quot;ABCDEF&quot;, &quot;def&quot;) = true&lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12392197">LANG-418</key>
            <summary>Javadoc incorrect for StringUtils.endsWithIgnoreCase</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-414] DateUtils.round() often fails</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-414</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The example below shows the failure of DateUtils.round(Date,int). With version 2.1 round() works fine.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;        Now                                 DateUtils                        calculated directly     
2008-02-22T11:09:06,680 Rounded:   2008-02-22T11:00:01,000         2008-02-22T11:09:07,000    ERROR
2008-02-22T11:09:06,680 Truncated: 2008-02-22T11:09:06,000         2008-02-22T11:09:06,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:07,040 Rounded:   2008-02-22T11:09:07,000         2008-02-22T11:09:07,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:07,040 Truncated: 2008-02-22T11:09:07,000         2008-02-22T11:09:07,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:07,399 Rounded:   2008-02-22T11:09:07,000         2008-02-22T11:09:07,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:07,399 Truncated: 2008-02-22T11:09:07,000         2008-02-22T11:09:07,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:07,743 Rounded:   2008-02-22T11:00:01,000         2008-02-22T11:09:08,000    ERROR
2008-02-22T11:09:07,743 Truncated: 2008-02-22T11:09:07,000         2008-02-22T11:09:07,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:08,102 Rounded:   2008-02-22T11:09:08,000         2008-02-22T11:09:08,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:08,102 Truncated: 2008-02-22T11:09:08,000         2008-02-22T11:09:08,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:08,446 Rounded:   2008-02-22T11:09:08,000         2008-02-22T11:09:08,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:08,446 Truncated: 2008-02-22T11:09:08,000         2008-02-22T11:09:08,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:08,805 Rounded:   2008-02-22T11:00:01,000         2008-02-22T11:09:09,000    ERROR
2008-02-22T11:09:08,805 Truncated: 2008-02-22T11:09:08,000         2008-02-22T11:09:08,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:09,149 Rounded:   2008-02-22T11:09:09,000         2008-02-22T11:09:09,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:09,149 Truncated: 2008-02-22T11:09:09,000         2008-02-22T11:09:09,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:09,508 Rounded:   2008-02-22T11:00:01,000         2008-02-22T11:09:10,000    ERROR
2008-02-22T11:09:09,508 Truncated: 2008-02-22T11:09:09,000         2008-02-22T11:09:09,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:09,852 Rounded:   2008-02-22T11:00:01,000         2008-02-22T11:09:10,000    ERROR
2008-02-22T11:09:09,852 Truncated: 2008-02-22T11:09:09,000         2008-02-22T11:09:09,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:10,211 Rounded:   2008-02-22T11:09:10,000         2008-02-22T11:09:10,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:10,211 Truncated: 2008-02-22T11:09:10,000         2008-02-22T11:09:10,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:10,555 Rounded:   2008-02-22T11:00:01,000         2008-02-22T11:09:11,000    ERROR
2008-02-22T11:09:10,555 Truncated: 2008-02-22T11:09:10,000         2008-02-22T11:09:10,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:10,915 Rounded:   2008-02-22T11:00:01,000         2008-02-22T11:09:11,000    ERROR
2008-02-22T11:09:10,915 Truncated: 2008-02-22T11:09:10,000         2008-02-22T11:09:10,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:11,258 Rounded:   2008-02-22T11:09:11,000         2008-02-22T11:09:11,000    ok
2008-02-22T11:09:11,258 Truncated: 2008-02-22T11:09:11,000         2008-02-22T11:09:11,000    ok

2008-02-22T11:09:11,618 Truncated: 2008-02-22T11:09:11,000         2008-02-22T11:09:11,000    ok

2008-02-22T11:09:12,665 Rounded:   2008-02-22T11:00:01,000         2008-02-22T11:09:13,000    ERROR
2008-02-22T11:09:12,665 Truncated: 2008-02-22T11:09:12,000         2008-02-22T11:09:12,000    ok
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-style: solid;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeHeader panelHeader&quot; style=&quot;border-bottom-width: 1px;border-bottom-style: solid;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Example Code&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;java.text.SimpleDateFormat dtFormat = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; java.text.SimpleDateFormat(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;yyyy-MM-dd&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;T&apos;&lt;/span&gt;HH:mm:ss,SSS&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);

&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;        Now            &quot;&lt;/span&gt;
    + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;            &quot;&lt;/span&gt;
    + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;   DateUtils  &quot;&lt;/span&gt;
    + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;         &quot;&lt;/span&gt;
    + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;       calculated directly &quot;&lt;/span&gt;
    + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;    &quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; errorCnt = 0;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;while&lt;/span&gt;(errorCnt &amp;lt; 10)
{
  java.util.Date now = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; java.util.Date();
  
  java.util.Date roundedByUtils = org.apache.commons.lang.time.DateUtils.round(now, java.util.Calendar.SECOND);
  java.util.Date truncatedByUtils = org.apache.commons.lang.time.DateUtils.truncate(now, java.util.Calendar.SECOND);
  
  &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;long&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;rest&lt;/span&gt; = now.getTime() % 1000;
  java.util.Date rounded;
  java.util.Date truncated = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; java.util.Date(now.getTime() - &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;rest&lt;/span&gt;);
  &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;rest&lt;/span&gt; &amp;lt; 500)
    rounded = truncated;
  &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;else&lt;/span&gt;
    rounded = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; java.util.Date(now.getTime() + (1000 - &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;rest&lt;/span&gt;));
  &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;boolean&lt;/span&gt; roundError = !roundedByUtils.equals(rounded);
  &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;boolean&lt;/span&gt; truncateError = !truncatedByUtils.equals(truncated);
  &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (roundError || truncateError)
    errorCnt++;

  &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(
      dtFormat.format(now)
      + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot; Rounded:   &quot;&lt;/span&gt;
      + dtFormat.format(roundedByUtils)
      + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;         &quot;&lt;/span&gt;
      + dtFormat.format(rounded)
      + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;    &quot;&lt;/span&gt;
      + (roundError ? &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;ERROR&quot;&lt;/span&gt; : &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;ok&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
  &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(
      dtFormat.format(now)
      + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot; Truncated: &quot;&lt;/span&gt;
      + dtFormat.format(truncatedByUtils)
      + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;         &quot;&lt;/span&gt;
      + dtFormat.format(truncated)
      + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;    &quot;&lt;/span&gt;
      + (truncateError ? &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;ERROR&quot;&lt;/span&gt; : &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;ok&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
  &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Thread&lt;/span&gt;.sleep(351);
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-412] StrBuilder appendFixedWidth does not handle nulls</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-412</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Appending a null value with fixed width causes a null pointer exception if getNullText() has not been set.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Java  1.5&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12388510">LANG-412</key>
            <summary>StrBuilder appendFixedWidth does not handle nulls</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="poxenham">Peter Oxenham</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 13 Feb 2008 04:23:25 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 2 May 2013 02:29:13 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 13 Feb 2008 05:45:03 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.3</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.4</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12568433" author="bayard" created="Wed, 13 Feb 2008 05:33:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Confirmed (visually). As appendNull&apos;s effect is to do nothing if it is set to null, my assumption is that having nullText be null is merely an optmization for the empty String.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So I think the solution will be to make the fixed width methods use an empty string if they get back a null nullText.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12568436" author="bayard" created="Wed, 13 Feb 2008 05:43:27 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Attaching tests and a fix (null -&amp;gt; &quot;&quot;).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12568438" author="bayard" created="Wed, 13 Feb 2008 05:45:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Applying my patch from &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-412&quot; title=&quot;StrBuilder appendFixedWidth does not handle nulls&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-412&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-412&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;; fixing Peter Oxenham&apos;s report that the appendFixedWidthPadRight and appendFixedWidthPadLeft are not null safe if the nullText has not been set&quot; src&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Sending        src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/text/StrBuilder.java&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/test/org/apache/commons/lang/text/StrBuilderTest.java&lt;br/&gt;
Transmitting file data ..&lt;br/&gt;
Committed revision 627248.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-410] Ambiguous / confusing names in StringUtils replace* methods</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-410</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The recently added replaceEach* methods use &quot;repl&quot; for the original string list, and &quot;with&quot; for the new (replacement) string list.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;These names are rather confusing.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;RE engines tend to use words such as:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Perl:&lt;br/&gt;
searchlist&lt;br/&gt;
replacementlist&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;ORO:&lt;br/&gt;
pattern&lt;br/&gt;
replacement&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Java has String.replace(regex, replacement)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In all cases, &quot;replacement&quot; is used for the NEW string, not the original string which is to be replaced.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Seems to me that searchString/List and replacement&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;List&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; would be unambiguous as well as descriptive.&lt;br/&gt;
Also useful in IDEs which show possible method completions.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Changing the names of the parameters would not affect the API.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Patch to follow&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12388001">LANG-410</key>
            <summary>Ambiguous / confusing names in StringUtils replace* methods</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-406] Add FractionFormat to oacl.text</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-406</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I&apos;d like to add a FractionFormat implementation, capable of formatting Numbers including oacl.math.Fraction to fractions, and of parsing fraction representation (and standalone integers) into oacl.math.Fraction instances.  Implementation and test forthcoming; opinions welcome.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12387713">LANG-406</key>
            <summary>Add FractionFormat to oacl.text</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="mbenson">Matthew Jason Benson</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mbenson">Matthew Jason Benson</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 2 Feb 2008 19:51:35 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 13 Feb 2008 07:04:51 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 4 Feb 2008 15:35:07 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.3</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12565111" author="mbenson" created="Sat, 2 Feb 2008 20:00:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch #3:  Fraction.toString() and Fraction.toProperString() should use FractionFormat, to keep all fraction formatting/parsing in one (IMO here=the right) place.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12565148" author="bayard" created="Sun, 3 Feb 2008 05:37:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Only opinion so far is that 2.4 is close enough to start asking whether we want to add new issues to 2.4. The last batch got added because this&apos;ll be an M2 release and we were blocked on the unreleased commons-parent pom. That&apos;s no longer blocking us now.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12565180" author="mbenson" created="Sun, 3 Feb 2008 15:13:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;As always, I&quot;m fine with whatever consensus says.  Though if this code is such that we don&apos;t have any contention over it, this issue could be resolved before the other two we&apos;ve got outstanding.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12565266" author="niallp" created="Mon, 4 Feb 2008 04:44:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m not sure why we have Fraction in both Lang and Math - I guess historically they just evolved separately. The duplication does seem like a waste of effort though and Math IMO is a better location - also Math already has a FractionFormat implementation. Perhaps would be a good idea to compare both Fraction implementations and ensure that one supports all features of the other and then deprecate one.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/commons/proper/math/trunk/src/java/org/apache/commons/math/fraction/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/commons/proper/math/trunk/src/java/org/apache/commons/math/fraction/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/math/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/math/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12565363" author="mbenson" created="Mon, 4 Feb 2008 14:20:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Ah... actually I began working on this before even realizing &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;math&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; had a Fraction (not being a consumer, never thought about it), much less a FractionFormat.  I only learned about the &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;math&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Fraction from your (Niall&apos;s) recent JIRA comments.  I will check out the &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;math&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; FractionFormat and make sure it&apos;s up to snuff.  &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;  If that all works out, then should we not also deprecate oacl.math.Fraction?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12565397" author="mbenson" created="Mon, 4 Feb 2008 15:35:07 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m okay to drop this.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-394] Equalsbuilder fails at using unmodifiable collection</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-394</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When using the equalsbuilder to build a equals-method it comes to failures, when comparing object which have unmodifiable list properties.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Look at the simplified example. A class Foo with a collection (A,B,C) is build up. The equals method uses the equalsbuilder to append the list to it. The getter of the list returns a unmodifiable collection. This situation leads to the test failure. Without capsulation in a unmodifiable collection the test succeeds. What&apos;s wrong? I want to compare such objects by value not by reference.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt; @Test&lt;br/&gt;
  public void testInEqualsBuilder() {&lt;br/&gt;
    class Foo {&lt;br/&gt;
      private final Collection&amp;lt;String&amp;gt; list;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;      public Foo() &lt;/p&gt;
{
        this.list = new ArrayList&amp;lt;String&amp;gt;();
        this.list.add(&quot;A&quot;);
        this.list.add(&quot;B&quot;);
        this.list.add(&quot;C&quot;);

      }

&lt;p&gt;      @Override&lt;br/&gt;
      public boolean equals(final Object object) {&lt;br/&gt;
        if (object == this) &lt;/p&gt;
{
          return true;
        }
&lt;p&gt;        if (!(object instanceof Foo)) &lt;/p&gt;
{
          return false;
        }
&lt;p&gt;        final Foo rhs = (Foo) object;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        final EqualsBuilder eb = new EqualsBuilder();&lt;br/&gt;
        eb.append(this.list, rhs.getList());&lt;br/&gt;
        return eb.isEquals();&lt;br/&gt;
      }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;      private Collection&amp;lt;String&amp;gt; getList() &lt;/p&gt;
{

         return Collections.unmodifiableCollection(this.list);
       }

&lt;p&gt;    }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    final Foo x = new Foo();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    assertTrue(x.equals&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/error.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    // FAILURE list &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;A,B,C&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; is not equal to list &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;A,B,C&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;, when using&lt;br/&gt;
    // unmodifiableCollection?&lt;br/&gt;
    assertTrue(x.equals(new Foo()));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  }&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Win XP SP2, JRE 1.5.0_12&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12385497">LANG-394</key>
            <summary>Equalsbuilder fails at using unmodifiable collection</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="6">Invalid</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bm">Benno Markiewicz</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 3 Jan 2008 14:42:25 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 5 Jan 2008 06:25:05 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 5 Jan 2008 06:25:05 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.3</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12555588" author="julien.ayme@gmail.com" created="Thu, 3 Jan 2008 15:15:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi, this is not an EqualsBuilder bug, but rather a misuse of the Collection interface:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The general contract for Collection#equals(Object) is the same as Object#equals(Object), ie a Collection is only equals to itself.&lt;br/&gt;
(see &lt;a href=&quot;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/Collection.html#equals(java.lang.Object&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/Collection.html#equals(java.lang.Object&lt;/a&gt;))&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Whereas the contract for List#equals(Object) is that a List is equals to any List of the same size which contains the same objects in the same order.&lt;br/&gt;
(see &lt;a href=&quot;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/List.html#equals(java.lang.Object&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/List.html#equals(java.lang.Object&lt;/a&gt;))&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;That&apos;s why your current test fails; instead of returning an unmodifiableCollection, try returning an unmodifiableList (which compares to other lists by value and not by reference).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Hope this help,&lt;br/&gt;
Julien&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12556182" author="bayard" created="Sat, 5 Jan 2008 06:25:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Many thanks for that explanation Julien, the javadoc definitely backs up what you&apos;re saying and so I&apos;m closing this issue.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-393] EqualsBuilder don&apos;t compare BigDecimals correctly </title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-393</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When comparing a BigDecimal, the comparing is made using equals, not compareTo, which is more appropriate in the case of BigDecimal.  &lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12385492">LANG-393</key>
            <summary>EqualsBuilder don&apos;t compare BigDecimals correctly </summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="luishenriques">Luis Henriques</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 3 Jan 2008 13:46:49 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 27 Apr 2015 20:23:14 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 13 Jan 2008 07:00:40 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.3</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.4</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12557196" author="bayard" created="Wed, 9 Jan 2008 09:28:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;From the BigDecimal javadoc:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &quot;Compares this BigDecimal with the specified Object for equality. Unlike compareTo, this method considers two BigDecimal objects equal only if they are equal in value and scale (thus 2.0 is not equal to 2.00 when compared by this method). &quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So I can definitely see that in BigDecimal&apos;s case, most users would want compareTo to be used.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12557197" author="bayard" created="Wed, 9 Jan 2008 09:28:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Need to create unit test/fix.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12557361" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Wed, 9 Jan 2008 18:06:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hm... is there a way to refactor our code so that the Equals and CompareTo be mixed and matched? At least, it sounds we need some kind of configurable map to tell us which class should use compareTo.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12557539" author="bayard" created="Thu, 10 Jan 2008 04:16:07 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Do we need it? &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is our first compareTo instance. Looks like we need an if instanceof BigDecimal inside the if(!lhsClass.isArray()) block of append(Object, Object).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12557564" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Thu, 10 Jan 2008 07:59:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Strictly XP-speaking, no. You are correct, we should start with the required case and refactor and generalize only if needed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12557914" author="bayard" created="Fri, 11 Jan 2008 06:15:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Suggested fix attached.  How does it look?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12558353" author="bayard" created="Sun, 13 Jan 2008 07:00:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Applying my patch from &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-393&quot; title=&quot;EqualsBuilder don&amp;#39;t compare BigDecimals correctly &quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-393&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-393&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;; EqualsBuilder uses compareTo for BigDecimal and not equals&quot; src&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Sending        src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/builder/EqualsBuilder.java&lt;br/&gt;

                            <comment id="12636021" author="dfuse" created="Wed, 1 Oct 2008 13:22:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The following simple test case shows that the applied patch throws a ClassCastException:&lt;br/&gt;
public static void main(String[] args) {&lt;br/&gt;
		class Test &lt;/p&gt;
{
			public Object o;
		}

&lt;p&gt;		BigDecimal d = new BigDecimal(1000);&lt;br/&gt;
		Long l = new Long(1000);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		Test t1 = new Test();&lt;br/&gt;
		Test t2 = new Test();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		t1.o = d;&lt;br/&gt;
		t2.o = l;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		System.out.println(EqualsBuilder.reflectionEquals(t1, t2));&lt;br/&gt;
	}&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12636187" author="scolebourne" created="Wed, 1 Oct 2008 21:41:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I hadn&apos;t spotted this one. While I understand the motivation, I do think that EqualsBuilder should use .equals(). There are people who will consider that to be the only valid equals comparison (all the state of the object being equal).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12636190" author="mbenson" created="Wed, 1 Oct 2008 21:48:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;@Stephen:  Might be late now; @Nicolas:  The compilation error only happens with Java 5, so yes, when &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;lang&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; moves to Java 5 it must be corrected.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12636289" author="dfuse" created="Thu, 2 Oct 2008 05:57:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;@Matt: You are right, I should have mentioned that (java5). But don&apos;t  you think it should be fixed now? It is not a compilation error but a runtime error, and it occurs for everyone using Java 5 in their project while using this library.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12645629" author="bayard" created="Fri, 7 Nov 2008 00:04:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Btw - this is fixed in trunk now. Separate issue is whether this change needs to be reverted or not.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12777867" author="bayard" created="Sat, 14 Nov 2009 10:11:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Note that due to inconsistency with HashCodeBuilder and hashCode in general, this fix has been reverted and will go back to its old behaviour of using equals() in Lang 3.0.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-388] org.apache.commons.lang.enum</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-388</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In src/test/org/apache/commons/lang/AllLangTestSuite.java, the package won&apos;t compile unless the line &quot;suite.addTest(org.apache.commons.lang.enum.EnumTestSuite.suite());&quot; is commented out.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Java 1.5, possibly earlier&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12385195">LANG-388</key>
            <summary>org.apache.commons.lang.enum</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/blocker.svg">Blocker</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

            <title>[LANG-385] http://commons.apache.org/lang/developerguide.html &quot;Building&quot; section is incorrect and incomplete</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-385</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/lang/developerguide.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/lang/developerguide.html&lt;/a&gt; - the Building section  says that the Ant target dist-build can be used to build the distribution.&lt;br/&gt;
However, there is no such target. Should presumably read &quot;ant dist&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The section mentions that Maven can be used to build the project but fails to provide any details.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
