<item>
            <title>[LANG-342] HashCodeBuilder.append(long) is incorrect</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-342</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I was looking at using HashCodeBuilder rather than always writing out the strategy by hand, and I noticed one potential mistake:&lt;br/&gt;
    /**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Append a hashCode for a long.&lt;br/&gt;
     *&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@param value  the long to add to the hashCode&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@return this&lt;br/&gt;
     */&lt;br/&gt;
    public HashCodeBuilder append(long value)
    {
        iTotal = iTotal * iConstant + ((int) (value ^ (value &amp;gt;&amp;gt; 32))); 
        return this;
    }&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;whereas Effective Java and Long.hashCode() use:&lt;br/&gt;
    /**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Returns a hash code for this &amp;lt;code&amp;gt;Long&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;. The result is&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;the exclusive OR of the two halves of the primitive&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;code&amp;gt;long&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt; value held by this &amp;lt;code&amp;gt;Long&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;object. That is, the hashcode is the value of the expression:&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;blockquote&amp;gt;&amp;lt;pre&amp;gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;(int)(this.longValue()^(this.longValue()&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;32))&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/blockquote&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
     *&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@return  a hash code value for this object.&lt;br/&gt;
     */&lt;br/&gt;
    public int hashCode() 
{
      return (int)(value ^ (value &amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt; 32));
    }&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;So the author accidentally used a signed right-shift rather than an unsigned.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Stephen Colebourne noted that while this is a bug, it is minor and could have backward compatability issues.  I would simply recommend that a non-JavaDoc comment be added noting this method doesn&apos;t follow &quot;Effective Java&quot; correctly.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12372191">LANG-342</key>
            <summary>HashCodeBuilder.append(long) is incorrect</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bmanes">Benjamin Manes</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 22 Jun 2007 07:42:50 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 20 Sep 2007 17:55:11 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 20 Sep 2007 17:55:12 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12510779" author="bayard" created="Fri, 6 Jul 2007 20:27:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Setting fix version to 2.3.1 so the javadoc can be added. Then it should be reversioned to 3.0 for consideration there.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12518586" author="bayard" created="Thu, 9 Aug 2007 00:29:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Non-javadoc note added to HashCodeBuilder.append.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12528909" author="jcsahnwaldt" created="Wed, 19 Sep 2007 21:29:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It doesn&apos;t matter if &amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt; or &amp;gt;&amp;gt; is used. We shift down the upper half of the long and XOR with the lower half. Of course, we also XOR the unshifted upper half with the shifted upper half (which consists of zeros or ones), but then we cast to int, which simply throws away the upper half. It doesn&apos;t matter at all if there were zeros or ones in the shifted upper half.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here&apos;s a little test. Looping through all longs takes too long, let&apos;s just use random numbers.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.util.Random rnd = new java.util.Random();&lt;br/&gt;
for (;&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
{&lt;br/&gt;
  long value = rnd.nextLong();&lt;br/&gt;
  int signed = (int)(value ^ (value &amp;gt;&amp;gt; 32));&lt;br/&gt;
  int unsigned = (int)(value ^ (value &amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt; 32));&lt;br/&gt;
  if (signed != unsigned) System.out.println(value+&quot; &quot;&lt;ins&gt;signed&lt;/ins&gt;&quot; &quot;+unsigned);&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12529170" author="scolebourne" created="Thu, 20 Sep 2007 17:55:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the analysis. I&apos;ll close the issue as &apos;Won&apos;t fix&apos;, as a comment has already been added to the sourcebase.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-339] StringEscapeUtils.escapeHtml() escapes multibyte characters like Chinese, Japanese, etc.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-339</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;StringEscapeUtils.escapeHtml() escapes multibyte characters like Chinese, Japanes, etc.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12371341">LANG-339</key>
            <summary>StringEscapeUtils.escapeHtml() escapes multibyte characters like Chinese, Japanese, etc.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-334] Enum is not thread-safe</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-334</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Enum uses no synchronization. Even if you assume that instances are only declared statically, the cEnumClasses map is global and can be written to when a thread triggers static initialization of B.class while some other thread is doing getEnumList(A.class). Unsynchronized access of a map undergoing mutation is not thread-safe.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This isn&apos;t theoretical. We&apos;re seeing ValuedEnum.getEnum(X.class, 0) return null after returning the correct value over 100,000 times, and then return the correct value again on the next invocation.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12369325">LANG-334</key>
            <summary>Enum is not thread-safe</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sclafani">Michael Sclafani</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 14 May 2007 22:30:59 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 5 Sep 2007 10:14:06 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 5 Sep 2007 10:14:06 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>2.4</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12499391" author="bayard" created="Sun, 27 May 2007 06:43:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fix for 2.3.1. First step, write a test.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12501959" author="bayard" created="Wed, 6 Jun 2007 15:24:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I made an attempt at a test, but it couldn&apos;t replicate the issue. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12502098" author="sclafani" created="Wed, 6 Jun 2007 20:56:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Well, the bug description refers to two enum classes, but your test only uses one enum class, so I&apos;m completely unsurprised you didn&apos;t replicate the problem.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The bug is caused by one thread calling getEnum(A.class, 0) while another thread is initializing B.class, and those two threads are excuting in such a way that the first thread is reading the cEnumClasses map while the second thread is modifying the same map by registering the mapping for B.class. If you use only one enum class, the bug won&apos;t be seen. If you use two enum classes, but statically reference them so that both classes are initialized before getEnum() is called, no bug. If you use two classes, or ten classes, or 10000 classes, but fail to overlap the threads reading the map and writing the map in just the right (or wrong) way, no bug.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Unit testing isn&apos;t a great approach for testing synchronization problems since it&apos;s impossible for the test to control the execution order, especially when the bug requires actual concurrency. This bug cropped up when we started using new multi-core hardware. I could write a unit test for you, but I wouldn&apos;t expect it to fail unless you had identical hardware and software.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12502107" author="bayard" created="Wed, 6 Jun 2007 21:14:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Sorry for missing the two class bit.  I&apos;m not looking for a unit test, just a way to replicate the issue so that a fix can be created. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Failing that, find time to sit and think hard &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12502119" author="sclafani" created="Wed, 6 Jun 2007 21:30:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think it will be sufficient to simply use Collections.synchronizedMap() to wrap the map instance that is assigned to cEnumClasses.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12502464" author="bayard" created="Thu, 7 Jun 2007 18:40:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I agree - but I really hate solving things without being able to show there was a problem and then confirming that the problem no longer appears. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Did this change fix the symptoms you were seeing in your system?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12502481" author="sclafani" created="Thu, 7 Jun 2007 19:14:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Sadly, it was much easier for us to use a common subclass that provided synchronization between the constructor and all the static accessors than it was get set up to build our own version of the package, then distribute and install it. So a different form a serialization did fix it.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I understand your discomfort in dealing with race conditions since I&apos;ve had to deal with solving them myself many, many times, but I don&apos;t know of any practical solution other than reasoning about the temporal logic of the code.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12516136" author="jason.madden@riskmetrics.com" created="Sat, 28 Jul 2007 04:13:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;We have also encountered the issue of thread safety in the Enum  &lt;br/&gt;
class. In our case, it shows up when running in a application server  &lt;br/&gt;
where there are many threads and other applications are loading  &lt;br/&gt;
classes at arbitrary times.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve attached the patch that we are using which seems to correct this  &lt;br/&gt;
issue for us. Rather than synchronize all access to the cEnumClasses  &lt;br/&gt;
map (which seems like it would be rather expensive and highly  &lt;br/&gt;
contended), we adopted a copy-on-write approach that only involves  &lt;br/&gt;
synchronization when new classes are loaded.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12518640" author="bayard" created="Thu, 9 Aug 2007 07:03:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It&apos;s great that you&apos;ve got a fix working in production Jason, the patch seems good to me.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Any thoughts Michael? I like the simplicity of using synchronizedMap, but the copy-on-write optimization seems attractive.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;And yeah... I&apos;ve given up trying to replicate this &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; I&apos;d need to be using something like cglib so I could generate new enum subclasses by the thousand and see if it hits the race condition that way.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12525051" author="bayard" created="Wed, 5 Sep 2007 10:14:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve applied Jason&apos;s patch to enums.Enum and enum.Enum. Many thanks to both of you for working on this issue.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-331] Fix for LANG-259 broke ValuedEnum.compareTo() on subclassed enumerations</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-331</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I have a ValuedEnum abstract subclass that I further subclass to attach useful implementation behaviors. The base class overrides getEnumClass(). The fix for &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-259&quot; title=&quot;ValuedEnum.compareTo(Object other) not typesafe - it easily could be...&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-259&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-259&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; broke compareTo() since it compares getClass(), not getEnumClass().&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12368854">LANG-331</key>
            <summary>Fix for LANG-259 broke ValuedEnum.compareTo() on subclassed enumerations</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sclafani">Michael Sclafani</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 8 May 2007 18:16:38 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 15 Oct 2013 02:32:59 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 20 Apr 2013 15:27:43 +0000</resolved>
                                                                    <component>lang.enums.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12499393" author="bayard" created="Sun, 27 May 2007 06:45:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Discuss what to do for this as a part of a 2.3.1.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12518644" author="bayard" created="Thu, 9 Aug 2007 07:20:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I wonder if the solution is simply to state the &apos;if different classloader&apos; better.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;ie) Rather than doing:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        if (other.getClass() != this.getClass()) {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Instead do:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        if (other.getClass().getClassLoader() != this.getClass().getClassLoader()) {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;That wouldn&apos;t help if your two separate grandchildren enums are in different classloaders and you still want them viewed equal, but I&apos;m not sure what would (without turning into lots of code).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;That allows RandomEnum.RED to equal MyEnum.RED, so you also need to check for inheritence:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Attaching patch.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12518647" author="bayard" created="Thu, 9 Aug 2007 07:32:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Not sure that last patch has the right idea or not. equals() would also have to change. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve also made a unit test for this. Attaching that now.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12537888" author="scolebourne" created="Fri, 26 Oct 2007 09:18:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The whole cross ClassLoader thing for enums was a Bad Idea &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/sad.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12539899" author="bayard" created="Sat, 3 Nov 2007 08:04:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Does &apos;Bad Idea&apos; imply any suggestions? &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12540681" author="pbenedict" created="Wed, 7 Nov 2007 06:38:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt; That allows RandomEnum.RED to equal MyEnum.RED, so you also need to check for inheritence: &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The JDK has the strict policy that enums cannot be inherited. That is to say, that you can&apos;t subclass one Enum with another Enum. In JDK 7, there is a possibility of an abstract Enum may exist, but that only defines methods and no enumerated constants.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12540770" author="pbenedict" created="Wed, 7 Nov 2007 15:37:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I do not believe that you should be able to inherit enum constants. Only the final concrete class should be able to have them. That seems to be the direction of the JDK, and I recommend the fix be comparable. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There&apos;s a whole discussion on this topic here:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=6570766&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=6570766&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12541949" author="bens" created="Mon, 12 Nov 2007 20:56:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It&apos;s just ugly in there... &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/sad.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I agree with Stephen that it was a Bad Idea; that aside, I don&apos;t see any easy way to address this. Henri&apos;s fix will take care of compareTo(), but it also breaks equals(). My first thought was to replace the enum classname Map with an ordinal assigned at creation time, but that&apos;ll break serialization for 2.2/2.3 users. Argh.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It&apos;s not ideal now, but I don&apos;t know how to fix this without breaking something else. Maybe we should push this back to 3.0 where we can have a more general discussion about the purpose of Enum.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12541974" author="bayard" created="Mon, 12 Nov 2007 22:55:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Moving back to 3.0 - though I suspect the &apos;solution&apos; will happen when we remove the enum packages.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13494860" author="tn" created="Sun, 11 Nov 2012 11:53:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;lang.enum package has been removed in the 3.0 release. Unless there are plans for a 2.7 release, we could close this one as Won&apos;t Fix.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13637286" author="tn" created="Sat, 20 Apr 2013 15:27:43 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Close this as Won&apos;t Fix after more than 5 years, as there are no plans for another 2.x release.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-328] LocaleUtils.toLocale() rejects strings with only language+variant</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-328</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;LocaleUtils.toLocale() throws an exception on strings containing a language and a variant but no country code. For example : fr__POSIX&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This string can be produced with the JDK by instanciating a Locale with an empty string for the country : new Locale(&quot;fr&quot;, &quot;&quot;, &quot;POSIX&quot;).toString(). According to the javadoc for the Locale class a variant is allowed with just a language code or just a country code.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Commons Configuration handles this case in its PropertyConverter.toLocale() method. I&apos;d like to replace our implementation by the one provided by LocaleUtils, but our tests fail due to this case.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12367331">LANG-328</key>
            <summary>LocaleUtils.toLocale() rejects strings with only language+variant</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="ebourg">Emmanuel Bourg</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 16 Apr 2007 23:11:44 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 8 Aug 2007 15:54:14 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 1 May 2007 23:50:11 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.3</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.4</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12492931" author="bayard" created="Tue, 1 May 2007 19:07:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fix asap issue; so marking for 2.3.1.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12492989" author="bayard" created="Tue, 1 May 2007 23:49:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Attaching a unit test/fix patch for this.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-320] LocaleUtilsTest fails with IBM JDK 1.5.0 because of false assuptions</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-320</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;LocaleUtilsTest.testLanguagesByCountry makes the assumption, that within the JDK there is only one language defined for GB: en. This is not true for the IBM JDK 1.5.0 that also knows about cy_GB i.e. Welsh.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12362465">LANG-320</key>
            <summary>LocaleUtilsTest fails with IBM JDK 1.5.0 because of false assuptions</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="joehni">Joerg Schaible</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 9 Feb 2007 21:13:45 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 17 Feb 2007 08:59:29 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 17 Feb 2007 08:59:29 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.2</version>
                                    <fixVersion>Known Issue</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12471837" author="rahul@apache.org" created="Fri, 9 Feb 2007 21:56:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Might want to consider guarding such tests where expected results are vendor-specific (potentially &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-318&quot; title=&quot;HashCodeBuilderTest and ToStringBuilderTest fail with IBM JDK 1.4.2&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-318&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-318&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; as well, though haven&apos;t looked at that closely) based on the vendor information. &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;lang&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; itself provides SystemUtils.JAVA_VENDOR etc. to make the information trivially accessible.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12471849" author="joehni" created="Fri, 9 Feb 2007 22:20:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This test in special has not to do much with the vendor. Sun might deliver the cy_GB local with every new patch and then the test will fails also. &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-318&quot; title=&quot;HashCodeBuilderTest and ToStringBuilderTest fail with IBM JDK 1.4.2&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-318&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-318&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; is different though.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12473190" author="bayard" created="Wed, 14 Feb 2007 20:48:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Should be fixed. We had the same problem with US_en when US_es turned up (or something like that). The solution then was to change the test to not use one with a dupe. Maybe we need a better test instead. Investigate for 3.0.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12473893" author="bayard" created="Sat, 17 Feb 2007 08:41:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve fixed this by changing both of the assertions to only assert that the results contain, rather than that the results equal. This should allow things to be less problematic when a JVM adds a language, and it seems a lot less likely that the JVM would remove a language.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Fixed in r508733.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-319] CharEncodingTest fails in IBM JDK 1.4.2</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-319</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The test CharEncodingTest.testNotSupported tests with invalid character encodings. According the JDK docu of String(byte[], String) the JDK should throw in this case an java.lang.UnsupportedCharacterEncoding exception, but the IBM JDK 1.4.2 throws java.nio.charset.IllegalCharsetNameException. This is not an issue with IBM JDK 1.5.0_3 anymore.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Gentoo Linux, IBM JDK 1.4.2_5&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12362464">LANG-319</key>
            <summary>CharEncodingTest fails in IBM JDK 1.4.2</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="joehni">Joerg Schaible</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="joehni">Joerg Schaible</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 9 Feb 2007 21:07:52 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 17 Feb 2007 09:01:57 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 17 Feb 2007 09:01:57 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.2</version>
                                    <fixVersion>Known Issue</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12471820" author="joehni" created="Fri, 9 Feb 2007 21:09:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is a JDK bug and we cannot catch the thrown exception, since it is only available in JDK 1.4+.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                                            <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">
                        <customfieldname>Attachment count</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>0.0</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>

            <title>[LANG-318] HashCodeBuilderTest and ToStringBuilderTest fail with IBM JDK 1.4.2</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-318</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The IBM JDK 1.4.2 reports the declared fields of a class in reverse declaration order. The tests are affected by this:&lt;/p&gt;

                            <comment id="12473899" author="bayard" created="Sat, 17 Feb 2007 09:01:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t see any reason to have the unit tests not run for this - makes them more honest and we don&apos;t need the IBM 1.4.2 JVM to develop with. <item>
            <title>[LANG-317] Enum Serialization - not backwards compatible</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-317</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In our distributed application we have to deal with different environments. The server runs in a JDK 1.5 environment while some clients runs with JDK 1.4. In this scenario we get an error when we try to transfer the result object via RMI. The error message is:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Exception:BusinessDelegatorComp.login() - connection error ocurred during loginCORBA MARSHAL 0x4942f89a No; nested exception is: &lt;br/&gt;
	org.omg.CORBA.MARSHAL: Unable to read value from underlying bridge : Mismatched serialization UIDs : Source (Rep. IDRMI:de.fraport.biaf.apm.user.UserRoleEnum:CBEF51ADA936FFFE:D100D6F29BD50386) = D100D6F29BD50386 whereas Target (Rep. ID RMI:de.fraport.biaf.apm.user.UserRoleEnum:CBEF51ADA936FFFE:D041682DA5693C42) = D041682DA5693C42  vmcid: IBM  minor code: 89A  completed: No&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The class causing this problem is derived from org.apache.commons.lang.enums.ValuedEnum. Aftre some recherches we found on &lt;a href=&quot;http://people.apache.org/~bayard/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://people.apache.org/~bayard/&lt;/a&gt; that there is a upcoming new release 2.3 of Commons-Lang. We saw that in this release a bug &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-286&quot; title=&quot;Serialization - not backwards compatible&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-286&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-286&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; has been fixed which seemed to be exactly our problem. We downloaded this version hopening that we can forget this problem. But unfortunately the problem still exists.&lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;JDK 1.5 -&amp;gt; JDK 1.4&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12362428">LANG-317</key>
            <summary>Enum Serialization - not backwards compatible</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="2" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/critical.svg">Critical</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="6">Invalid</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="ukkmfra">U. Klinkm&#252;ller</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 9 Feb 2007 13:03:54 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 14 Feb 2007 20:41:41 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 14 Feb 2007 20:41:41 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.2</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12471817" author="bayard" created="Fri, 9 Feb 2007 21:05:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I believe the solution you need here is that you&apos;ll need to define serialVersionUID in your de.fraport.biaf.apm.user.UserRoleEnum class. The one in the ValuedEnum is private.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12472217" author="ukkmfra" created="Mon, 12 Feb 2007 08:40:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Till now we didn&apos;t try this because if a JDK 1.5 client communicates with the server (1.5 &amp;lt;-&amp;gt; 1.5) the problem does not arise. It is not known to me that in serialisation JDK 1.5 has a different behavior than JDK 1.4.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12472222" author="joehni" created="Mon, 12 Feb 2007 08:58:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This has less to do with the JDK, but more with the compiler you&apos;re using. E.g. if you have compiled the class with Eclipse (it uses &lt;b&gt;always&lt;/b&gt; the internal compiler and not the selected JDK&apos;s one) it will have a different serialVersionUID generated that the same class from the Sun compiler from the identical JDK. The only way to get them compatible is to define an own serialVersionUID.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12473186" author="bayard" created="Wed, 14 Feb 2007 20:41:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Closing this issue - J&#246;rg&apos;s reply seems good to me. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please reopen if that didn&apos;t help.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>

                        <customfieldname>Rank (Obsolete)</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>74792</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310222" key="com.atlassian.jira.ext.charting:timeinstatus">
                        <customfieldname>Time in Status</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-315] StopWatch: suspend() acts as split(), if followed by stop()</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-315</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In my opinion, it is a bug that suspend() acts as split(), if followed by stop(); see below:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        StopWatch sw = new StopWatch();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        sw.start();&lt;br/&gt;
        Thread.sleep(1000);&lt;br/&gt;
        sw.suspend();&lt;br/&gt;
        // Time 1 (ok)&lt;br/&gt;
        System.out.println(sw.getTime());&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        Thread.sleep(2000);&lt;br/&gt;
        // Time 1 (again, ok)&lt;br/&gt;
        System.out.println(sw.getTime());&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        sw.resume();&lt;br/&gt;
        Thread.sleep(3000);&lt;br/&gt;
        sw.suspend();&lt;br/&gt;
        // Time 2 (ok)&lt;br/&gt;
        System.out.println(sw.getTime());&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        Thread.sleep(4000);&lt;br/&gt;
        // Time 2 (again, ok)&lt;br/&gt;
        System.out.println(sw.getTime());&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        Thread.sleep(5000);&lt;br/&gt;
        sw.stop();&lt;br/&gt;
        // Time 2 (should be, but is Time 3 =&amp;gt; NOT ok)&lt;br/&gt;
        System.out.println(sw.getTime());&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;suspend/resume is like a pause, where time counter doesn&apos;t continue. So a following stop()-call shouldn&apos;t increase the time counter, should it?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12362095">LANG-315</key>
            <summary>StopWatch: suspend() acts as split(), if followed by stop()</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-313] Wrong behavior of Entities.unescape</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-313</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hi,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    There&apos;s seems to be a bug at Entities.unescape. Try for example StringEscapeUtils.unescapeHtml(&quot;&amp;amp; &amp;amp;&quot;). It outputs &quot;&amp;amp; &amp;amp;&quot; instead of &quot;&amp;amp; &amp;amp;&quot;. The problem is at this piece of code:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;                if (entityValue == -1) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                    buf.append(&apos;&amp;amp;&apos;);
                    buf.append(entityName);
                    buf.append(&apos;;&apos;);
                }
&lt;p&gt; else &lt;/p&gt;
{
                    buf.append((char) (entityValue));
                }
&lt;p&gt;                i = semi;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;     The method always skips to the next &quot;;&quot;, even if it doesn&apos;t finds the entity value and then disregarding any entity that may be actually be referred inside.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Regards,&lt;br/&gt;
Thiago Souza&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12360576">LANG-313</key>
            <summary>Wrong behavior of Entities.unescape</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-304] NullPointerException in isAvailableLocale(Locale)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-304</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;FindBugs pointed out:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   UwF: Field not initialized in constructor: org.apache.commons.lang.LocaleUtils.cAvailableLocaleSet&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;cAvailableSet is used directly once in the source - and if availableLocaleSet() hasn&apos;t been called it will cause a NullPointerException.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12359315">LANG-304</key>
            <summary>NullPointerException in isAvailableLocale(Locale)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>

            <title>[LANG-303] FastDateFormat.mRules is not transient or serializable</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-303</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Reported by FindBugs.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Either we need to make the Rule interface Serializable, or make mRules transient and add deserializing code to kick off init().&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12359312">LANG-303</key>
            <summary>FastDateFormat.mRules is not transient or serializable</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

                            <comment id="12460908" author="bayard" created="Tue, 26 Dec 2006 18:31:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The latter seems to make the most sense - the Rule objects are a tokenized version of the mPattern String, and that is going to be happily serialized.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;(I&apos;ve no clue why java.text.Format is Serializable anyway)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12460928" author="bayard" created="Tue, 26 Dec 2006 22:08:27 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Applying test for #&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-303&quot; title=&quot;FastDateFormat.mRules is not transient or serializable&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-303&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-303&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;, and a fix. &quot; src/&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/time/FastDateFormat.java&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/test/org/apache/commons/lang/time/FastDateFormatTest.java&lt;br/&gt;
Transmitting file data ..&lt;br/&gt;
Committed revision 490387.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;mRules and mMaxLengthEstimate have been made transient as the init() method sets both of them up.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The deserialize method is:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;+    // Serializing&lt;br/&gt;
+    //-----------------------------------------------------------------------&lt;br/&gt;
+    private void readObject(ObjectInputStream in) throws IOException, ClassNotFoundException &lt;/p&gt;
{
+        in.defaultReadObject();
+        init();
+    }
</comment>
                            <comment id="12460929" author="bayard" created="Tue, 26 Dec 2006 22:10:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Improved #&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-303&quot; title=&quot;FastDateFormat.mRules is not transient or serializable&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-303&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-303&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; test to prove the formatting works on each side of the serializing&quot; src/&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-302] StrBuilder does not implement clone()</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-302</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;As reported by FindBugs.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Does StrBuilder need to be Cloneable?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12359311">LANG-302</key>
            <summary>StrBuilder does not implement clone()</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bayard">Henri Yandell</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 22 Dec 2006 19:47:10 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 10 Jan 2011 20:42:34 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 11 May 2008 05:58:13 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.2</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.6</fixVersion>
                    <fixVersion>3.0</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.text.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12460905" author="bayard" created="Tue, 26 Dec 2006 18:19:07 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Neither StringBuffer, StringBuilder or String itself is cloneable, so we&apos;re not doing this because it&apos;s needed. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12460912" author="bayard" created="Tue, 26 Dec 2006 18:57:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;As we don&apos;t have the public clone(), this is only of value to subclasses. The state of this class is currently in 4 attributes. Two are protected, two are private. Both of the private attributes have public get/set methods.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So no reason for subclasses to need a clone.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12460914" author="bayard" created="Tue, 26 Dec 2006 18:59:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;StrBuilder no longer implements Cloneable. #&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-302&quot; title=&quot;StrBuilder does not implement clone()&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-302&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-302&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&quot; src/java/&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/text/StrBuilder.java&lt;br/&gt;
Transmitting file data .&lt;br/&gt;
Committed revision 490355.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12461061" author="scolebourne" created="Wed, 27 Dec 2006 18:34:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I disagree with this. It was probably an error to be Clonable, but now its there its doing no harm. Removing it breaks binary compatability, and thats a big deal in &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;lang&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;. -1 to the change.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12461063" author="bayard" created="Wed, 27 Dec 2006 18:39:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Reopening due to Stephen&apos;s -1.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ll roll the commit back and move this fix to 3.0.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12461427" author="bayard" created="Fri, 29 Dec 2006 18:42:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Rolling back r490355 - StrBuilder implements Cloneable again&quot; src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/text/StrBuilder.java &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Sending        src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/text/StrBuilder.java&lt;br/&gt;
Transmitting file data .&lt;br/&gt;
Committed revision 491073.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12539901" author="bayard" created="Sat, 3 Nov 2007 08:09:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Moving up to 2.4 - we should look into writing a clone method. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12541254" author="pbenedict" created="Fri, 9 Nov 2007 08:26:43 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;If StringBuilder or StringBuffer implemented Cloneable, then I&apos;d say do it here too. But Henri already confirmed it does not, so do remove the interface since its implementation was never complete.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12541255" author="bayard" created="Fri, 9 Nov 2007 08:27:08 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Pondered again for 2.4; but we shouldn&apos;t fix clone(). The less people who are able to get it to work, the less people are affected when it&apos;s removed in 3.0. Moving back to 3.0.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12595885" author="bayard" created="Sun, 11 May 2008 05:58:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;We&apos;re on 3.0 now, so removing the interface implementation. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Removing the Cloneable interface from StrBuilder as per &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-302&quot; title=&quot;StrBuilder does not implement clone()&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-302&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-302&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Sending        src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/text/StrBuilder.java&lt;br/&gt;
Transmitting file data .&lt;br/&gt;
Committed revision 655251.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12595886" author="bayard" created="Sun, 11 May 2008 05:59:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Question - is this okay for 3.0, or does it need to be LangTwo?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12979438" author="niallp" created="Mon, 10 Jan 2011 00:16:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I know this is resolved for 3.0 - but Sebb raised this again concerning a 2.6 release (also &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-603&quot; title=&quot;Removes &amp;quot;implement Cloneable&amp;quot; from StrBuilder&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-603&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-603&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;):&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://markmail.org/message/qa42zi27j4svsuna&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://markmail.org/message/qa42zi27j4svsuna&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;I agree with Stephen that we can&apos;t remove Cloneable in the 2.x branch because of compatibility issues. IMO the best solution is to implement clone(). As it stands this implementation is breaking the contract of Cloneable and I think that is worse than any difference with StringBuilder or StringBuffer. Its also very trivial to implement.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Attaching a patch to implement clone&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12979457" author="niallp" created="Mon, 10 Jan 2011 02:27:43 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;v2 of patch attached&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-301] Unnecessary code in StrTokenizer</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-301</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In StrTokenizer, we have the following:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1086     public Object clone() {&lt;br/&gt;
1087         try &lt;/p&gt;
{
1088             return cloneReset();
1089         }
&lt;p&gt; catch (CloneNotSupportedException ex) &lt;/p&gt;
{
1090             return null;
1091         }
&lt;p&gt;1092     }&lt;br/&gt;
...&lt;br/&gt;
1101     Object cloneReset() throws CloneNotSupportedException {&lt;br/&gt;
1102         StrTokenizer cloned = (StrTokenizer) super.clone();&lt;br/&gt;
1103         if (cloned.chars != null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
1104             cloned.chars = (char[]) cloned.chars.clone();
1105         }
&lt;p&gt;1106         cloned.reset();&lt;br/&gt;
1107         return cloned;&lt;br/&gt;
1108     }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;FindBugs just reported it because the clone() method doesn&apos;t call super.clone(). While that&apos;s not a worry (because the method it calls does), I don&apos;t understand why we&apos;re not just doing:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public Object clone() {&lt;br/&gt;
         StrTokenizer cloned = (StrTokenizer) super.clone();&lt;br/&gt;
         if (cloned.chars != null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
             cloned.chars = (char[]) cloned.chars.clone();
         }
&lt;p&gt;         cloned.reset();&lt;br/&gt;
         return cloned;&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;and why we return null and not a runtime CloneNotSupportedException.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also, is there any value in StrTokenizer being Cloneable? Or is it just done for the sake of the getXxxInstance methods?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12359310">LANG-301</key>
            <summary>Unnecessary code in StrTokenizer</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="6">Invalid</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bayard">Henri Yandell</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 22 Dec 2006 19:42:43 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 6 Feb 2007 23:47:28 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 29 Dec 2006 18:00:21 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.2</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12460924" author="bayard" created="Tue, 26 Dec 2006 21:28:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Moving this back to 3.0. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There are three things to do here, if reasons for the current code don&apos;t show up:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) Refactor the cloneReset method away. It&apos;s possible that it&apos;s setup this way to be more useful for subclasses. &lt;br/&gt;
2) Switch from returning null to throwing CloneNotSupported.&lt;br/&gt;
3) Stop supporting clone() and Cloneable.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The latter 2 definitely need to wait for 3.0, the former is not very critical.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12461419" author="scolebourne" created="Fri, 29 Dec 2006 18:00:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The cloneReset() method exists to enable testing.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The return null should never happen, as super.clone() should succeed. Its really just a way around the JDK flaw of the exception not being a runtime exception.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                                            <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">
                        <customfieldname>Attachment count</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>0.0</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>

                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>Fri, 29 Dec 2006 18:00:21 +0000</customfieldvalue>

                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12314020" key="com.atlassian.jira.plugins.jira-development-integration-plugin:devsummary">
                        <customfieldname>Development</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                        <customfield id="customfield_12313422" key="com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin:jobcheckbox">
                        <customfieldname>Enable Automatic Patch Review</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue><![CDATA[false]]></customfieldvalue>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-300] NumberUtils.createNumber throws NumberFormatException for one digit long</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-300</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;NumberUtils.createNumber throws a NumberFormatException when parsing &quot;1l&quot;, &quot;2l&quot; .. etc...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It works fine if you try to parse &quot;01l&quot; or &quot;02l&quot;.  The condition isDigits(numeric.substring(1)), line 455 return false as numeric.substring(1) is an empty string for &quot;1l&quot;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12359052">LANG-300</key>
            <summary>NumberUtils.createNumber throws NumberFormatException for one digit long</summary>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-299] Bug in method appendFixedWidthPadRight of class StrBuilder causes an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-299</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;There&apos;s a bug in method appendFixedWidthPadRight of class StrBuilder:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public StrBuilder appendFixedWidthPadRight(Object obj, int width, char padChar) {&lt;br/&gt;
        if (width &amp;gt; 0) {&lt;br/&gt;
            ensureCapacity(size + width);&lt;br/&gt;
            String str = (obj == null ? getNullText() : obj.toString());&lt;br/&gt;
            int strLen = str.length();&lt;br/&gt;
            if (strLen &amp;gt;= width) &lt;/p&gt;
{
 ==&amp;gt;            str.getChars(0, strLen, buffer, size);   &amp;lt;==== BUG: it should be str.getChars(0, width, buffer, size);
            }
&lt;p&gt; else {&lt;br/&gt;
                int padLen = width - strLen;&lt;br/&gt;
                str.getChars(0, strLen, buffer, size);&lt;br/&gt;
                for (int i = 0; i &amp;lt; padLen; i++) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                    buffer[size + strLen + i] = padChar;
                }
&lt;p&gt;            }&lt;br/&gt;
            size += width;&lt;br/&gt;
        }&lt;br/&gt;
        return this;&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is causing an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException, so this method is unusable when strLen &amp;gt; width.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It&apos;s counterpart method appendFixedWidthPadLeft seems to be ok.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12358279">LANG-299</key>
            <summary>Bug in method appendFixedWidthPadRight of class StrBuilder causes an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-295] StrBuilder contains usages of thisBuf.length when they should use size</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-295</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;While fixing &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-294&quot; title=&quot;StrBuilder.replaceAll and StrBuilder.deleteAll can throw ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-294&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-294&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; I noticed that there are two other places in StrBuilder that reference thisBuf.length and unless I&apos;m mistaken they shouldn&apos;t.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12354403">LANG-295</key>
            <summary>StrBuilder contains usages of thisBuf.length when they should use size</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-294] StrBuilder.replaceAll and StrBuilder.deleteAll can throw ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-294</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;StrBuilder.replaceAll and StrBuilder.deleteAll can thrown ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException&apos;s. Here are a couple of additions to the StrBuilderTest class that demonstrate this problem:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;StrBuilder.deleteAll() - added to testDeleteAll_String():&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        sb = new StrBuilder(&quot;\n%BLAH%\nDo more stuff\neven more stuff\n%BLAH%\n&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
        sb.deleteAll(&quot;\n%BLAH%&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
        assertEquals(&quot;\nDo more stuff\neven more stuff\n&quot;, sb.toString());&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;this causes the following error:&lt;br/&gt;
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.lang.System.arraycopy(Native Method)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang.text.StrBuilder.deleteImpl(StrBuilder.java:1114)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang.text.StrBuilder.deleteAll(StrBuilder.java:1188)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang.text.StrBuilderTest.testDeleteAll_String(StrBuilderTest.java:606)&lt;br/&gt;
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)&lt;br/&gt;
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)&lt;br/&gt;
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:585)&lt;br/&gt;
	at junit.framework.TestCase.runTest(TestCase.java:154)&lt;br/&gt;
	at junit.framework.TestCase.runBare(TestCase.java:127)&lt;br/&gt;
	at junit.framework.TestResult$1.protect(TestResult.java:106)&lt;br/&gt;
	at junit.framework.TestResult.runProtected(TestResult.java:124)&lt;br/&gt;
	at junit.framework.TestResult.run(TestResult.java:109)&lt;br/&gt;
	at junit.framework.TestCase.run(TestCase.java:118)&lt;br/&gt;
	at junit.framework.TestSuite.runTest(TestSuite.java:208)&lt;br/&gt;
	at junit.framework.TestSuite.run(TestSuite.java:203)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.junit3.JUnit3TestReference.run(JUnit3TestReference.java:128)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.TestExecution.run(TestExecution.java:38)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.runTests(RemoteTestRunner.java:460)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.runTests(RemoteTestRunner.java:673)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.run(RemoteTestRunner.java:386)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.main(RemoteTestRunner.java:196)&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;StrBuilder.replaceAll() - added to testReplaceAll_String_String():&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        sb = new StrBuilder(&quot;\n%BLAH%\nDo more stuff\neven more stuff\n%BLAH%\n&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
        sb.replaceAll(&quot;\n%BLAH%&quot;, &quot;&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
        assertEquals(&quot;\nDo more stuff\neven more stuff\n&quot;, sb.toString());&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;this causes the exception:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.lang.System.arraycopy(Native Method)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang.text.StrBuilder.replaceImpl(StrBuilder.java:1256)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang.text.StrBuilder.replaceAll(StrBuilder.java:1339)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.lang.text.StrBuilderTest.testReplaceAll_String_String(StrBuilderTest.java:763)&lt;br/&gt;
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)&lt;br/&gt;
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)&lt;br/&gt;
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:585)&lt;br/&gt;
	at junit.framework.TestCase.runTest(TestCase.java:154)&lt;br/&gt;
	at junit.framework.TestCase.runBare(TestCase.java:127)&lt;br/&gt;
	at junit.framework.TestResult$1.protect(TestResult.java:106)&lt;br/&gt;
	at junit.framework.TestResult.runProtected(TestResult.java:124)&lt;br/&gt;
	at junit.framework.TestResult.run(TestResult.java:109)&lt;br/&gt;

	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.junit3.JUnit3TestReference.run(JUnit3TestReference.java:128)&lt;br/&gt;

                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Java 1.5.0_09, win XP Pro.&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12354353">LANG-294</key>
            <summary>StrBuilder.replaceAll and StrBuilder.deleteAll can throw ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="andylehane">Andy Lehane</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 31 Oct 2006 11:07:08 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 6 Feb 2007 23:47:27 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 31 Oct 2006 22:15:27 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.2</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.3</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12445986" author="bayard" created="Tue, 31 Oct 2006 18:20:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Confirmed. Adding to 3.0 (though that may mostly end up being 2.3).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12446081" author="bayard" created="Tue, 31 Oct 2006 22:08:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The bug is actually in indexOf. Here&apos;s a test for it:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public void testIndexOfLang294() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    	StrBuilder sb = new StrBuilder(&quot;onetwothree&quot;);
    	sb.deleteFirst(&quot;three&quot;);
    	assertEquals(-1, sb.indexOf(&quot;three&quot;));  // fails as the indexOf is 6
    }

&lt;p&gt;The problem being that IndexOf does not look at whether it has gone over the actual size of the String being built and into the flotsam that is floating at the end of the buffer array beyond the length of the size variable.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12446085" author="bayard" created="Tue, 31 Oct 2006 22:14:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Unit test and fix for this bug. The indexOf method needed to understand that the buffer did not represent the entire underlying String but had more junk data at the end for performance reasons.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12446087" author="bayard" created="Tue, 31 Oct 2006 22:15:27 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Fixing #&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-294&quot; title=&quot;StrBuilder.replaceAll and StrBuilder.deleteAll can throw ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-294&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-294&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;. The indexOf method did not take into account the size variable that limited the amount of the buffer that should be looked at. &quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Sending        src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/text/StrBuilder.java&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/test/org/apache/commons/lang/text/StrBuilderTest.java&lt;br/&gt;
Transmitting file data ..&lt;br/&gt;
Committed revision 469677.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-292] unescapeXml(&quot;&amp;12345678;&quot;) should be &quot;&amp;12345678;&quot;</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-292</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Following test (in EntitiesTest.java) fails:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public void testNumberOverflow() throws Exception &lt;/p&gt;
{
        doTestUnescapeEntity(&quot;&amp;amp;#12345678;&quot;, &quot;&amp;amp;#12345678;&quot;);
        doTestUnescapeEntity(&quot;x&amp;amp;#12345678;y&quot;, &quot;x&amp;amp;#12345678;y&quot;);
        doTestUnescapeEntity(&quot;&amp;amp;#x12345678;&quot;, &quot;&amp;amp;#x12345678;&quot;);
        doTestUnescapeEntity(&quot;x&amp;amp;#x12345678;y&quot;, &quot;x&amp;amp;#x12345678;y&quot;);
    }

&lt;p&gt;Maximim value for char is 0xFFFF, so &amp;amp;#12345678; is invalid entity reference, and so should be left as is.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12354333">LANG-292</key>
            <summary>unescapeXml(&quot;&amp;12345678;&quot;) should be &quot;&amp;12345678;&quot;</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
