<item>
            <title>[LANG-286] Serialization - not backwards compatible</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-286</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Release report states that commons-lang 2.2 is binary backwards compatible, this does not seem to be correct between commons-lang 2.1 and 2.2&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Running 2.2 at the server and 2.1 on client will result in an exception:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;org.omg.CORBA.MARSHAL: Unable to read value from underlying bridge : Mismatched serialization UIDs : Source (Rep. IDRMI:org.apache.commons.lang.exception.NestableDelegate:4F998DA78EFC2530:F68F1455DDEE96BB) = F68F1455DDEE96BB whereas Target (Rep. ID RMI:org.apache.commons.lang.exception.NestableDelegate:4F998DA78EFC2530:0000000000000001) = 0000000000000001  minor code: 4942F89A  completed: No&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;N/A&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12353405">LANG-286</key>
            <summary>Serialization - not backwards compatible</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="david@davidkarlsen.com">David J. M. Karlsen</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 17 Oct 2006 13:45:04 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 30 Jan 2007 23:21:50 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 30 Jan 2007 23:21:50 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.2</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.2</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12443619" author="bayard" created="Thu, 19 Oct 2006 19:18:58 +0000"  >
&lt;p&gt;The error is in my use of the phrase &apos;binary backwards compatible&apos; - I meant that the API has not changed so you should be able to drop it in place without a recompile. Not that you could serialize objects between 2.1 and 2.2.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;We have applied serialVersionIDs in 2.2; so between 2.2 and 2.3 serialization should work. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12444478" author="bayard" created="Tue, 24 Oct 2006 19:59:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Keeping this open to remind me to check this when 2.3 is released (though it may not be released and instead go straight to 3.0).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve requested that jardiff support diffs on serialVersionId for Serializable classes.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12461422" author="scolebourne" created="Fri, 29 Dec 2006 18:17:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Changed issue title&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12467834" author="david@davidkarlsen.com" created="Fri, 26 Jan 2007 14:45:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Any news on this?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m extending NestableRuntimeException and NestableException - and expiriencing serialization errors between a WebSphere 5.0.2 server and a WebSphere 6.1 server - probably due to changed serializationUIDs on some of the classes that are used within NestableDelegate:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;org.omg.CORBA.MARSHAL: Unable to read value from underlying bridge : Mismatched serialization UIDs : Source (RepId RMI:org.apache.commons.lang.exception.NestableDelegate:4F998DA78EFC2530:EAEF728564560A6A) = EAEF728564560A6A whereas Target (RepId RMI:org.apache.commons.lang.exception.NestableDelegate:4F998DA78EFC2530:F68F1455DDEE96BB) = F68F1455DDEE96BB  vmcid: IBM  minor code: 89A  completed: No&lt;br/&gt;
        at com.ibm.rmi.iiop.CDRInputStream.read_value(CDRInputStream.java:2105)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;explicitly setting an serializationUID on NestableDelegate would probably solve the case.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Using commons-lang 2.1 in both JVM/servers.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12467846" author="bayard" created="Fri, 26 Jan 2007 15:57:08 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The following had serialVersionUID set for the 2.2 release. There have been no new ones added for 2.3. So when 2.3 is released, you shouldn&apos;t get the problems you&apos;ve had from 2.1 to 2.2 for these files.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;./src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/builder/StandardToStringStyle.java&lt;br/&gt;
./src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/builder/ToStringStyle.java&lt;br/&gt;
./src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/CharRange.java&lt;br/&gt;
./src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/CharSet.java&lt;br/&gt;
./src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/enum/Enum.java&lt;br/&gt;

./src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/SerializationException.java&lt;br/&gt;
./src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/text/CompositeFormat.java&lt;br/&gt;
./src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/text/StrBuilder.java&lt;br/&gt;
./src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/time/FastDateFormat.java&lt;br/&gt;
./src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/UnhandledException.java&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12468821" author="bayard" created="Tue, 30 Jan 2007 23:21:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This was effectively fixed in 2.2 (no new serialUIDs in 2.3)- however it&apos;s not until you go from 2.2 to a new version that you notice.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-281] DurationFormatUtils returns wrong result</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-281</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;DurationFormatUtils returns wrong result.  oddly, it is only when Date is set to Dec 31, 2005&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The following code will result in a String of -2 which is way off.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve tested against 2.1 and 2.2.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        Calendar cal = Calendar.getInstance();&lt;br/&gt;
        cal.set(Calendar.MONTH, Calendar.DECEMBER);&lt;br/&gt;
        cal.set(Calendar.DAY_OF_MONTH, 31);&lt;br/&gt;
        cal.set(Calendar.YEAR, 2005);&lt;br/&gt;
        cal.set(Calendar.HOUR_OF_DAY, 0);&lt;br/&gt;
        cal.set(Calendar.MINUTE, 0);&lt;br/&gt;
        cal.set(Calendar.SECOND, 0);&lt;br/&gt;
        cal.set(Calendar.MILLISECOND, 0);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        String result = DurationFormatUtils.formatPeriod(cal.getTimeInMillis(), System.currentTimeMillis(), &quot;MM&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
        System.out.println(result);&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Win xp pro&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12352519">LANG-281</key>
            <summary>DurationFormatUtils returns wrong result</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="stlum9495">stlum9495</reporter>

                    </labels>

                            <comment id="12440269" author="bayard" created="Thu, 5 Oct 2006 21:35:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Setting for a 2.3 fix version (ie the version being worked on now). I&apos;m starting to hate this class, yet another edge case.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks for finding it though &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12440620" author="bayard" created="Fri, 6 Oct 2006 23:06:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Attached unit test.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12440623" author="bayard" created="Fri, 6 Oct 2006 23:26:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Unit test attached.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12440627" author="bayard" created="Sat, 7 Oct 2006 00:20:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Attaching a fix. It&apos;s not a very good sign that I&apos;m fixing this by deleting a block of code and discovering that no unit tests are suddenly failling. So I need to add more unit tests, and rethink things.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The block of code removed was meant to fix an overshooting when blindly adding 31 days instead of a known month number and I&apos;ve also changed that to add the number of days in the previous month (with a big TODO to review it).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;First step, make some unit tests to identify this case as apparantly I&apos;ve not got them currently.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12440628" author="bayard" created="Sat, 7 Oct 2006 00:23:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Adding a unit test for #&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-281&quot; title=&quot;DurationFormatUtils returns wrong result&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-281&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-281&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; and a fix. The fix involves removing the reduceAndCorrect method. It appears that this method was doing sod all - which is worrying as it used to be important. I&apos;m guessing that it was a bad fix for a bug that was then subsequently fixed with other code. I&apos;ll create a JIRA issue to create more tests to test out the +31 block of code. &quot; &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Sending        src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/time/DurationFormatUtils.java&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-278] javadoc for StringUtils.removeEnd is incorrect</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-278</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The javadoc for StringUtils.removeEnd(String, String) lists a number of examples, one of which is wrong:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;StringUtils.removeEnd(&quot;www.domain.com&quot;, &quot;.com.&quot;)  = &quot;www,domain&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The actual result of this is just &quot;www.domain.com&quot;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12349705">LANG-278</key>
            <summary>javadoc for StringUtils.removeEnd is incorrect</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/trivial.svg">Trivial</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="skaffman">Kenny MacLeod</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 12 Sep 2006 12:09:36 +0000</created>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-277] Javadoc errors on StringUtils.splitPreserveAllTokens(String, char)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-277</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In the Javadoc for StringUtils.splitPreserveAllTokens(String, char) there are a couple of mistakes.  I didn&apos;t check for similar mistakes in the similar functions with different signatures.&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;StringUtils.splitPreserveAllTokens(&quot;a..b.c&quot;, &apos;.&apos;)   = &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot;a&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;b&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;c&amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;should read&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;StringUtils.splitPreserveAllTokens(&quot;a..b.c&quot;, &apos;.&apos;)   = &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot;a&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;b&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;c&amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;These two lines have the same input giving different outputs.  I think that the input string on the second call should be &quot;a b c  &quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;StringUtils.splitPreserveAllTokens(&quot;a b c &quot;, &apos; &apos;)   = &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot;a&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;b&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;c&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;&amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
StringUtils.splitPreserveAllTokens(&quot;a b c &quot;, &apos; &apos;)   = &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot;a&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;b&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;c&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;&amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12348902">LANG-277</key>
            <summary>Javadoc errors on StringUtils.splitPreserveAllTokens(String, char)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-272] Minor build and checkstyle changes</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-272</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Attaching a patch for minor changes to the build:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) Change project.properties so that the source distro unpacks to a different directory&lt;br/&gt;
2) Include checkstyle.properties and all the RELEASE-NOTES files in the source distro&lt;br/&gt;
3) Remove the exclusion of the &quot;text&quot; package from the source distro&lt;br/&gt;
4) Include the NOTICE.txt in the maven generated binary distro (and jar)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Althought the ant build is used to create the binary distro in the release process - I still think the maven generated binary distro should include the NOTICE.txt&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also attaching a patch to clean up the few minor checkstyle issues.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12345656">LANG-272</key>
            <summary>Minor build and checkstyle changes</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="niallp">Niall Pemberton</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 10 Jul 2006 09:43:21 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 16 Oct 2013 08:54:56 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 16 Jul 2006 01:13:18 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>2.2</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12419954" author="bayard" created="Mon, 10 Jul 2006 12:25:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;1, 2 and 4 look good. As do the checkstyle changes. Feel free to commit if you want, otherwise I&apos;ll hit them at some point.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;3 is changing a target called &apos;dist-build-2.1&apos;. Either we shoud leave it as it is, or remove the target itself.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12420045" author="niallp" created="Mon, 10 Jul 2006 19:01:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve committed the JavaDoc/Checkstyle changes and 1, 2 and 4.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Wrt to 3 (&quot;Remove the exclusion of the &quot;text&quot; package from the source distro&quot;) - looks like the target &apos;dist-build-2.1&apos; should be removed. If we don&apos;t remove the exclusion in maven.xml and the &quot;dist-build&quot; target is used to build lang 2.2 then it will mean that the binary distro includes classes which are missing from the source distro.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=rev&amp;amp;revision=209004&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=rev&amp;amp;revision=209004&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Anyway I&apos;ll leave it up to you as I&apos;m not a lang dev - just trying to be pro-active and get my nitpicks in before a RC was done, rather than after &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12420181" author="scolebourne" created="Tue, 11 Jul 2006 05:37:22 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m not sure why we have the old release notes files hanging around. IMHO they should be deleted from svn not included in the release.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;On the text package issue, we should be including it in the release, both bin and src&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12420221" author="niallp" created="Tue, 11 Jul 2006 12:40:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Old release notes can be useful if you&apos;re thinking of upgrading or need to upgrade because of a bug - anyway I&apos;ll leave it up to you lang devs to decide.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve removed the remaining bits that were put in to exclude the &quot;org.apache.commons.lang.text&quot; package from version 2.1&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12421367" author="bayard" created="Sun, 16 Jul 2006 01:13:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Release notes removed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

                            <comment id="12422552" author="bayard" created="Fri, 21 Jul 2006 05:28:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In Java 1.6, the US languages go from &quot;en_US&quot; to &quot;en_US, es_US&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is a problem once we need to compile on 1.6, but it doesn&apos;t cause a problem I think for the usage of a Lang 2.2 jar under the 1.6 JVM.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So punting this to 2.3.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-265</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Invoking ant test results in error message:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;===&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; /Users/yozh/devel/left/commons-lang/src/test/org/apache/commons/lang/builder/EqualsBuilderTest.java:969: reference to reflectionEquals is ambiguous, both method reflectionEquals(java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object,java.util.Collection) in org.apache.commons.lang.builder.EqualsBuilder and method reflectionEquals(java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object,java.lang.String[]) in org.apache.commons.lang.builder.EqualsBuilder match&lt;br/&gt;

    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;         assertEquals((((17 * 37 + 1) * 37 + 2) * 37 + 3), HashCodeBuilder.reflectionHashCode(x, null));&lt;br/&gt;

            <title>[LANG-264] ToStringBuilder/HashCodeBuilder javadoc code examples</title>

                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-262] Use of enum prevents a classloader from being garbage collected resuling in out of memory exceptions.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-262</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When an enum is created it is placed in the static hashmap - cEnumClasses.  If the enum is created from a classloader which has a limited lifetime then due to the strong reference the classloader is never garbage collected resulting in a memory leak.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I believe that making the cEnumClasses a WeakHashMap should resolve the problem.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12343931">LANG-262</key>
            <summary>Use of enum prevents a classloader from being garbage collected resuling in out of memory exceptions.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="2" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/critical.svg">Critical</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="neilredway">Neil Redway</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 5 Jun 2006 15:40:06 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 6 Feb 2007 23:47:24 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 7 Dec 2006 21:43:23 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>2.3</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12415299" author="bayard" created="Thu, 8 Jun 2006 15:42:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In an effort to get 2.2 out sooner rather than later, I&apos;m assiging all the Enum issues to 2.3. There&apos;s been no work on them currently and might be best to focus on them in a 2.3 release instead of trying to squeeze them into the 2.2 release.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Hopefully this will keep the 2.3 release scope pretty tight.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12436009" author="bayard" created="Tue, 19 Sep 2006 21:17:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Applying requested fix from Neil Redway in #&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-262&quot; title=&quot;Use of enum prevents a classloader from being garbage collected resuling in out of memory exceptions.&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-262&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-262&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&quot; src/java/&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/enum/Enum.java&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/enums/Enum.java&lt;br/&gt;
Transmitting file data ..&lt;br/&gt;
Committed revision 447975.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12436013" author="bayard" created="Tue, 19 Sep 2006 21:22:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks Neil, I&apos;ve applied that to the trunk (which is now for 2.3). It sounds like a completely plausible fix to me, though Stephen suggested on the mailing list that :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;I don&apos;t know whether a WeakHashMap works when the keys are Class objects&lt;br/&gt;
(as Class objects aren&apos;t exactly run-of the-mill). &quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Which is also pretty believable.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Could you try out the nightly build from tonight? The 0920 build in:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://people.apache.org/builds/jakarta-commons/nightly/commons-lang/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://people.apache.org/builds/jakarta-commons/nightly/commons-lang/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12455925" author="bayard" created="Wed, 6 Dec 2006 09:01:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Not heard from Neil as to whether it fixed his problem. Understandable given that it took a couple of months to get passed 2.2 and apply the fix to SVN.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is a research class that I &lt;em&gt;think&lt;/em&gt; shows that WeakHashMaps are okay with Classes as keys provided the ClassLoader is available for garbage collection. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m a bit unsure of it though because I don&apos;t understand why accessing the class through the HashMap API is giving me null as the classes ClassLoader, yet when it was loaded it was the correct FooClassLoader.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Any thoughts? Is this proof or just crap?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12456591" author="bayard" created="Thu, 7 Dec 2006 20:33:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Took another look at this. I was being dumb and calling getClass() on the key when it came back from the map; and as it was the Class object itself that meant it returned java.lang.Class from the bootstrap loader.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Have deleted the original and reattached a version with the correct debug statement. This class shows that the patch should work:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) Load a class from a different classloader.&lt;br/&gt;
2) Make it the key in a WeakHashMap.&lt;br/&gt;
3) Remove references to the original classloader.&lt;br/&gt;
4) Let System.gc occur.&lt;br/&gt;
5) The WeakHashMap is empty.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12456606" author="bayard" created="Thu, 7 Dec 2006 21:43:22 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think my research class shows that things should work. Making it a unit test seems a lot more painful, which I&apos;m finding very hard to have the energy for. Resolving this as fixed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                            <attachment id="12346708" name="ClassMapping.java" size="1623" author="bayard" created="Thu, 7 Dec 2006 20:33:48 +0000"/>
                    </attachments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-261] Error in an example in the javadoc of the StringUtils.splitPreserveAllTokens() method</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-261</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;There is an error in the javadoc of the org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtils.splitPreserveAllTokens(String str,char separatorChar) method.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here the original line :&lt;br/&gt;
StringUtils.splitPreserveAllTokens(&quot;a..b.c&quot;, &apos;.&apos;)   = &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot;a&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;b&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;c&amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But it should be :&lt;br/&gt;
StringUtils.splitPreserveAllTokens(&quot;a..b.c&quot;, &apos;.&apos;)   = &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot;a&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;b&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;c&amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12343737">LANG-261</key>
            <summary>Error in an example in the javadoc of the StringUtils.splitPreserveAllTokens() method</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/trivial.svg">Trivial</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="cimballi">Cimballi</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 1 Jun 2006 00:10:25 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 16 Dec 2009 08:50:40 +0000</updated>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-259] ValuedEnum.compareTo(Object other) not typesafe - it easily could be...</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-259</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;int org.apache.commons.lang.enums.ValuedEnum.compareTo(Object other)&lt;br/&gt;
 is not typesafe - if the int-values are the same, it will return &quot;0&quot; even for two totally different sub-classes of ValuedEnum&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;all&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12343351">LANG-259</key>
            <summary>ValuedEnum.compareTo(Object other) not typesafe - it easily could be...</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="ralfhauser">Ralf Hauser</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 22 May 2006 21:10:15 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 21 Oct 2006 11:26:20 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 18 Aug 2006 22:21:34 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.2</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12412798" author="ralfhauser" created="Mon, 22 May 2006 23:00:43 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Before just comparing the &lt;br/&gt;
   iValue - ((ValuedEnum) other).iValue&lt;br/&gt;
it should be checked that the classes are the same!&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		Enum otherEnum = (Enum) other;&lt;br/&gt;
		String thisClassName = this.getClass().getName();&lt;br/&gt;
		String otherClassName = otherEnum.getClass().getName();&lt;br/&gt;
		if (!otherClassName.equals(thisClassName)) &lt;/p&gt;
{
			log.warn(&quot;enum classes are not equal \&quot;&quot; + thisClassName + &quot;\&quot; &amp;lt;&amp;gt; \&quot;&quot; + otherClassName + &quot;\&quot;&quot;);
			throw new ClassCastException(&quot;enum classes are not equal \&quot;&quot; + thisClassName + &quot;\&quot; &amp;lt;&amp;gt; \&quot;&quot; + otherClassName
					+ &quot;\&quot;&quot;);
		}

&lt;p&gt;Furthermore, it might be recommendable to make some methods of org.apache.commons.lang.enums.Enum at least &quot;protected&quot; such that ValuedEnum can use them too:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If available, I would love to also have the more sophisticated checks, Enum.compareTo(Object other) does also used in ValuedEnum.compareTo(Object other):&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;if (res == 0) {&lt;br/&gt;
			String otherName = otherEnum.getName();&lt;br/&gt;
			if (other.getClass() != this.getClass()) {&lt;br/&gt;
				if (other.getClass().getName().equals(this.getClass().getName())) &lt;/p&gt;
{
					return iName.compareTo(getNameInOtherClassLoader(other));
				}
&lt;p&gt;			}&lt;br/&gt;
			res = iName.compareTo(otherName);&lt;br/&gt;
			if (res != 0) &lt;/p&gt;
{
				log.warn(&quot;enum names are not equal \&quot;&quot; + otherName + &quot;\&quot; &amp;lt;&amp;gt; \&quot;&quot; + this.getName() + &quot;\&quot;&quot;);
				throw new ClassCastException(&quot;enum names are not equal \&quot;&quot; + otherName + &quot;\&quot; &amp;lt;&amp;gt; \&quot;&quot; + this.getName()
						+ &quot;\&quot;&quot;);
                       }
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12412801" author="ralfhauser" created="Mon, 22 May 2006 23:45:37 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;furthermore, it would be great if the classe&apos;s init would also detect if multiple int values are the same:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;e.g.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt; public static final JavaVersionEnum  JAVA1_0  = new JavaVersionEnum( &quot;Java 1.0&quot;, JAVA1_0_VALUE );&lt;br/&gt;
 public static final JavaVersionEnum  JAVA1_0_=  = new JavaVersionEnum( &quot;Java 1.0.0&quot;, JAVA1_0_VALUE );&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12412802" author="ralfhauser" created="Mon, 22 May 2006 23:47:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;similarly, it should detect double entries of this kind...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public static final int  JAVA1_0_VALUE  = 100;&lt;br/&gt;
public static final int  JAVA1_0_0VALUE  = 100;&lt;br/&gt;
...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt; public static final JavaVersionEnum JAVA1_0 = new JavaVersionEnum( &quot;Java 1.0&quot;, JAVA1_0_VALUE );&lt;br/&gt;
 public static final JavaVersionEnum JAVA1_0_0 = new JavaVersionEnum( &quot;Java 1.0.0&quot;, JAVA1_0_0VALUE );&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;------&lt;br/&gt;
ps, the last line in the previous comment should have been&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public static final JavaVersionEnum JAVA1_0_0 = new JavaVersionEnum( &quot;Java 1.0.0&quot;, JAVA1_0_VALUE );&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12412909" author="ralfhauser" created="Tue, 23 May 2006 18:03:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;see also &lt;a href=&quot;http://issues.apache.org/struts/browse/SB-20&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://issues.apache.org/struts/browse/SB-20&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/STR-2943&quot; title=&quot;support enum&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;STR-2943&quot;&gt;SB-20&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-258&quot; title=&quot;Enum JavaDoc: 1) outline 5.0 native Enum migration 2) warn not to use the switch() , 3) point out approaches for persistence and gui&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-258&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-258&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12415296" author="bayard" created="Thu, 8 Jun 2006 15:42:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In an effort to get 2.2 out sooner rather than later, I&apos;m assiging all the Enum issues to 2.3. There&apos;s been no work on them currently and might be best to focus on them in a 2.3 release instead of trying to squeeze them into the 2.2 release.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Hopefully this will keep the 2.3 release scope pretty tight.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12427364" author="scolebourne" created="Thu, 10 Aug 2006 22:43:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Does anyone believe that the classloader tricks in Enum are useful? They seem like a Bad Idea now, and are broken, even for equals.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Is it  too backwards incompatible to remove the classloader code?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12429140" author="scolebourne" created="Fri, 18 Aug 2006 22:21:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fix compareTo to check type&lt;br/&gt;
rv 432748&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-158] new StringUtils.split methods that split on the whole separator string</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-158</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In other languages, the string split method can split a string using a whole&lt;br/&gt;
string as the delimiter rather than using the separator string as a list of&lt;br/&gt;
characters at which to split the string-to-be-split.  I&apos;ve implemented these&lt;br/&gt;
methods a few times, and I&apos;ve given them the signature split( String, String,&lt;br/&gt;
boolean&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;, int&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; ) so that they can delegate to the existing lang split( String,&lt;br/&gt;
String&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;, int&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; ) methods where appropriate.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341110">LANG-158</key>
            <summary>new StringUtils.split methods that split on the whole separator string</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="hotfusionman@yahoo.com">Albert Davidson Chou</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 22 Nov 2003 14:33:20 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 16 Dec 2009 08:50:39 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 16 Dec 2009 08:50:39 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>

                            <comment id="12405497" author="hotfusionman@yahoo.com" created="Sat, 29 Nov 2003 07:26:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Given the changes made in response to &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-41&quot; title=&quot;last substring returned by StringUtils.split( String, String, int ) is too long&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-41&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;COM-960&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;, should I submit new patches based on the &lt;br/&gt;
state of CVS now?  The old patches did not change the contract of this family of methods, and &lt;br/&gt;
neither would new ones.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405498" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sat, 29 Nov 2003 21:30:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;There is an informal rule in StringUtils that we don&apos;t use a boolean flag to &lt;br/&gt;
distinguish between two method variants. Instead we use an alternate &lt;br/&gt;
descriptive name. splitByString() may be a possible name.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also, any patches should use the style of the surrounding code - brackets at &lt;br/&gt;
end on line in this case.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405499" author="hotfusionman@yahoo.com" created="Sun, 30 Nov 2003 01:47:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Darn, I was hoping this would be a generalization of the existing split() family, and the way I came &lt;br/&gt;
up with to delegate existing behavior to the existing methods was to change the method &lt;br/&gt;
signature.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m happy to change the method name if that&apos;s what&apos;s needed (and reformat opening brace &lt;br/&gt;
placement).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405500" author="bayard" created="Sun, 22 Aug 2004 10:42:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Methods committed as splitByWholeSeparator method. Opinions and a better name&lt;br/&gt;
are both desired.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-157] Removed compile warning in ObjectUtils</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-157</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In Eclipse 2.1.M4, you get the following warning compiling &lt;br/&gt;
java/org/apache/commons/lang/ObjectUtils.java:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Access to enclosing constructor ObjectUtils.Null() is emulated by a synthetic &lt;br/&gt;
accessor method. Increasing its visibility will improve your performance&lt;br/&gt;
	ObjectUtils.java	Jakarta Commons &lt;br/&gt;
Lang/src/java/org/apache/commons/lang	line 85&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Attaching patch.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;FYI, there are currently no other such warnings in the &quot;src/java&quot; tree. There &lt;br/&gt;
are plenty of warnings in the &quot;src/test&quot; tree, which I am not as much &lt;br/&gt;
concerned with.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340535">LANG-157</key>
            <summary>Removed compile warning in ObjectUtils</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-156] [LANG] - o.a.c.lang.enum.ValuedEnum: &apos;enum&apos;is a keyword in JDK1.5.0</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-156</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I meet this error while trying to compile cocoon code using JDK1.5.0:&lt;br/&gt;
 /cocoon-2.1/src/blocks/forms/java/org/apache/cocoon/forms/event/ProcessingPhase.java:22:&lt;br/&gt;
as of release 1.5, &apos;enum&apos; is a keyword, and may not be used as an identifier&lt;br/&gt;
(try -source 1.4 or lower to use &apos;enum&apos; as an identifier)&lt;br/&gt;
import org.apache.commons.lang.enum.ValuedEnum;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Seems like JDK1.5.0 don&apos;t like the enum keyword inside the import statement.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341787">LANG-156</key>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-155] [lang] maven-beta10 checkstyle problem</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-155</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;maven beta 10 uses the newest version of checkstyle, which no longer supports&lt;br/&gt;
the property configuration format.  It expects an xml file.  So, the line in&lt;br/&gt;
lang&apos;s project.properties which points to checkstyle.properties is causing the&lt;br/&gt;
plugin to fail.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340867">LANG-155</key>
            <summary>[lang] maven-beta10 checkstyle problem</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mhawthorne@alumni.pitt.edu">_matthewHawthorne</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 23 Jul 2003 02:11:38 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:37:05 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:37:05 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12404740" author="mhawthorne@alumni.pitt.edu" created="Wed, 23 Jul 2003 02:12:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=7459)&lt;br/&gt;
a tiny patch which comments out the checkstyle.properties line&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404741" author="phil@steitz.com" created="Thu, 24 Jul 2003 11:55:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Another way to deal with this problem is to create &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1. an xml config file, checkstyle.xml containing the properties in&lt;br/&gt;
checkstyle.properties&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2. add a line to your local build.properties file (create one if you aren&apos;t&lt;br/&gt;
using one) that sets maven.checkstyle.properties = checkstyle.xml. This will&lt;br/&gt;
override the setting in project.properties.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;That way, the maven checkstyle plugin will still work for people using the old&lt;br/&gt;
version.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I am no maven expert, but the above is working for me.  It would probably be a&lt;br/&gt;
good idea for someone to add a good checkstyle.xml to cvs.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404742" author="mhawthorne@alumni.pitt.edu" created="Thu, 24 Jul 2003 12:21:43 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Your suggestion is without a doubt the correct long term solution.  A week or so&lt;br/&gt;
ago when maven-b10 was released, I looked into the new checkstyle configuration&lt;br/&gt;
format, but didn&apos;t have to time to learn the new syntax.  My solution was meant&lt;br/&gt;
to be a quick fix until a proper checkstyle.xml could be constructed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404743" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sat, 26 Jul 2003 20:24:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Applied.&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;sarcasm&amp;gt;Nice to see maven makes life easier for project management.&amp;lt;/sarcasm&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                            <attachment id="12332431" name="ASF.LICENSE.NOT.GRANTED--project.properties.patch" size="474" author="mhawthorne@alumni.pitt.edu" created="Wed, 23 Jul 2003 02:12:21 +0000"/>
                    </attachments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-154] [lang][patch] Remove redundant check for null separator in StringUtils#join</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-154</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The method guards against a null separator so the later check for null is not&lt;br/&gt;
required.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;(Thanks to findbugs 0.7.1)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;patch attached.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341276">LANG-154</key>
            <summary>[lang][patch] Remove redundant check for null separator in StringUtils#join</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="janekdb@yahoo.co.uk">Janek Bogucki</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 16 Feb 2004 05:17:19 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 16 Oct 2013 08:55:03 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 16 Dec 2009 08:50:32 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12406030" author="janekdb@yahoo.co.uk" created="Mon, 16 Feb 2004 05:18:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=10369)&lt;br/&gt;
Removes redundant null check in StringUtls#jion&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12406031" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Tue, 17 Feb 2004 07:48:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch applied and then some. Thanks!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12406032" author="bayard" created="Wed, 26 Apr 2006 13:10:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;2.1 released, closing.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-153] [lang] Can&apos;t XMLDecode an Enum</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-153</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I am encoding and decoding Enums using java.beans.XMLEncoder/Decoder.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When an Enum is decoded, I am using the following to get the instance. The&lt;br/&gt;
enumClass name and the enum name are stored in the serialized XML file, then&lt;br/&gt;
used to restore the bean at read time&lt;br/&gt;
        return EnumUtils.getEnum(enumClass, name);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The problem is that the Enum.cEnumClasses map may not contain an entry for the&lt;br/&gt;
Enum class yet, despite the fact that the Class for the enum has been loaded.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If I loop through the Class.fields using reflection and get(null) the value for&lt;br/&gt;
each one, then the cEnumClasses is populated and getEnum works.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows 2000&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342108">LANG-153</key>
            <summary>[lang] Can&apos;t XMLDecode an Enum</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="3">Duplicate</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="kevin.gilpin@alum.mit.edu">Kevin Gilpin</reporter>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-152] [lang] DurationFormatUtils.formatDurationWords &quot;11 &lt;unit&gt;s&quot; gets converted to &quot;11 &lt;unit&gt;&quot;</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-152</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The method DurationFormatUtils.formatDurationWords incorrectly outputs numbers&lt;br/&gt;
ending in &quot;1&quot; without a plural &quot;s&quot; postfix for the time unit.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Added a fix and tests that &quot;1 &amp;lt;unit&amp;gt;s&quot; gets converted to &quot;1 &amp;lt;unit&amp;gt;&quot; but that &quot;11&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;unit&amp;gt;s&quot; is left alone.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-151] [lang] General case: infinite loop: ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-151</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Something like the following structure results in an infinite loop:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;cClass Alpha {&lt;br/&gt;
Beta beta;&lt;br/&gt;
public toString() {&lt;br/&gt;
return ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;class Beta {&lt;br/&gt;
Alpha alpha;&lt;br/&gt;
public toString() &lt;/p&gt;
{
return ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString
}

}&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
Something like the following structure results in an infinite loop:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
cClass Alpha {&lt;br/&gt;
Beta beta;&lt;br/&gt;
public toString() {&lt;br/&gt;
return ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
class Beta {&lt;br/&gt;
Alpha alpha;&lt;br/&gt;
public toString() {return ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString}
}

&lt;p&gt;Bug 15976 refers to inner classes - in fact any mutually referential classes&lt;br/&gt;
will spin out into an infinite loop. (Discovered this using two Hibernate&lt;br/&gt;
persistent beans.) refers to inner classes - in fact any mutually referential classes&lt;br/&gt;
will spin out into an infinite loop. (Discovered this using two Hibernate&lt;br/&gt;
persistent beans.)&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340677">LANG-151</key>
            <summary>[lang] General case: infinite loop: ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bugzilla@jackwasey.com">Jack Wasey</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 26 Apr 2003 01:29:19 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:40:28 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:40:28 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12404144" author="mohankishore@yahoo.com" created="Sat, 26 Apr 2003 08:35:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Bug 15976 seems to be incorrect. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;And what is proposed resolution? I mean, the same situation would arise, even &lt;br/&gt;
if the ToStringBuilder was not used and the classes used each others toString() &lt;br/&gt;
method recursively... seems to be incorrect. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;And what is proposed resolution? I mean, the same situation would arise, even &lt;br/&gt;
if the ToStringBuilder was not used and the classes used each others toString() &lt;br/&gt;
method recursively...&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404145" author="mohankishore@yahoo.com" created="Sat, 26 Apr 2003 08:36:37 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I meant, that the bug# provided in the original comment seems to be incorrect. &lt;br/&gt;
It does not refer to inner classes etc.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404146" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Mon, 23 Jun 2003 23:21:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This has been fixed in the nightly build for quite some time as I notice that&lt;br/&gt;
this report is marked for version 1.0Alpha. Can you please check your case&lt;br/&gt;
against a current build? Thanks.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404147" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Tue, 24 Jun 2003 00:27:16 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;For an example test, see the method&lt;br/&gt;
ToStringBuilderTest.testReflectionObjectCycle() v 1.8. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I would like to close thie PR if the reporter (Jack Wasey) could confirm that&lt;br/&gt;
the current build solves the issue in his code.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404148" author="eiichiro.takahashi@ulsystems.co.jp" created="Thu, 21 Aug 2003 20:22:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hello. I found similar bug.&lt;br/&gt;
I&apos;m not good at English.&lt;br/&gt;
So, if you found &quot;syntax error&quot;, please ignore it. &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;---------------------------------------------------------------&lt;br/&gt;
private static class Alpha{&lt;br/&gt;
  private Alpha alpha;&lt;br/&gt;
  public Alpha()&lt;/p&gt;
{
    this.alpha = this;
  }

&lt;p&gt;  public String toString()&lt;/p&gt;
{
    return ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString(this);
  }
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;br/&gt;
---------------------------------------------------------------&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This code ends with StackOverflowError. My environment is ...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;System.out.println(&quot;&quot; + ToStringBuilder.class.getPackage&lt;br/&gt;
().getImplementationVersion()); returns &quot;1.0.1&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404149" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Tue, 27 Jul 2004 04:48:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Closing. This was fixed a long time ago.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404150" author="bayard" created="Wed, 26 Apr 2006 13:08:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Not entirely sure, but going with 2.0 as the fix version for this.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-150] [lang] StringEscapeUtils.unescapeHtml skips first entity after standalone ampersand</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-150</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;StringEscapeUtils.unescapeHtml skips the first entity after a standalone ampersand.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Code:&lt;br/&gt;
System.out.println(&lt;br/&gt;
StringEscapeUtils.unescapeHtml(&quot;test &amp;amp; &amp;auml; &amp;ouml;&quot;)&lt;br/&gt;
);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Output:&lt;br/&gt;
test &amp;amp; &amp;auml; &#246;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Expected output:&lt;br/&gt;
test &amp;amp; &#228; &#246;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342894">LANG-150</key>
            <summary>[lang] StringEscapeUtils.unescapeHtml skips first entity after standalone ampersand</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

                            <comment id="12411383" author="trejkaz" created="Mon, 6 Mar 2006 09:14:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=17838)&lt;br/&gt;
Patch to work around this issue&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This patch works around spaces being between the &apos;&amp;amp;&apos; and the &apos;;&apos;.  To be more&lt;br/&gt;
correct, it should probably ensure that all characters between the &apos;&amp;amp;&apos; and &apos;;&apos;&lt;br/&gt;
are valid entity characters, but in most cases the offending character is a&lt;br/&gt;
space.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411384" author="bayard" created="Tue, 18 Apr 2006 13:41:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Recreated issue with unit test. The proposed solution is too simple - we need to&lt;br/&gt;
be able to handle all situations, not just times when there is a space after the &amp;amp;. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411385" author="bayard" created="Tue, 18 Apr 2006 14:24:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed by checking whether an &amp;amp; is closer than the subsequent ;. If so, then skip&lt;br/&gt;
onwards. Also a problem in unescapeXml.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Fixing issue #38569&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/Entities.java&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/test/org/apache/commons/lang/StringEscapeUtilsTest.java&lt;br/&gt;
Transmitting file data ..&lt;br/&gt;
Committed revision 394875.   &lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-149] [lang] Nestable.indexOfThrowable(Class) uses Class.equals() to match</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-149</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The indexOfThrowable() method should use Class.isAssignableFrom() to find the&lt;br/&gt;
nested esception so that it can find subclasses of the given exception.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Or alternatively, the javadoc should state the usage of Class.equals()&lt;br/&gt;
explicitly so that people that go looking for SQLExceptions know that the method&lt;br/&gt;
is useless to them and that they&apos;ll need to write their own.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341669">LANG-149</key>
            <summary>[lang] Nestable.indexOfThrowable(Class) uses Class.equals() to match</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="shorn.tolley@nrm.qld.gov.au">Shorn Tolley</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 30 Aug 2004 07:35:53 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:21:55 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:21:55 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12407380" author="bayard" created="Thu, 30 Sep 2004 13:23:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This seems logical to me.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;throwables&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;i&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;.getClass().equals(type)   changed to&lt;br/&gt;
type.isAssignableFrom(throwables&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;i&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;.getClass()) in ExceptionUtils and NestableDelegate.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407381" author="bayard" created="Thu, 30 Sep 2004 13:51:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Reopening for the moment. It breaks tests (I foolishly had only the Time tests running from previous &lt;br/&gt;
dev work) and I want to get community opinion.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407382" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sun, 17 Oct 2004 00:49:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I changed the behaviour of Nestable, but left ExceptionUtils alone. Instead, in &lt;br/&gt;
ExceptionUtils I added a parallel method, indexOfType. This should cover the &lt;br/&gt;
use cases and some measure of backwards compatability.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407383" author="bayard" created="Wed, 26 Apr 2006 13:11:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;2.1 released, closing.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-148] [lang] Performance modifications on StringUtils.replace</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-148</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I dont know how picky you are about performance, but I think it would be nice &lt;br/&gt;
for methods like this not to create new objects (StringBuffers) and copy over, &lt;br/&gt;
if it doesnt need to (e.g. if what you are searching for is not in the &quot;text&quot; &lt;br/&gt;
String).  Also, if the text is empty, we can return it right away.  And, my &lt;br/&gt;
profiler gets two StringBuffers and an arrayCopy here sometimes since we only &lt;br/&gt;
allocate enough for the original String.  I think overall it is better to &lt;br/&gt;
allocate a little more (+20%) for the StringBuffer to reduce this possibility &lt;br/&gt;
and only have 1 StringBuffer to be garbage collected.  Feel free to pick and &lt;br/&gt;
choose from any of these ideas.  &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public static String replace(String text, String repl, String with, int max) {&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;could be written as:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  public static String replace(String text, String repl, String with, int max) &lt;br/&gt;
{&lt;br/&gt;
    if (isEmpty(text) || isEmpty(repl) || with == null || max == 0) &lt;/p&gt;
{
      return text;
    }&lt;br/&gt;
    int start = 0, end = text.indexOf(repl, start);&lt;br/&gt;
    if (end == -1) {      return text;    }
&lt;p&gt;    //add a bit of padding so we reduce the StringBuffer extend capacity&lt;br/&gt;
    StringBuffer buf = new StringBuffer(text.length() &lt;br/&gt;
        + (text.length() &amp;lt; 20 ? 4 : text.length()/5));&lt;br/&gt;
    while (end != -1) {&lt;br/&gt;
      buf.append(text.substring(start, end)).append(with);&lt;br/&gt;
      start = end + repl.length();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;      if (--max == 0) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        break;
      }
&lt;p&gt;      end = text.indexOf(repl, start);&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;br/&gt;
    buf.append(text.substring(start));&lt;br/&gt;
    return buf.toString();&lt;br/&gt;
  }&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;I tested it on the test cases in the javadoc and it worked fine.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks!&lt;br/&gt;
Chris&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342547">LANG-148</key>
            <summary>[lang] Performance modifications on StringUtils.replace</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mchyzer@yahoo.com">Chris</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 10 Sep 2005 05:46:47 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 16 Dec 2009 08:50:32 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 16 Dec 2009 08:50:32 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>2.2</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12410385" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sat, 10 Sep 2005 18:37:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Code changed, based on code below, but with different algorithm for sizing.&lt;br/&gt;
Please test this algorithm to see if it still helps with your performance issues.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        <customfield id="customfield_12311820" key="com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-lexo-rank">

<item>
            <title>[LANG-147] StringUtils.chopNewLine - StringIndexOutOfBoundsException</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-147</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;StringUtils.chopNewLine doesn&apos;t handle a single char string of &quot;\n&quot;. It looks&lt;br/&gt;
for the previous char to see if it&apos;s &quot;\r&quot; which causes it to throw exception.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340777">LANG-147</key>
            <summary>StringUtils.chopNewLine - StringIndexOutOfBoundsException</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
