<item>
            <title>[LANG-146] Enum does not support inner sub-classes</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-146</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The org.apache.commons.lang.enum.Enum class does not support the following&lt;br/&gt;
construct of static inner anonymous sub-classed constants:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public abstract class MyEnum extends Enum {&lt;br/&gt;
	public static final MyEnum ENUM1 = new MyEnum(&quot;enum1&quot;) {&lt;br/&gt;
		public String getValue() &lt;/p&gt;
{
			return &quot;X&quot;;
		}
&lt;p&gt;	};&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	public static final MyEnum ENUM2 = new MyEnum(&quot;enum2&quot;) {&lt;br/&gt;
		public String getValue() &lt;/p&gt;
{
			return &quot;Y&quot;;
		}
&lt;p&gt;	};&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	/**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Constructor.&lt;br/&gt;
	 */&lt;br/&gt;
	protected MyEnum(String name) 
{
		super(name);
	}&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;	/**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Returns a value.&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Creation date: (16/12/2002 13:25:35)&lt;br/&gt;
	 */&lt;br/&gt;
	public abstract String getValue();&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;ENUM1 and ENUM2 are assigned anonymous inner class names &apos;MyEnum$0&apos; and&lt;br/&gt;
&apos;MyEnum$1&apos; respectively instead of the super class &apos;MyEnum&apos; when added to the&lt;br/&gt;
list of enumerations kept in the Enum super class via the Enum constructor.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A simple work around is to strip the inner class descriminator off the class&lt;br/&gt;
name  in the Enum constructor, i.e.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    protected Enum(String name) {&lt;br/&gt;
        super();&lt;br/&gt;
        if (name == null || name.length() == 0) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            throw new IllegalArgumentException(&quot;The Enum name must not be empty&quot;);
        }
&lt;p&gt;        iName = name;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        // Retrieve class name.&lt;br/&gt;
        String className = getClass().getName();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        // Search for inner class.&lt;br/&gt;
        int index = className.lastIndexOf(&apos;$&apos;);&lt;br/&gt;
        if (index &amp;gt; -1) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                // Strip off inner class reference.
                className = className.substring(0, index);
        }

&lt;p&gt;        Entry entry = (Entry) cEnumClasses.get(className);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        if (entry == null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            entry = new Entry();
            cEnumClasses.put(className, entry);
        }
&lt;p&gt;        if (entry.map.containsKey(name)) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            throw new IllegalArgumentException(&quot;The Enum name must be unique, &apos;&quot;
+ name + &quot;&apos; has already been added&quot;);
        }
&lt;p&gt;        entry.map.put(name, this);&lt;br/&gt;
        entry.list.add(this);&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340462">LANG-146</key>
            <summary>Enum does not support inner sub-classes</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="chris.webb@voxsurf.com">Chris Webb</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 17 Dec 2002 20:38:22 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:44:37 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:44:37 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12403366" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Thu, 19 Dec 2002 07:21:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In the example given, it would seem appropriate to add an extra parameter to &lt;br/&gt;
the constructor:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public static final MyEnum ENUM1 = new MyEnum(&quot;enum1&quot;, &quot;X&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Does this solve the problem?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403367" author="chris.webb@voxsurf.com" created="Thu, 19 Dec 2002 22:07:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Yes I agree if the inner sub-class method was just returning a value then&lt;br/&gt;
modifying the constructor to take in the value would work because no&lt;br/&gt;
sub-classing would be required. My example was probably not the best because I&lt;br/&gt;
was thinking more along the lines where the static enum definition contained a&lt;br/&gt;
method that encapsulated logic other than merely returning a value which would&lt;br/&gt;
require sub-classing.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403368" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Wed, 1 Jan 2003 06:46:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Change made to support functional enums along the lines proposed here. Check &lt;br/&gt;
the CVS.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403369" author="chris.webb@voxsurf.com" created="Thu, 30 Jan 2003 00:10:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=4621)&lt;br/&gt;
Patch Enum class&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403370" author="chris.webb@voxsurf.com" created="Thu, 30 Jan 2003 00:11:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=4622)&lt;br/&gt;
Enum test class&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403371" author="chris.webb@voxsurf.com" created="Thu, 30 Jan 2003 00:12:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I found a bug with my original very simplisting solution. The follwing is the&lt;br/&gt;
correct algorythm to determine the actual enumeration class for a given&lt;br/&gt;
enumeration object which may be defined by an inner class. I&apos;ve attached the&lt;br/&gt;
patched class and a test class.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;// Search for actual enumerated type. This is necessary as enumerated types might&lt;br/&gt;
// be defined by inner classes. The actual enumerated type is defined as the top&lt;br/&gt;
container or&lt;br/&gt;
// declaring class that can be assigned to the actual class of enumeration being&lt;br/&gt;
added.&lt;br/&gt;
Class clazz = this.getClass();&lt;br/&gt;
while (clazz.getDeclaringClass() != null &amp;amp;&amp;amp;     &lt;br/&gt;
clazz.getDeclaringClass().isAssignableFrom(this.getClass())) {&lt;br/&gt;
	clazz = clazz.getSuperclass();&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403372" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Wed, 5 Feb 2003 02:33:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Regrettably, getDeclaringClass() doesn&apos;t function correctly on my JDK141. I &lt;br/&gt;
have got a version and test code on the CVS for your problem, and also to &lt;br/&gt;
support hierarchical Enums now. Perhaps you could test that?&lt;br/&gt;
Stephen&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403373" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Mon, 24 Mar 2003 00:26:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Closing as I believe fixed in CVS&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-145] [lang][PATCH] Unused field &apos;startFinal&apos; in DateIterator</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-145</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The field &apos;startFinal&apos; in o.a.c.lang.time.DateUtils$DateIterator is unused. The&lt;br/&gt;
attached patch removes this field. The unit tests run okay after this change.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;(Unrelated to this (except by locality), is there any reason why &apos;endFinal&apos; is&lt;br/&gt;
final and &apos;spot&apos; is not?)&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340821">LANG-145</key>
            <summary>[lang][PATCH] Unused field &apos;startFinal&apos; in DateIterator</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="janekdb@yahoo.co.uk">Janek Bogucki</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 26 Jun 2003 06:59:03 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:38:17 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:38:17 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12404625" author="janekdb@yahoo.co.uk" created="Thu, 26 Jun 2003 07:00:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=6982)&lt;br/&gt;
This patch removes an unused variable from o.a.c.lang.time.DateUtils$DateIterator&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404626" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Fri, 27 Jun 2003 02:20:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Should the constructor DateIterator(Calendar startFinal, Calendar endFinal) be&lt;br/&gt;
abbreviated to DateIterator(Calendar endFinal)?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Perhaps the author could shed some light on this. Thanks.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404627" author="janekdb@yahoo.co.uk" created="Fri, 27 Jun 2003 03:10:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The constructor needs to keep the two arg version so it can know the date range&lt;br/&gt;
to iterate over.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404628" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Fri, 27 Jun 2003 04:00:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;But one of the args is not used in the class. Is that a bug?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404629" author="janekdb@yahoo.co.uk" created="Fri, 27 Jun 2003 05:01:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The parameter &apos;startFinal&apos; is used twice, once to assign to the field&lt;br/&gt;
&apos;this.startFinal&apos; and then to assign to the field &apos;this.spot&apos;. It&apos;s the field&lt;br/&gt;
which is unused not the parameter. Sorry for the confusion. The patch file&lt;br/&gt;
explained it better than I did!&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;   /**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Date iterator.&lt;br/&gt;
     */&lt;br/&gt;
    static class DateIterator implements Iterator {&lt;br/&gt;
        private final Calendar startFinal;&lt;br/&gt;
        private final Calendar endFinal;&lt;br/&gt;
        private Calendar spot = null;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;        DateIterator(Calendar startFinal, Calendar endFinal) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            super();
            this.startFinal = startFinal;
            this.endFinal = endFinal;
            spot = startFinal;
            spot.add(Calendar.DATE, -1);
        }

&lt;p&gt;        public boolean hasNext() &lt;/p&gt;
{
            return spot.before(endFinal);
        }

&lt;p&gt;        public Object next() {&lt;br/&gt;
            if (spot.equals(endFinal)) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                throw new NoSuchElementException();
            }
&lt;p&gt;            spot.add(Calendar.DATE, 1);&lt;br/&gt;
            return spot.clone();&lt;br/&gt;
        }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        public void remove() &lt;/p&gt;
{
            throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
        }
&lt;p&gt;    }&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404630" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sun, 29 Jun 2003 00:52:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch applied, thanks&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-144] [lang] [patch] EqualsBuilder.append(Object[], Object[]) throws NPE</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-144</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hi,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;if you append array&apos;s which contains null values to an EqualsBuilder instance, &lt;br/&gt;
a NPE is thrown. This causes troubles in the ArrayUtils.isEquals(Object[], &lt;br/&gt;
Object[]) method as well because it uses the EqualsBuilder class.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To duplicate: execute this code:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Object[] array1 = new Object[] &lt;/p&gt;
{&quot;1&quot;, null, &quot;2&quot;};&lt;br/&gt;
Object[] array2 = new Object[] {&quot;1&quot;, null, &quot;2&quot;}
&lt;p&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
new EqualsBuilder().append(array1, array2).isEquals();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;and you&apos;ll get this Exception:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.lang.NullPointerException&lt;br/&gt;
at org.apache.commons.lang.builder.EqualsBuilder.append(EqualsBuilder.java:513)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;kind regards,&lt;br/&gt;
Maarten Coene&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340969">LANG-144</key>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-140] [lang] DurationFormatUtils.formatPeriod() returns the wrong result</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-140</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;/**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;lib: commons-lang-2.1.jar&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;this class run result.&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Result:&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Date1-&amp;gt;Date2=2006/01/26 18:47:34 000-&amp;gt;2006/02/26 10:47:34 000===0000&amp;rdquo;N01&lt;br/&gt;
&#140;&#142;-1&amp;ldquo;&#250; 16:00:00 000&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Date1-&amp;gt;Date2=2006/01/26 18:47:34 000-&amp;gt;2006/02/26 10:47:34 000===0000/01/-&lt;br/&gt;
1 16:00:00 000&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;want result:&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Date1-&amp;gt;Date2=2006/01/26 18:47:34 000-&amp;gt;2006/02/26 10:47:34 000===0000&amp;rdquo;N00&#140;&#142;&lt;br/&gt;
30&amp;ldquo;&#250; 16:00:00&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Date1-&amp;gt;Date2=2006/01/26 18:47:34 000-&amp;gt;2006/02/26 10:47:34&lt;br/&gt;
000===0000/00/30 16:00:00&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;the results are wrong.&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;p&gt; */&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;import java.text.SimpleDateFormat;&lt;br/&gt;
import java.util.Calendar;&lt;br/&gt;
import java.util.Date;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import org.apache.commons.lang.time.DurationFormatUtils;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public class Test {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    static SimpleDateFormat formatter = new SimpleDateFormat(&quot;yyyy/MM/dd &lt;br/&gt;
HH:mm:ss SSS&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;    public static void main(String[] args) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        Date date1 = newDate(2006, 1, 26, 18, 47, 34);
        Date date2 = newDate(2006, 2, 26, 10, 47, 34);
        System.out.println(&quot;Date1-&amp;gt;Date2=&quot; + 
                formatter.format(date1) + &quot;-&amp;gt;&quot; + formatter.format(date2) 
+ &quot;===&quot; +  
                DurationFormatUtils.formatPeriod(date1.getTime(), date2.getTime
(), &quot;yyyy&amp;rdquo;NMM&#140;&#142;dd&amp;ldquo;&#250; HH:mm:ss SSS&quot;) );

        System.out.println(&quot;Date1-&amp;gt;Date2=&quot; + 
                formatter.format(date1) + &quot;-&amp;gt;&quot; + formatter.format(date2) 
+ &quot;===&quot; +  
                DurationFormatUtils.formatPeriod(date1.getTime(), date2.getTime
(), &quot;yyyy/MM/dd HH:mm:ss SSS&quot;) );
    
    }

&lt;p&gt;    public static Date newDate(int y, int m, int d, int h, int mi, int s) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        Calendar calendar1 = Calendar.getInstance();
        calendar1.clear();
        calendar1.set(y, m - 1, d, h, mi, s);
        Date date1 = calendar1.getTime();
        return date1;
    }

&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342874">LANG-140</key>
            <summary>[lang] DurationFormatUtils.formatPeriod() returns the wrong result</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="bayard">Henri Yandell</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="yuhere@gmail.com">yu.peng</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 26 Jan 2006 22:41:00 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 6 Feb 2007 23:47:17 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 19 Jun 2006 19:49:40 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>2.2</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12411327" author="bayard" created="Thu, 9 Mar 2006 16:18:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;So it&apos;s claiming it&apos;s 1 month minus 1 day and not 30 days. Ugh.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Looking into it, the issue is that when the code rolls back in hours, it rolls&lt;br/&gt;
the days back - even if 0. It needs to roll months back if days are 0 (and so on&lt;br/&gt;
back up to years).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411328" author="bayard" created="Thu, 9 Mar 2006 16:21:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Not that easy though. Needs to be, for this particular case:&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;If days = 0, then roll month back (from 1 to 0) and set days to the maximum&lt;br/&gt;
number of days in the preceding month (which is January and thus 30). &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It gets ugly when you get down to the seconds, as their rollback effect becomes&lt;br/&gt;
an increasingly nested loop.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411329" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Fri, 10 Mar 2006 02:34:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In the context of Ticket 33825&lt;br/&gt;
(&lt;a href=&quot;http://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=33825&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=33825&lt;/a&gt;), one can consider&lt;br/&gt;
Joda-Time.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411330" author="yuhere@gmail.com" created="Fri, 10 Mar 2006 17:28:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=17861)&lt;br/&gt;
period &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;there is a &quot;period&quot; method in this file , that method can return the period&lt;br/&gt;
String , can&apos;t format it , because the some format methods are use &apos;package&apos;&lt;br/&gt;
defined. I hope the &quot;period&quot; method can add into the common_lang lib,and&lt;br/&gt;
provides the format function.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411331" author="bayard" created="Mon, 17 Apr 2006 13:22:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=18111)&lt;br/&gt;
Unit test for this bug.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

                            <comment id="12412711" author="yuhere@gmail.com" created="Mon, 22 May 2006 07:52:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;How can I get the DurationFormatUtilsTest.java and fixed DurationFormatUtils.java.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12416757" author="bayard" created="Mon, 19 Jun 2006 19:49:40 +0000"  >
&lt;p&gt;Fix committed. Played with it while on holiday and found that there was a nice simple fix (least all the unit tests pass with this fix and it seems to make sense). The nightly build appears to be down currently, so the way to get to the code would be to svn co &lt;a href=&quot;https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/jakarta/commons/proper/lang/trunk&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/jakarta/commons/proper/lang/trunk&lt;/a&gt; and build a jar using ant or maven.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Added unit test for &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-140&quot; title=&quot;[lang] DurationFormatUtils.formatPeriod() returns the wrong result&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-140&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-140&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; - thanks to Yu Peng for the test case&quot; src/t&lt;br/&gt;
est/org/apache/commons/lang/time/DurationFormatUtilsTest.java &lt;br/&gt;

Transmitting file data .&lt;br/&gt;
Committed revision 415316.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt; svn ci -m &quot;Committing fix for &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-140&quot; title=&quot;[lang] DurationFormatUtils.formatPeriod() returns the wrong result&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-140&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-140&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;. By reversing the order of field calculation,&lt;br/&gt;
 Yu Peng&apos;s bug goes away&quot; src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/time/DurationFormatUtils.java &lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-139] [lang] EnumTest fails on Linux Sun JDK 1.3.0</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-139</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;both tests in EnumTest.testOperationSerialization() fail with the following &lt;br/&gt;
exception:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) testOperationSerialization(org.apache.commons.lang.enum.EnumTest)&lt;br/&gt;
java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/apache/commons/lang/enum/OperationEnum$1&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;where OperationEnum$1 is OperationEnum.PLUS, the static anonymous class in &lt;br/&gt;
OperationEnum. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I plan to comment these tests out for any releases.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Linux&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340664">LANG-139</key>
            <summary>[lang] EnumTest fails on Linux Sun JDK 1.3.0</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bayard">Henri Yandell</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 15 Apr 2003 21:21:33 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 16 Oct 2013 08:54:58 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:41:01 +0000</resolved>

                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12404097" author="bayard" created="Wed, 30 Jul 2003 10:01:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Also breaks on JDK 1.2.2 on Linux. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;One possible way to get around it is the rather dubious use of an explicitly named &lt;br/&gt;
OperationEnum$1 class. &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;ie) not an anonymous inner class, but pretending to be&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404098" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sun, 3 Aug 2003 01:41:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Change made to OperationEnum. Can someone try it on Linux to see if it fixes &lt;br/&gt;
it??&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404099" author="phil@steitz.com" created="Sun, 3 Aug 2003 02:54:07 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The tests and all sources now compile and run fine for me under Sun Linux JDK&lt;br/&gt;
1.3.1_8&lt;/p&gt;

be instantiated.&lt;br/&gt;

    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;                ^&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
/home/phil/jakarta-commons/lang/src/test/org/apache/commons/lang/enum/OperationEnum.java:76:&lt;br/&gt;

be instantiated.&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;         MINUS = new OperationEnum(&quot;Minus&quot;) {&lt;br/&gt;

    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 2 errors, 1 warning&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I also had to add &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;encoding=&quot;ISO-8859-1&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;to the build.xml javac targets to get Entities, MethodUtils and&lt;br/&gt;
DurationFormatUtils to compile under 1.2.2_016.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404100" author="phil@steitz.com" created="Mon, 4 Aug 2003 09:32:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;To clarify the comment above, all that is failing is compile.tests under Sun&lt;br/&gt;
Linux  JDK 1.2.2.  The compile target succeeds (i.e. src/java builds fine) and&lt;br/&gt;
the tests run clean using this JRE when compiled using 1.4.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404101" author="bayard" created="Tue, 5 Aug 2003 00:41:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Stephen&apos;s change still fails to compile on my Linux JDK 1.2.2.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; /home/hen/jakarta/src/jakarta-&lt;br/&gt;
commons/lang/src/test/org/apache/commons/lang/enum/OperationEnum.java:71: &lt;br/&gt;
class org.apache.commons.lang.enum.OperationEnum is an abstract class. It &lt;br/&gt;
can&apos;t be instantiated.&lt;br/&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;javac&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;         PLUS = new OperationEnum(&quot;Plus&quot;) {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I haven&apos;t needed to use Phil&apos;s encoding attribute however to make the others &lt;br/&gt;
compile.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404102" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Tue, 5 Aug 2003 03:24:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;OK, I finally understand the problem.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;static final OperationEnum PLUS = new OperationEnum(&quot;Plus&quot;) {&lt;br/&gt;
};&lt;br/&gt;
is defining a new anonymous class. However, because it is assigned to a static &lt;br/&gt;
field and declared in a static context, the class must be a static nested class &lt;br/&gt;
instead of an inner class. (inner classes reference their owning object, nested &lt;br/&gt;
classes don&apos;t)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Obviously Sun improved the spec between 1.2 and 1.3 to allow for this unusual &lt;br/&gt;
case by generating a nested class instead of an inner. 1.2 just objects that it &lt;br/&gt;
can&apos;t create an inner class here.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So...we either find a way around the problem, or declare this particular piece &lt;br/&gt;
of functionality broken if compiled using 1.2.&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12404103" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Tue, 5 Aug 2003 06:57:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Change made. It should work now on JDK1.2.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404104" author="bayard" created="Thu, 7 Aug 2003 10:06:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Now works on JDK 1.2 on Linux. 1.3 had the same problem.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-138] ValuedEnum</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-138</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When values of ValuedEnum are defined as final (as the JavaDoc suggests),&lt;br/&gt;
then all classes that use this enum will hold the value itself and not reference&lt;br/&gt;
after compilation. Compiler substitutes references to final with the value of&lt;br/&gt;
final variable itself. Then if you change the value in you enum and recompile &lt;br/&gt;
it, you must recompile also all the classes that use the enum. Otherwise they &lt;br/&gt;
continue to use old value.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341751">LANG-138</key>
            <summary>ValuedEnum</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="itzik.levin@verint.com">Itzik Levin</reporter>

                            <comment id="12407644" author="bayard" created="Thu, 30 Sep 2004 13:37:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Added a javadoc. Largely this is something developers just learn, do a clean then build if making lots of &lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-136] [lang] Make StopWatch validate state transitions</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-136</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Per Henri&apos;s email to commons-dev on 5/23/2004, StopWatch currently let&apos;s you &lt;br/&gt;
call split() or stop() multiple times.  StopWatch could benefit from some &lt;br/&gt;
validation, to make sure the following validation occurs:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1. split(), suspend(), or stop() cannot be invoked twice.&lt;br/&gt;
2. unsplit() may only be called if the watch has been split()&lt;br/&gt;
3. resume() may only be called if the watch has been suspend()&lt;br/&gt;
4. start() cannot be called twice.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Whomever takes on this burden should take some time to draw a simple state &lt;br/&gt;
transition diagram and put it in the JavaDoc.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341470">LANG-136</key>
            <summary>[lang] Make StopWatch validate state transitions</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="tobrien@discursive.com">Tim O&apos;Brien</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 24 May 2004 04:20:09 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 16 Oct 2013 08:54:57 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:25:10 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12406665" author="bayard" created="Wed, 2 Jun 2004 10:58:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;There should also be a getLastSplitTime() or some such. For a StopWatch, I&lt;br/&gt;
should have available the last split time and the current time at the same time.&lt;br/&gt;
If not split, the last split time should be 0.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12406666" author="bayard" created="Sun, 18 Jul 2004 11:23:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Attempt at a crude state table.&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;                  STATE_UNSTARTED STATE_RUNNING STATE_SPLIT STATE_STOPPED&lt;br/&gt;
STATE_SUSPENDED&lt;br/&gt;
=================|===============|=============|===========|=============|===============&lt;br/&gt;
start()          |      X        |      -      |     -     |      -      |       -&lt;br/&gt;
stop()           |      -        |      X      |     X     |      -      |       -&lt;br/&gt;
reset()          |      -        |      ?      |     ?     |      X      |       -&lt;br/&gt;
split()          |      -        |      X      |     X     |      -      |       -&lt;br/&gt;
unsplit()        |      -        |      -      |     X     |      -      |       -&lt;br/&gt;
suspend()        |      -        |      X      |     X     |      -      |       -&lt;br/&gt;
resume()         |      -        |      -      |     -     |      -      |       X&lt;br/&gt;
getTime()        |      X        |      X      |     X     |      X      |       X&lt;br/&gt;
getSplitTime()   |      -        |      -      |     X     |      -      |       -&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12406667" author="bayard" created="Sun, 18 Jul 2004 11:27:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The table above represents my thoughts on how Stopwatch should work. Bit crappy&lt;br/&gt;
as it means a change in the features of the API. Perhaps stupidly, X means yes,&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;means no and ? is unsure.&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;In addition, getTime would always return the time to now (unless suspended),&lt;br/&gt;
while getSplitTime would be used to do splits.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I can see one immediate problem. If in SUSPEND, should still be able to call&lt;br/&gt;
stop(). The two ? marks are because I&apos;m not sure if reset() should stop() if the&lt;br/&gt;
stopwatch is not stopped yet. If so, then the only state that can&apos;t have reset&lt;br/&gt;
is UNSTARTED.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12406668" author="bayard" created="Wed, 2 Feb 2005 13:24:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Tis all implemented. The state table is slightly different for reset, anything&lt;br/&gt;
may be reset so X&apos;s all the way across.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12406669" author="bayard" created="Wed, 26 Apr 2006 13:10:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;2.1 released, closing.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-135] [lang][patch] Javadoc fixes for CharSetUtils</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-135</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The attached patch fixes the Javadoc for three methods in CharSetUtils.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Incidentally the @deprecated tag for translate(String, String, String) suggests&lt;br/&gt;
StringUtils#replaceChars(String, String, String) as a replacement but&lt;br/&gt;
StringUtils#replaceChars behaves differently when &apos;searchChars&apos; is longer than&lt;br/&gt;
&apos;replaceChars&apos;. CharUtils#translate will use the last char of the replacement&lt;br/&gt;
string whereas StringUtils#replaceChars will delete. Is this difference worth&lt;br/&gt;
noting?&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@deprecated Use 
{@link StringUtils#replaceChars(String, String, String)}
&lt;p&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Method will be removed in Commons Lang 3.0.&lt;br/&gt;
     */&lt;br/&gt;
    public static String translate(String str, String searchChars, String&lt;br/&gt;
replaceChars) {&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341293">LANG-135</key>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-134] javadoc - &apos;four basic XML entities&apos; should be 5 (apos is missing)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-134</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;in class &amp;lt;code&amp;gt;StringEscapeUtils&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;, the javadoc of the methods&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;code&amp;gt;public static String escapeXml(String str)&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
and&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;code&amp;gt;public static String unescapeXml(String str)&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
says:&lt;br/&gt;
&apos;Supports only the four basic XML entities (gt, lt, quot, amp).&apos;&lt;br/&gt;
It should say &lt;br/&gt;
&apos;Supports only the five basic XML entities (gt, lt, quot, amp, apos).&apos;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341782">LANG-134</key>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-132] [lang] SystemUtils.IS_OS_*, IS_JAVA_* are always false.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-132</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;SystemUtils.IS_OS_&lt;b&gt;, IS_JAVA_&lt;/b&gt; always returns false.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This case is on Mac OS X.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;
&lt;p&gt;% java -version&lt;br/&gt;
java version &quot;1.4.1_01&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.1_01-39)&lt;br/&gt;
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.1_01-14, mixed mode)&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;hr /&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The test code is:&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;#8212;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import org.apache.commons.lang.*;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public class OSNameTest {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    static public void main(String[] arg) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        System.out.println(System.getProperty(&quot;os.name&quot;));
        System.out.println(SystemUtils.IS_OS_MAC_OSX);
        System.out.println(SystemUtils.IS_OS_WINDOWS);
        System.out.println(SystemUtils.IS_JAVA_1_4);
    }
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;#8211;&lt;br/&gt;
The result is:&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;#8212;&lt;br/&gt;
Mac OS X&lt;br/&gt;
false&lt;br/&gt;
false&lt;br/&gt;
false&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;#8212;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It should be:&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;#8211;&lt;br/&gt;
Mac OS X&lt;br/&gt;
true&lt;br/&gt;
false&lt;br/&gt;
true&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;#8211;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The cause:  IS_JAVA_&lt;b&gt;, IS_OS_&lt;/b&gt; values are based on&lt;br/&gt;
JAVA_VERSOIN, OS_NAME, OS_VERSION. But JAVA_VERSION, OS_NAME,&lt;br/&gt;
OS_VERSION are initialized after IS_JAVA_&lt;b&gt;, IS_OS_&lt;/b&gt; values.&lt;br/&gt;
When IS_OS_* are initialized, OS_NAME == null.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;They should be declared considering the initialization order.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340862">LANG-132</key>
            <summary>[lang] SystemUtils.IS_OS_*, IS_JAVA_* are always false.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="tetsuyak@ka2.so-net.ne.jp">KANEUCHI Tetsuya</reporter>

                    </labels>

patch to o.a.c.l.SystemUtils.java. Modified declaration order.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404724" author="tetsuyak@ka2.so-net.ne.jp" created="Mon, 21 Jul 2003 19:37:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=7422)&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-131] [lang] StringEscapeUtils.unescapeHtml() doesn&apos;t handle an empty entity</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-131</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Pass the a string containing &quot;&amp;amp;;&quot; (without double quotes) to &lt;br/&gt;
StringEscapeUtils.unescapeHtml().  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This will result in an ArrayIndexOutOfBounds error.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341468">LANG-131</key>
            <summary>[lang] StringEscapeUtils.unescapeHtml() doesn&apos;t handle an empty entity</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="dan.goldberg@fetch.com">dan goldberg</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 22 May 2004 05:40:42 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:25:13 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:25:13 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12406658" author="dan.goldberg@fetch.com" created="Sat, 22 May 2004 05:53:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Sorry, the error it throws is a StringIndexOutOfBoundsException not an &lt;br/&gt;
ArrayIndexOutOfBounds&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12406659" author="janekdb@yahoo.co.uk" created="Wed, 26 May 2004 05:15:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&amp;amp;#; also causes a problem&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException: String index out of range: 1&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;     at java.lang.String.charAt(String.java:460)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;     at org.apache.commons.lang.Entities.unescape(Entities.java:652)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;     at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang.StringEscapeUtils.unescapeHtml(StringEscapeUtils.java:447)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Is this really a bug though? How robust should this method be in the face of&lt;br/&gt;
malformed entities? For example all these malformed entities also cause&lt;br/&gt;
problems. Maybe these exceptions should be converted to an&lt;br/&gt;
IllegalArgumentException and rethrown.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &amp;amp;# ; java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: &quot; &quot;&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &amp;amp;#&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;Unable to render embedded object: File ( For input string: &amp;quot;) not found.&lt;/span&gt;&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &amp;amp;#&quot;; java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: &quot;&quot;&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &amp;amp;##; java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: &quot;#&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &amp;amp;#$; java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: &quot;$&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &amp;amp;#%; java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: &quot;%&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &amp;amp;#&apos;; java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: &quot;&apos;&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &amp;amp;#(; java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: &quot;(&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &amp;amp;#); java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: &quot;)&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &amp;amp;#&lt;b&gt;; java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: &quot;&lt;/b&gt;&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &amp;amp;#&lt;ins&gt;; java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: &quot;&lt;/ins&gt;&quot;&lt;br/&gt;

                            <comment id="12406660" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Wed, 2 Jun 2004 04:31:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;If these can be easily trapped without a major performance overhead then they should be.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12406661" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sun, 17 Oct 2004 01:54:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixes added to handle invalid entities, and treat them as non-entities.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-130] [lang] Memory &quot;leak&quot; in StringUtils</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-130</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The static field PADDING allocates 262152 bytes for nothing.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;private static final String[] PADDING = new String&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;Character.MAX_VALUE&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;At least use lazy creation, better completely remove it (move to method) to save&lt;br/&gt;
memory (Having 20 apps on one tomcat --&amp;gt; 5MB allocated for nothing).&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342941">LANG-130</key>
            <summary>[lang] Memory &quot;leak&quot; in StringUtils</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebastian.kirsch@paybox.net">sebastian.kirsch</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 27 Feb 2006 22:59:21 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 16 Dec 2009 08:50:40 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 16 Dec 2009 08:50:40 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.2</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12411512" author="bayard" created="Mon, 6 Mar 2006 15:34:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I favour switching to lazy loading; have asked on the mailng list how others feel.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411513" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Tue, 7 Mar 2006 03:18:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Seems like a good idea. Since PADDING is private, the change will not create an&lt;br/&gt;
incompatibility.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411514" author="sandymac@apache.org" created="Tue, 7 Mar 2006 04:05:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Has it been shown that the PADDING caching actually benefits anything? I think&lt;br/&gt;
it should be removed as it&apos;s just going to consume more and more memory until&lt;br/&gt;
the StringUtils class is unloaded.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Either way the StringUtils.padding(int,char) should be changed to use a&lt;br/&gt;
StringBuffer. I&apos;d change the method to:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;private static String padding(int repeat, char padChar) {&lt;br/&gt;
  StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer(repeat); &lt;br/&gt;
  while (sb.length() &amp;lt; repeat) &lt;/p&gt;
{
    pad = pad.concat(pad);
  }
&lt;p&gt;  return sb.toString();&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;and remove the PADDING static field.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411515" author="sandymac@apache.org" created="Tue, 7 Mar 2006 04:13:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;One more thing, if it is desirable to keep the number of equal string instances&lt;br/&gt;
low then the return could be changed to:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  return sb.toString().intern();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But if Java 1.1 is a target for lang then that shouldn&apos;t be used as it will leak&lt;br/&gt;
memory. It wasn&apos;t until Java 1.2 that the intered string pool would allow unused&lt;br/&gt;
intered strings to be garbage collected.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411516" author="sebastian.kirsch@paybox.net" created="Tue, 7 Mar 2006 15:52:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;(In reply to comment #3)&lt;br/&gt;
I agree to this proposal, would be my preferred solution.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411517" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Wed, 8 Mar 2006 04:47:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think we should let call sites decide whether or not Strings should be interned.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411518" author="sandymac@apache.org" created="Wed, 8 Mar 2006 05:22:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fix commited. I choose to use a char[] array instead of a StringBuffer but&lt;br/&gt;
otherwise it&apos;s just like what comment #3 describes.&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs?rev=384017&amp;amp;view=rev&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs?rev=384017&amp;amp;view=rev&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-129] [lang] test.time fails in Japanese (non-us) locale.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-129</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;test.time fails in Japanese locale.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The tests are DateUtilsTest.testParseCVS() and&lt;br/&gt;
DateFormatUtilsTest.testSMTP().&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The cause is that these tests depend on US locale but use&lt;br/&gt;
default locale.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;By the way, does parseCVS() needs Locale arg?&lt;br/&gt;
I think &quot;CVS format&quot; means that the language is English.&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-128] [lang] WordUtils capitalizeFully() throws a null pointer exception</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-128</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When submitting a null value I get a null pointer exception, it would be &lt;br/&gt;
preferable for a function such as this to simply return the null value instead &lt;br/&gt;
of blow up.  Otherwise I have to add unnecessary logic in front of what should &lt;br/&gt;
be a simple function call.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342088">LANG-128</key>
            <summary>[lang] WordUtils capitalizeFully() throws a null pointer exception</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-126] [lang][patch] Make ClassUtils methods null-safe and not throw an IAE.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-126</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;A number of ClassUtils methods that a designed to return Strings throw a new&lt;br/&gt;
IllegalArgumentException when the input arg is null. I would like to change&lt;br/&gt;
these methods to return &quot;&quot; (or null). The methods are:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;String getShortClassName(Class cls)&lt;br/&gt;
String getShortClassName(String className)&lt;br/&gt;
String getPackageName(Class cls)&lt;br/&gt;
String getPackageName(String className)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thoughts for or against?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-125] [lang] DateUtils constants should be long</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-125</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The fields&lt;br/&gt;
    MILLIS_IN_SECOND ,MILLIS_IN_MINUTE ,MILLIS_IN_HOUR,MILLIS_IN_DAY &lt;br/&gt;
should be of type long so that if you have an expression:&lt;br/&gt;
System.out.println(new Date(30 * 365 * DateUtils.MILLIS_IN_DAY));&lt;br/&gt;
it doesn&apos;t print out as&lt;br/&gt;
Wed Jan 14 18:46:34 GMT 1970&lt;br/&gt;
due to overflow of integer!&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341166">LANG-125</key>
            <summary>[lang] DateUtils constants should be long</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="n.metchev@teamphone.com">Nikolay Metchev</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 18 Dec 2003 23:09:51 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:31:15 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:31:15 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12405689" author="amamment" created="Fri, 19 Dec 2003 00:12:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;IMHO, bad reason to make the constants long.  All it takes is using any of:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;System.out.println(new Date(30L * 365 * DateUtils.MILLIS_IN_DAY));&lt;br/&gt;
System.out.println(new Date(30 * 365L * DateUtils.MILLIS_IN_DAY));&lt;br/&gt;
System.out.println(new Date(30L * 365L * DateUtils.MILLIS_IN_DAY));&lt;br/&gt;
  or, best of all, &lt;br/&gt;
System.out.println(new Date((long) 30 * 365 * DateUtils.MILLIS_IN_DAY));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;-AMT&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405690" author="n.metchev@teamphone.com" created="Fri, 19 Dec 2003 00:21:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;IMHO, its a good reason to change because it introduces very subtle bugs which &lt;br/&gt;
are tremendously difficult to track down. The fact that to fix the bug is an &lt;br/&gt;
easy thing doesn&apos;t mean that finding the bug is easy. This will eliminate the &lt;br/&gt;
bug altogether.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you can think of a reason why it SHOULDN&apos;T be long then let me know but if &lt;br/&gt;
there are not good reasons for keeping it an int then I guess it wont hurt!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405691" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Fri, 19 Dec 2003 03:51:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This should definitely be changed&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405692" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Fri, 19 Dec 2003 04:52:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Indeed, since these values express milliseconds and APIs which take or return&lt;br/&gt;
millisconds usually do so a longs.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405693" author="phil@steitz.com" created="Tue, 23 Dec 2003 11:58:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;New long constants MILLIS_PER_SECOND ,MILLIS_PER_MINUTE&lt;br/&gt;
,MILLIS_PER_HOUR,MILLIS_PER_DAY have been added and the integer versions have&lt;br/&gt;
been deprecated.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The new constants should appear in &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;lang&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; nightly builds starting 1/23/03.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The deprecated constants will be removed in Lang 3.0.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405694" author="bayard" created="Wed, 26 Apr 2006 13:11:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;2.1 released, closing.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                                            <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">
                        <customfieldname>Attachment count</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>0.0</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        <customfield id="customfield_10010" key="com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:importid">
                        <customfieldname>Bugzilla Id</customfieldname>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-124] [lang] enum package is not compatible with 1.5 jdk</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-124</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Classes that are located in org.apache.commons.lang.enum package can&apos;t be used &lt;br/&gt;
with 1.5 jdk (aka the 5.0) because the &quot;enum&quot; is a reserved keyword. Compiler &lt;br/&gt;
error looks like this: &quot;as of release 1.5, &apos;enum&apos; is a keyword, and may not be &lt;br/&gt;
used as an identifier (try -source 1.4 or lower to use &apos;enum&apos; as an &lt;br/&gt;
identifier)&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There probably should be a separate jar for 1.5+ jdk&lt;/p&gt;</description>

            <title>[LANG-123] [lang] Unclear javadoc for DateUtils.iterator()</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-123</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The javadoc for DateUtils.iterator() seems to say that the iterator returned&lt;br/&gt;
will only have two dates: the start date and the end date. If it iterates over&lt;br/&gt;
more dates, which interval is use: hour, day, week or something else?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;For instance, passing Thursday, July 4, 2002 and a RANGE_MONTH_SUNDAY will&lt;br/&gt;
return an Iterator that starting with Sunday, June 30, 2002 iterates over every&lt;br/&gt;
day (at midnight) until with Saturday, August 3, 2002.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also the Date version of the method does not say that the iterator returns&lt;br/&gt;
Calendar and not Date as I would have expected given the method signature.&lt;/p&gt;</description>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-122] [lang] EscapeUtil.escapeHtml() should clarify that it does not escape &apos; chars to &amp;apos;</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-122</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The official HTML character entity spec does not include the popular &quot;&amp;amp;apos;&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
entity name for the single quote character &apos;. the StringUtils class correctly&lt;br/&gt;
follows this behavior, leaving single quotes alone. However, many developers&lt;br/&gt;
incorrectly assume that &apos; will get escaped into &amp;amp;apos; (I was one!) and we can&lt;br/&gt;
help them by clarifying this in the Javadoc.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The following could be appended to the method Javadoc:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Note: Not all common HTML entity names are formally included in the standard&lt;br/&gt;
specification (&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/sgml/entities.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/sgml/entities.html&lt;/a&gt;, as listed&lt;br/&gt;
below). This method follows the standard, and thus does not escape the&lt;br/&gt;
single-quote &apos; character into &amp;amp;apos.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342684">LANG-122</key>
            <summary>[lang] EscapeUtil.escapeHtml() should clarify that it does not escape &apos; chars to &amp;apos;</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-121] split using null and max less than actual token count adds &quot;null&quot;</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-121</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;/*&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This bug is using Commons Lang 1.0 with JDK 1.4.0_01.&lt;br/&gt;
The problem only occurs when using null as the separator and using a&lt;br/&gt;
max value which is less than the number of actual tokens and making &lt;br/&gt;
use of the last token which consists of what is left of the string&lt;br/&gt;
being tokenized. Because null is passed, the existing code loops through&lt;br/&gt;
the rest of the tokens, appending null to each of them, expecting that&lt;br/&gt;
the result will be the remaining string, except the string &quot;null&quot; is &lt;br/&gt;
appended rather than a real token...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;*/&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtils;&lt;br/&gt;
import java.util.StringTokenizer;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;/**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;If you replace the&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;String[] split(String str, String separator, int max) code with the&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;fixedSplit code below, it will fix the problem.  The code below&lt;br/&gt;
demonstrates the problem&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;and the solution.&lt;br/&gt;
 *&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;NOTE: I have not run any JUnit tests for this - don&apos;t know how.  But - this&lt;br/&gt;
demonstrates the&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;but and supplies the solution.&lt;br/&gt;
 *&lt;br/&gt;
 */&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;public class DemoSplitBug {&lt;br/&gt;
    public static final String strToSplit = &quot;This is a test of the emergency &lt;br/&gt;
broadcast system.&quot;;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public static void main(String[] args) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        DemoSplitBug.demoSplitBug(strToSplit);
        DemoSplitBug.demoSplitBugFix(strToSplit);
    }

&lt;p&gt;    public static void demoSplitBug(String theString) {&lt;br/&gt;
        String[] theSplits = StringUtils.split(theString, null, 4);&lt;br/&gt;
        for (int i = 0; i &amp;lt; theSplits.length; i++) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            String theSplit = theSplits[i];
            System.out.println(&quot;theSplit:&quot; + theSplit);
        }
&lt;p&gt;    }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public static void demoSplitBugFix(String theString) {&lt;br/&gt;
        String[] theSplits = fixedSplit(theString, null, 4);&lt;br/&gt;
        for (int i = 0; i &amp;lt; theSplits.length; i++) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            String theSplit = theSplits[i];
            System.out.println(&quot;theSplit:&quot; + theSplit);
        }
&lt;p&gt;    }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public static String[] fixedSplit(String str, String separator, int max) {&lt;br/&gt;
        StringTokenizer tok = null;&lt;br/&gt;
        if (separator == null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            // Null separator means we&apos;re using StringTokenizer&apos;s default
            // delimiter, which comprises all whitespace characters.
            tok = new StringTokenizer(str);
        }
&lt;p&gt; else &lt;/p&gt;
{
            tok = new StringTokenizer(str, separator);
        }

&lt;p&gt;        int listSize = tok.countTokens();&lt;br/&gt;
        if (max &amp;gt; 0 &amp;amp;&amp;amp; listSize &amp;gt; max) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            listSize = max;
        }

&lt;p&gt;        String[] list = new String&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;listSize&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
        int i = 0;&lt;br/&gt;
        int lastTokenBegin = 0;&lt;br/&gt;
        int lastTokenEnd = 0;&lt;br/&gt;
        while (tok.hasMoreTokens()) {&lt;br/&gt;
            if (max &amp;gt; 0 &amp;amp;&amp;amp; i == listSize - 1) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                // In the situation where we hit the max yet have
                // tokens left over in our input, the last list
                // element gets all remaining text.
                String endToken = tok.nextToken();
                lastTokenBegin = str.indexOf(endToken, lastTokenEnd);
                list[i] = str.substring(lastTokenBegin);
                break;
            }
&lt;p&gt; else &lt;/p&gt;
{
                list[i] = tok.nextToken();
                lastTokenBegin = str.indexOf(list[i], lastTokenBegin);
                lastTokenEnd = lastTokenBegin + list[i].length();
            }
&lt;p&gt;            i++;&lt;br/&gt;
        }&lt;br/&gt;
        return list;&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340390">LANG-121</key>
            <summary>split using null and max less than actual token count adds &quot;null&quot;</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mcdoma@ncs.com">Mark McDowell</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 30 Oct 2002 03:43:08 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:45:54 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:45:54 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.0.1</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>

                            <comment id="12403116" author="mcdoma@ncs.com" created="Wed, 30 Oct 2002 04:24:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Slightly embarassing, but what follows is code that works better than the &lt;br/&gt;
originally submitted code...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public static String[] split(String str, String separator, int max) {&lt;br/&gt;
        StringTokenizer tok = null;&lt;br/&gt;
        if (separator == null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            // Null separator means we&apos;re using StringTokenizer&apos;s default
            // delimiter, which comprises all whitespace characters.
            tok = new StringTokenizer(str);
        }
&lt;p&gt; else &lt;/p&gt;
{
            tok = new StringTokenizer(str, separator);
        }

&lt;p&gt;        int listSize = tok.countTokens();&lt;br/&gt;
        if (max &amp;gt; 0 &amp;amp;&amp;amp; listSize &amp;gt; max) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            listSize = max;
        }

&lt;p&gt;        String[] list = new String&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;listSize&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
        int i = 0;&lt;br/&gt;
        int lastTokenBegin = 0;&lt;br/&gt;
        int lastTokenEnd = 0;&lt;br/&gt;
        while (tok.hasMoreTokens()) {&lt;br/&gt;
            if (max &amp;gt; 0 &amp;amp;&amp;amp; i == listSize - 1) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                // In the situation where we hit the max yet have
                // tokens left over in our input, the last list
                // element gets all remaining text.
                String endToken = tok.nextToken();
                lastTokenBegin = str.indexOf(endToken, lastTokenEnd);
                list[i] = str.substring(lastTokenBegin);
                break;
            }
&lt;p&gt; else &lt;/p&gt;
{
                list[i] = tok.nextToken();
                lastTokenBegin = str.indexOf(list[i], lastTokenEnd);
                lastTokenEnd = lastTokenBegin + list[i].length();
            }
&lt;p&gt;            i++;&lt;br/&gt;
        }&lt;br/&gt;
        return list;&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-120] [lang] public static boolean DateUtils.equals(Date dt1, Date dt2) ?</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-120</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hello,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtils, we can find StringUtils.equals(?,?). &lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang.time.DateUtils should have the same. Like this :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    /**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;p&amp;gt;Compares two Dates, returning &amp;lt;code&amp;gt;true&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt; if they are equal.&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
     *&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;p&amp;gt;&amp;lt;code&amp;gt;null&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;s are handled without exceptions. Two&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;code&amp;gt;null&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;references are considered to be equal.&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
     *&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;pre&amp;gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;DateUtils.equals(null, null)   = true&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;DateUtils.equals(null, &quot;abc&quot;)  = false&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;DateUtils.equals(&quot;abc&quot;, null)  = false&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;DateUtils.equals(&quot;abc&quot;, &quot;abc&quot;) = true&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;DateUtils.equals(&quot;abc&quot;, &quot;ABC&quot;) = false&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
     *&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@see java.util.Date#equals(Object)&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@param dt1  the first Date, may be null&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@param dt2  the second Date, may be null&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@return &amp;lt;code&amp;gt;true&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt; if the Dates are equal or both&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;code&amp;gt;null&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
     */&lt;br/&gt;
	  public static boolean equals(Date dt1, Date dt2) 
{
	      return (dt1 == null ? dt2 == null : dt1.equals(dt2));
	  }&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341266">LANG-120</key>
            <summary>[lang] public static boolean DateUtils.equals(Date dt1, Date dt2) ?</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
