                            <comment id="12405992" author="brentworden" created="Sat, 14 Feb 2004 02:55:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Other than the stronger typed method signature, how is what you propose any &lt;br/&gt;
different than the equals method in ObjectUtils?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405993" author="serge" created="Sat, 14 Feb 2004 03:22:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I was going to comment on this, but this actually answers the comment by Brent.&lt;br/&gt;
 I suggest DateUtils.equals would test the getTime() method.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;long now = System.currentTimeMillis();&lt;br/&gt;
java.util.Date date = new java.util.Date(now);&lt;br/&gt;
java.util.Date timestamp = new java.sql.Timestamp(now);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;DateUtils.equals(date, timestamp) = true&lt;br/&gt;
however&lt;br/&gt;
ObjectUtils.equals(date, timestamp) = false&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405994" author="mpatron@influe.com" created="Mon, 16 Feb 2004 17:31:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Yes, I agree with you. And I propose the code to do this :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    /**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;p&amp;gt;Compares two Dates, returning &amp;lt;code&amp;gt;true&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt; if they are equal.&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
     *&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;p&amp;gt;&amp;lt;code&amp;gt;null&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;s are handled without exceptions. Two&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;code&amp;gt;null&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;references are considered to be equal.&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
     *&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;pre&amp;gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;long now = System.currentTimeMillis();&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;java.util.Date date = new java.util.Date(now);&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;java.sql.Timestamp timestamp = new java.sql.Timestamp(now);&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;DateUtils.equals(null, null)   = true&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;DateUtils.equals(null, date)  = false&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;DateUtils.equals(date, null)  = false&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;DateUtils.equals(date, date) = true&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;DateUtils.equals(date, timestamp) = true&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;/pre&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
     *&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@see java.util.Date#equals(Object)&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@param dt1  the first Date, may be null&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@param dt2  the second Date, may be null&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@return &amp;lt;code&amp;gt;true&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt; if the Dates are equal or both&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;code&amp;gt;null&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
     */&lt;br/&gt;
	  public static boolean equals(Date dt1, Date dt2) 
{
	      return (dt1 == null ? dt2 == null : dt1.getTime() == dt2.getTime
());
	  }&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12405995" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Tue, 17 Feb 2004 02:57:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The assumption that time values are equal for Date and Timestamp is incorrect as&lt;br/&gt;
the basic test below shows. Writting unit tests first avoids this kind of&lt;br/&gt;
misunderstandings &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; Also, supplying unit tests with your code greatly&lt;br/&gt;
increases the patching process and confidence in submissions compared to &quot;blind&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
submissions. &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Index: ObjectUtilsTest.java&lt;br/&gt;

&lt;p&gt;+    public void testDateEquals() &lt;/p&gt;
{
+        long now = 1076957313284L; // Feb 16, 2004 10:49 PST
+        java.util.Date date = new java.util.Date(now);
+        java.util.Date timestamp = new java.sql.Timestamp(now);
+        assertEquals(date.getTime(), timestamp.getTime());
+        assertEquals(timestamp, date);
+        assertTrue(ObjectUtils.equals(date, timestamp));
+    }
&lt;p&gt;+    &lt;br/&gt;
     public void testIdentityToString() {&lt;br/&gt;
         assertEquals(null, ObjectUtils.identityToString(null));&lt;br/&gt;
         assertEquals(&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405996" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Tue, 17 Feb 2004 03:17:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;BTW, the 1st assert blows up.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405997" author="mpatron@influe.com" created="Tue, 17 Feb 2004 17:16:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Yes, in fact. ObjectUtils can do the job to compare two dates.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;long now= System.currentTimeMillis();&lt;br/&gt;
java.util.Date date= new java.util.Date(now);&lt;br/&gt;
java.sql.Timestamp timestamp= new java.sql.Timestamp(now);&lt;br/&gt;
assertTrue(ObjectUtils.equals(null, null));&lt;br/&gt;
assertFalse(ObjectUtils.equals(null, date));&lt;br/&gt;
assertFalse(ObjectUtils.equals(date, null));&lt;br/&gt;
assertTrue(ObjectUtils.equals(date, date));&lt;br/&gt;
assertTrue(ObjectUtils.equals(date, timestamp));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Then, DateUtils doesn&apos;t need a specific &apos;equals&apos; methode.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks for all.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405998" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Wed, 18 Feb 2004 02:43:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Reopening, this issue is still under discussion on commons-dev.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405999" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sun, 17 Oct 2004 00:11:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In total, five date comparison methods have been added to DateUtils. Hopefully &lt;br/&gt;
we can close this call for 2.1 now.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-119] [lang] Can&apos;t subclass EqualsBuilder because isEquals is private</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-119</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I want to create my own version of EqualsBuilder that not only goes through&lt;br/&gt;
arrays and checks if array contents are equal, but also goes through Maps,&lt;br/&gt;
Lists, Sets, etc.  I can&apos;t because isEquals is private and there is no setEquals&lt;br/&gt;
method.  Please make isEquals protected or add a setEquals method.  Thanks!&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Matt&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341929">LANG-119</key>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-118] [lang] StringEscapeUtils.unescapeHtml() doesn&apos;t handle hex entities</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-118</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Pass a string into the unescapeHtml() method that contains a hex entity (i.e. &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;#xB7; instead of &amp;#183;) and you will get a NumberFormatException.  The &lt;br/&gt;
offending code is in Entity.java, line 690.  It should check whether the &lt;br/&gt;
character after the # is &apos;x&apos; and if so, prefix it with &apos;0&apos; and call &lt;br/&gt;
Integer.decode().intValue() (or some other hex converting function).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Hex entities are valid HTML &lt;br/&gt;
(&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.htmlhelp.com/reference/html40/entities/latin1.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.htmlhelp.com/reference/html40/entities/latin1.html&lt;/a&gt;) so this should &lt;br/&gt;
be supported.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341138">LANG-118</key>
            <summary>[lang] StringEscapeUtils.unescapeHtml() doesn&apos;t handle hex entities</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mgiles@visionstudio.com">Michael Giles</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 5 Dec 2003 04:53:52 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:31:47 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:31:47 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12405587" author="petebyhre@yahoo.com" created="Sat, 10 Jan 2004 04:27:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Shouldn&apos;t the unescape also handle percent sign prefixed hex values like %20 ?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405588" author="petebyhre@yahoo.com" created="Sat, 10 Jan 2004 07:32:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=9887)&lt;br/&gt;
added handling for &apos;%xx&apos; escapes and fixed bug for &apos;&amp;amp;#x&apos; escapes&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405589" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Sat, 10 Jan 2004 09:04:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Is the %nn format part of the HTML spec? &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I know &amp;amp;#x and &amp;amp;#X are: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/charset.html#h-5.3.1&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/charset.html#h-5.3.1&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405590" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Sat, 10 Jan 2004 09:09:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In the future, please use the patch format so we can see what the changes are:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/patches.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/patches.html&lt;/a&gt;. Thanks.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405591" author="fredrik.westermarck@mdh.se" created="Sat, 10 Jan 2004 09:40:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The &apos;%nn&apos; encoding is for encoding URLs/URIs and not for encoding HTML.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405592" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Sat, 10 Jan 2004 11:00:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve fixed &quot;&amp;#xN;&quot; and &quot;&amp;#XN;&quot; in CVS. The &quot;%nn&quot; format is out of the scope of&lt;br/&gt;
this API. A unit tests has been added. Please check it out and confirm that this&lt;br/&gt;
addresses your issue. Thanks!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405593" author="bayard" created="Sun, 13 Jun 2004 11:43:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;According to the comments in this, this is done. Considering it fixed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

            <title>[LANG-117] [lang] FastDateFormat: wrong format for date &quot;01.01.1000&quot;</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-117</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;FastDateFromat.getInstance(&quot;dd.MM.yyyy&quot;).format(date) returns &quot;01.01.01000&quot;,&lt;br/&gt;
when date is 1 Januar 1000 (01.01.1000)&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12343050">LANG-117</key>
            <summary>[lang] FastDateFormat: wrong format for date &quot;01.01.1000&quot;</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

                            <comment id="12411820" author="bayard" created="Mon, 1 May 2006 11:49:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=18210)&lt;br/&gt;
Unit test&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411821" author="bayard" created="Mon, 1 May 2006 12:30:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Running through the source, the problem is that:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;log(1000) / log(10)  is 2.9999999999999996 and not 3.0 as it should.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Solving this by simplifying the method of finding out how many digits there are&lt;br/&gt;
in a number - Integer.toString(value).length(). I&apos;ve added an assert for value&lt;br/&gt;
being negative (using Validate). Just in case. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411822" author="bayard" created="Mon, 1 May 2006 12:32:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Adding unit test for #39410. Implementing fix by switching from using Math.log&lt;br/&gt;
to Integer.toString to figure out the number of digits.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Sending        src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/time/FastDateFormat.java&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/test/org/apache/commons/lang/time/FastDateFormatTest.java&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-116] Enum&apos;s outer class may not be loaded for EnumUtils</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-116</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I have a class with an Enum inner class, and I call MyClass.MyEnum.getEnumList()&lt;br/&gt;
in a JSP page (with Tomcat 3.3.1).  I&apos;m using enums pretty much exactly as&lt;br/&gt;
described in Enum&apos;s javadoc.  It returns an empty Collection, even though I have&lt;br/&gt;
defined several enums.  At any point in the JSP page after I reference a&lt;br/&gt;
specific Enum, the list shows up properly populated.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;What&apos;s happening is presumably a classloader issue, where&lt;br/&gt;
MyClass.MyEnum.getEnumList() can be called without loading this class.  Perhaps&lt;br/&gt;
Tomcat&apos;s multiple classloaders make this possible.  In any case, the workaround&lt;br/&gt;
is easy.  I changed:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        public static List getEnumList() &lt;/p&gt;
{
            return getEnumList(MyEnum.class);
        }

&lt;p&gt;to:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        public static List getEnumList() &lt;/p&gt;
{
            new MyParentClass();
            return getEnumList(MyEnum.class);
        }

&lt;p&gt;for all the methods that need to access the enums.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-114] [lang] Wrong format for date &quot;01.01.1000&quot;</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-114</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;FastDateFormat.getInstance(&quot;dd.MM.yyyy&quot;).format() returns &quot;01.01.01000&quot; instead&lt;br/&gt;
of&quot;01.01.1000&quot; &lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;   public void testFastDateFormatter() throws ParseException&lt;/p&gt;
   {
      final String dateString = &quot;01.01.1000&quot;;
      final SimpleDateFormat simpleDateFormatter = new
SimpleDateFormat(&quot;dd.MM.yyyy&quot;);
      final FastDateFormat fastDateFormatter =
FastDateFormat.getInstance(&quot;dd.MM.yyyy&quot;);
      final Date date = simpleDateFormatter.parse( dateString );
      assertEquals(simpleDateFormatter.format( date ),  dateString,
simpleDateFormatter.format( date ));
      assertEquals(fastDateFormatter.format( date ),  dateString,
fastDateFormatter.format( date ));
   }</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12343049">LANG-114</key>
            <summary>[lang] Wrong format for date &quot;01.01.1000&quot;</summary>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-113] [LANG] SystemUtils does not play nice in an Applet</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-113</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;SystemUtils accesses a number of System properties statically.  Most of them are&lt;br/&gt;
default readable in an unsigned Applet, except for java.class.path.  So, any&lt;br/&gt;
access to SystemUtils from an unsigned Applet causes problems.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340722">LANG-113</key>
            <summary>[LANG] SystemUtils does not play nice in an Applet</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="becke@u.washington.edu">Michael Becke</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 23 May 2003 00:52:40 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:39:44 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:39:44 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12404268" author="becke@u.washington.edu" created="Fri, 23 May 2003 00:53:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=6460)&lt;br/&gt;
possible fix&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404269" author="becke@u.washington.edu" created="Fri, 23 May 2003 00:55:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Attached is a patch that fixes this problem by using a default value when&lt;br/&gt;
java.class.path cannot be read.  This could also be applied to the other&lt;br/&gt;
properties, if necessary.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404270" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Fri, 23 May 2003 04:54:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch applied, with change made to all properties.&lt;br/&gt;
Thanks&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404271" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Fri, 23 May 2003 07:11:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Should a notification be printed on System.err when the SecurityException is &lt;br/&gt;
detected? &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I am wondering if not printing anything will cause people to have to dig deep &lt;br/&gt;
in their debugger just to find out that they need to tweak their security if &lt;br/&gt;
that is appropriate for their configuration. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404272" author="becke@u.washington.edu" created="Fri, 23 May 2003 10:06:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Agreed, burying exceptions like this could be annoying.  Is System.err used in other places in &lt;br/&gt;
Lang?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404273" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Fri, 23 May 2003 10:41:37 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;FYI, the references to System.err are:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Apache Jakarta Commons/lang/src/java - &lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang.exception.ExceptionUtils.printRootCauseStackTrace&lt;br/&gt;
(Throwable) : void&lt;br/&gt;
Apache Jakarta Commons/lang/src/java - &lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang.exception.NestableDelegate.printStackTrace() : void&lt;br/&gt;
Apache Jakarta Commons/lang/src/java - &lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang.reflect.MethodUtils.log(Object) : void&lt;br/&gt;
Apache Jakarta Commons/lang/src/java - &lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang.reflect.MethodUtils.log(Object, Throwable) : void (2 &lt;br/&gt;
matches)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404274" author="becke@u.washington.edu" created="Fri, 23 May 2003 21:47:07 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=6470)&lt;br/&gt;
fix 2&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404275" author="becke@u.washington.edu" created="Fri, 23 May 2003 21:49:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Attached above is a new patch for this problem.  This patch adds an error&lt;br/&gt;
message and changes the default property to &quot;&quot;.  I think defaulting to null is a&lt;br/&gt;
bad idea as it has the potential to cause NPEs.  In particular if java.version&lt;br/&gt;
cannot be read there will be gauranteed NPEs with the IS_JAVA_1_1_* variables.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404276" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sat, 24 May 2003 20:44:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I have added the error message.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I have left the return type as null. This is consistent with the use of this &lt;br/&gt;
class on early JVMs where a property is not available.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I have added code to handle all cases (in SystemUtils) where a field may be &lt;br/&gt;
null.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-112] [lang] Wrong length check in StrTokenizer.StringMatcher</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-112</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The length check in StringMatcher&apos;s isMatch() method causes the matcher to stop&lt;br/&gt;
one character too early. So a match at the very end of the source data won&apos;t be&lt;br/&gt;
detected.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-111] [Lang] time unit tests fail on Sundays</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-111</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The time unit tests fail when run on a Sunday:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;test.time:&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;echo&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Running time package tests ...&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; ...F.F................&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Time: 4.394&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; There were 2 failures:&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 1)&lt;br/&gt;
testParse(org.apache.commons.lang.time.CalendarUtilsTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError:&lt;br/&gt;
parse last Sunday expected Sun Apr 27 06:39:17 MST 2003 but got Sun Apr 20&lt;br/&gt;
06:39:17 MST 2003&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang.time.CalendarUtilsTest.assertEquals(CalendarUtilsTest.java:373)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang.time.CalendarUtilsTest.testParse(CalendarUtilsTest.java:243)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at&lt;br/&gt;
sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at&lt;br/&gt;
sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 2)&lt;br/&gt;
testWeekIterator(org.apache.commons.lang.time.CalendarUtilsTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError:&lt;br/&gt;
 expected Mon Apr 28 00:00:00 MST 2003 but got Mon Apr 21 00:00:00 MST 2003&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang.time.CalendarUtilsTest.assertEquals(CalendarUtilsTest.java:373)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang.time.CalendarUtilsTest.assertWeekIterator(CalendarUtilsTest.java:346)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang.time.CalendarUtilsTest.assertWeekIterator(CalendarUtilsTest.java:324)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang.time.CalendarUtilsTest.testWeekIterator(CalendarUtilsTest.java:284)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at&lt;br/&gt;
sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 	at&lt;br/&gt;
sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Looks to me like the unit test code is checking the value of Calendar.DATE, when&lt;br/&gt;
it should be looking at Calendar.DAY_OF_WEEK (at line 237 and below) to decide&lt;br/&gt;
whether to make adjustments for today==Sunday.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When I fix this, testParse succeeds but testWeekIterator hangs at the statement&lt;br/&gt;
it = CalendarUtils.getCalendarIterator(now, CalendarUtils.RANGE_WEEK_RELATIVE);&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340679">LANG-111</key>
            <summary>[Lang] time unit tests fail on Sundays</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="phil@steitz.com">Phil Steitz</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sun, 27 Apr 2003 21:49:50 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:40:25 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:40:25 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12404154" author="mohankishore@yahoo.com" created="Wed, 30 Apr 2003 02:52:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Just a note, the CalendarUtils.getCalendarIterator(now, &lt;br/&gt;
CalendarUtils.RANGE_WEEK_RELATIVE) hangs irrespective of the changes to the &lt;br/&gt;
test-case. i.e. it will always hang if run on a sunday.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It is just getting highlighted as currently, the assert just ahead of it fails &lt;br/&gt;
on sundays. Hence, either everything runs fine, or the (unrelated) assert in &lt;br/&gt;
front of it fails.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As suggested, there are 2 places currently which need to be &lt;br/&gt;
Calendar.DAY_OF_WEEK and not DATE. The RANGE_WEEK_RELATIVE logic needs to be &lt;br/&gt;
investigated.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404155" author="mohankishore@yahoo.com" created="Wed, 30 Apr 2003 03:30:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=6081)&lt;br/&gt;
DATE to DAY_OF_WEEK, in test-case and minor fix in CalendarUtils&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404156" author="phil@steitz.com" created="Sat, 24 May 2003 11:02:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I am attaching another patch to CalendarUtilsTest.java that runs&lt;br/&gt;
testWeekIterator() in a loop, incrementing the reference date in a loop to hit&lt;br/&gt;
all days of the week.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This patch also fixes the error in the test identified above (Calendar.DATE&lt;br/&gt;
should be Calendar.DAY_OF_WEEK) in two places.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Applying this patch will cause the test to hang, since it exposes the&lt;br/&gt;
CalendarUtils bug identified (and patched) by Mohan above.  This bug causes&lt;br/&gt;
getCalendarIterator(Calendar focus, int rangeStyle) to go into an infinite loop&lt;br/&gt;
when focus is a Sunday and rangeStyle is RANGE_WEEK_RELATIVE.  Mohan&apos;s patch to&lt;br/&gt;
CalendarUtils handles the boundary cases.  When it is applied, all tests,&lt;br/&gt;
(including the loop addition) succeed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404157" author="phil@steitz.com" created="Sat, 24 May 2003 11:04:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=6476)&lt;br/&gt;
patch to run testWeekIterator in a loop over start days&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404158" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Mon, 9 Jun 2003 06:18:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;All patches applied, plus many other changes in time package.&lt;br/&gt;
Thanks for the patches.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>0|i0d6pz:</customfieldvalue>

                        </customfieldvalues>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-109] [lang] HashCodeBuilder failed to generate unique hashcode</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-109</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;HashCodeBuilder class failed to generate unique hashcode for objects.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here are codes to reproduce the problem:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import org.apache.commons.lang.builder.HashCodeBuilder;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public class Person&lt;br/&gt;
{&lt;br/&gt;
    public int id;&lt;br/&gt;
    public String name;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public Person(int id, String name)&lt;/p&gt;
    {
        this.id=id;
        this.name = name;
    }

&lt;p&gt;    public int hashCode()&lt;/p&gt;
    {
        return new HashCodeBuilder(17,37).
                append(id).
                append(name).
                toHashCode();
    }
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;package com.ball.edi.prototype;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public class TestHashCode&lt;br/&gt;
{&lt;br/&gt;
    static public void main(String args[])&lt;/p&gt;
    {
        Person p1=new Person(214686, &quot;03065&quot;);
        Person p2=new Person(214691, &quot;03006&quot;);

        System.out.println(&quot;The hashcode for p1 is &quot; + p1.hashCode());
        System.out.println(&quot;The hashcode for p2 is &quot; + p2.hashCode());
    }
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When you ran TestHashCode class, you will get &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The hashcode for p1 is 53862859&lt;br/&gt;
The hashcode for p2 is 53862859&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I found this problem when I am using OJB.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341890">LANG-109</key>
            <summary>[lang] HashCodeBuilder failed to generate unique hashcode</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="4">Incomplete</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bsun@ball.com">Bruce Sun</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 24 Nov 2004 03:25:13 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 6 Feb 2007 23:47:15 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 6 Feb 2007 23:47:15 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12408155" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Wed, 24 Nov 2004 04:25:37 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This might be a case where the pattern:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        return new HashCodeBuilder(17,37).&lt;br/&gt;
                append(id).&lt;br/&gt;
                append(name).&lt;br/&gt;
                toHashCode();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;is not a fit the domain object. If the &quot;id&quot; is unique you can just return the id&lt;br/&gt;
for the hash code. The general case where the id AND the name need to be used as&lt;br/&gt;
a  primary key is going to be a problem for hash codes in general I think since&lt;br/&gt;
we only have the int range.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Anyone else care to comment please?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408156" author="bsun@ball.com" created="Wed, 24 Nov 2004 05:21:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I just created the simple code so that the problem can be easily reproduced.&lt;br/&gt;
The problem actually happened in using OJB to query data from AS400/DB2&lt;br/&gt;
database where usually several columns are together used as primary keys.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Bruce&lt;br/&gt;
(In reply to comment #1)&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; This might be a case where the pattern:&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt;         return new HashCodeBuilder(17,37).&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt;                 append(id).&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt;                 append(name).&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt;                 toHashCode();&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; is not a fit the domain object. If the &quot;id&quot; is unique you can just return the id&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; for the hash code. The general case where the id AND the name need to be used as&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; a  primary key is going to be a problem for hash codes in general I think since&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; we only have the int range.&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; Anyone else care to comment please?&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12408157" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Wed, 24 Nov 2004 07:21:45 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you want to use and int and a String together as a primary key/hash code,&lt;br/&gt;
then I think you will run into issues unless the value range of id and name can&lt;br/&gt;
be reduced. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Hash codes are ints, so you can have as many unique hash codes for a set of&lt;br/&gt;
objects as you can have ints, which is Integer.MIN_VALUE to Integer.MAX_VALUE. A&lt;br/&gt;
simplification would be to say that you can have Integer.MAX_VALUE * 2 hash codes.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If your int id can have all int legal values AND you can have any String to&lt;br/&gt;
create your primary keys then you&apos;ll run out of int hash codes to cover all the&lt;br/&gt;
cases.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So, defining the legal range of values for id and name is where to start. From&lt;br/&gt;
there, a proper hashCode() method can be coded. We can then see how the&lt;br/&gt;
HashCodeBuilder class be improved to help you.&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12408158" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Thu, 25 Nov 2004 08:12:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The problem with this bug report is the initial statement.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;HashCodeBuilder class failed to generate unique hashcode for objects.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;HashCodes are not unique.&lt;br/&gt;
I suggest reading the Javadoc of Object.hashCode() to clarify this point.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408159" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Thu, 25 Nov 2004 08:50:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Indeed I should have been more careful in my comment. Thanks for clarifying.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For reference from the Sun Javadoc: &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;As much as is reasonably practical, the hashCode method defined by class Object&lt;br/&gt;
does return distinct integers for distinct objects. (This is typically&lt;br/&gt;
implemented by converting the internal address of the object into an integer,&lt;br/&gt;
but this implementation technique is not required by the JavaTM programming&lt;br/&gt;
language.)&quot;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408160" author="bsun@ball.com" created="Tue, 30 Nov 2004 03:06:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I appended the string first and then integer and seem to get different&lt;br/&gt;
hashcode back. But the problem may come back for some other combinations.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Many thanks for comments posted.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Bruce&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408161" author="bayard" created="Sat, 18 Dec 2004 11:51:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Stephen&apos;s point seems to nullify this as being a bug. Marking as INVALID (sorry&lt;br/&gt;
it&apos;s such a cold term Bruce).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-107] FastDateFormat year bug</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-107</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Jerson Chua reports in an email entitled: &quot;FastDateFormat year bug &quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I used FastDateFormat to convert a date object to string using this pattern yyyy-MM-dd.&lt;br/&gt;
No zeros are padded if I my year is 0001. I&#226;&#128;&#153;m getting 1-01-01.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;After looking through the code, I replaced line 498&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;rule = UnpaddedNumberField.INSTANCE_YEAR;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;to&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;rule = selectNumberRule(Calendar.YEAR, tokenLen);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;And it fixed the problem.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341716">LANG-107</key>
            <summary>FastDateFormat year bug</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bayard">Henri Yandell</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sun, 12 Sep 2004 12:10:51 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 16 Oct 2013 08:54:56 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:20:48 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>

                            <comment id="12407538" author="bayard" created="Wed, 26 Apr 2006 13:11:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;2.1 released, closing.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-106] [lang] StringUtils#getLevenshteinDistance() performance is sub-optimal</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-106</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The implementation of Commons Lang StringUtils#getLevenshteinDistance(String,&lt;br/&gt;
String) is based on work from &amp;lt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.merriampark.com/ld.htm&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.merriampark.com/ld.htm&lt;/a&gt;&amp;gt;. While this&lt;br/&gt;
implementation works, it is &lt;b&gt;very&lt;/b&gt; memory hungry and can thus slow down heavy&lt;br/&gt;
computations (GC has much more to collect in memory-constrained environment).&lt;br/&gt;
Actual implementation needs x*y byte of memory.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;An improved implementation can be found at&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.merriampark.com/ldjava.htm&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.merriampark.com/ldjava.htm&lt;/a&gt;&amp;gt;, which can lead to performance&lt;br/&gt;
improvements of up to 3 times (my own internal benchmarks in low-memory&lt;br/&gt;
situation). This new implementation needs x+y bytes of memory.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please change the getLevenshteinDistance() implementation to use the one at&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.merriampark.com/ldjava.htm&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.merriampark.com/ldjava.htm&lt;/a&gt;&amp;gt;.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342963">LANG-106</key>
            <summary>[lang] StringUtils#getLevenshteinDistance() performance is sub-optimal</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-105] [lang] ExceptionUtils goes into infinite loop in getThrowables is throwable.getCause() == throwable</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-105</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The ExceptionUtils.getThrowables(throwable) can loop for ever if&lt;br/&gt;
throwable.getCause() == throwable.&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;The following code should fix this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public static Throwable[] getThrowables(final Throwable throwable) {&lt;br/&gt;
        List list = new ArrayList();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        if (throwable != null) {&lt;br/&gt;
            Throwable cause = throwable.getCause();&lt;br/&gt;
            list.add(throwable);&lt;br/&gt;
            while (cause != null &amp;amp;&amp;amp; cause != throwable) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                list.add(cause);
                cause = ExceptionUtils.getCause(cause);
            }
&lt;p&gt;        }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        return (Throwable[]) list.toArray(new Throwable&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;list.size()&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;);&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also, the getCauseUsingWellKnownTypes(throwable) should be enhanced to avoid the&lt;br/&gt;
same problems:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    private static Throwable getCauseUsingWellKnownTypes(Throwable throwable) {&lt;br/&gt;
        if (throwable instanceof Nestable &amp;amp;&amp;amp; throwable.getCause() != throwable) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            return ((Nestable) throwable).getCause();
        }
&lt;p&gt; else if (throwable instanceof SQLException) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            return ((SQLException) throwable).getNextException();
        }
&lt;p&gt; else if (throwable instanceof InvocationTargetException) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            return ((InvocationTargetException) throwable).getTargetException();
        }
&lt;p&gt; else &lt;/p&gt;
{
            return null;
        }
&lt;p&gt;    }&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Cheers&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Andy&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows 2000&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342623">LANG-105</key>
